Cavill broods handsomely as Superman, but this reboot skimps on fun and romance.
Even at the age of 77, Redford can command a screen, and he's the main reason to watch this man-against-nature story.
And the award for Best Actor in a Disappointing Movie goes to... Benedict Cumberbatch as Julian Assange in "The Fifth Estate."
Though it's nothing you haven't seen before, it's so artfully made and skillfully executed that you won't care a bit.
Battle of the Year is too inept to make this tired premise sing.
"Thanks for Sharing" has several nice moments and understated insights, but it never quite gets to the heart of its subject.
In another movie, either of these men -- the arrogant hunk, the frozen robot -- might have been our villain. But screenwriter Peter Morgan ("Frost/Nixon") has a deeper insight.
A small-scale movie made much bigger by achingly good performances from Louis-Dreyfus and Gandolfini in one of his final roles.
Mostly, "Cloudy 2" relies on the usual noxious recipe for junky kid flicks: loud noise, pop music and poop jokes.
movie_title: Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 2 (2013)

movie_review_blurb: With nothing new to offer, "Carrie" is reduced to attempting the impossible: repeating De Palma's long, tense buildup to Carrie's prom, one of the most stylishly executed horror-film sequences in history.
Rarely has a film offered such raw and honest talk -- with visuals, too -- about male sexuality.
The assassination of John F. Kennedy, as seen through the eyes of bystanders, insiders and other players.
The movie mostly wants to look timely and seem topical. Instead, it feels irrelevant.
Let Me In is one of the few horror films that will trouble you long after the credits roll.
This is the kind of gripping thriller for the age of globalization that director Paul Greengrass has been honing in movies like "United 93" and "The Green Zone."
It's saved by an enjoyably loopy script, several surprisingly strong performances, and the inventive direction of Robert Rodriguez, whose low-budget creativity is a performance in itself.
"12 Years a Slave" works on so many levels -- some topical, some timeless -- that it's almost impossible to count them.
It's a rare combination of jaw-dropping special effects and visual artistry, and it also works as slam-bang entertainment with just two actors and a swift running time of 90 minutes.
"Before Midnight" is heartbreaking, but not because of Jesse and Celine. It's the filmmakers' passions that seem to have cooled.
It would rather mock its protagonists than help us understand them.
With no outsiders to coddle, this tight-knit ensemble locks into a groove and reaches some truly giddy heights, turning even the weakest material (a spoof of "The Exorcist") into anarchic fun.
"Parker" winds up with the worst of both worlds: It's pointlessly violent and nauseatingly cute.
The magic is in the details, from the little surprises to the colorful casting.
"Stand Up Guys" is mostly a string of low-key, almost-amusing chats over breakfast tables and pool tables, as if just watching these actors exhale should be entertaining enough.
"Koch" is a treasure trove of little moments that illuminate a famously cantankerous, sharp-elbowed, showboating personality.
"Side Effects" has the sleek, chic look of a Soderbergh film -- cool colors, seductive lighting -- but the script, by frequent collaborator Scott Z. Burns, is disappointingly clunky.
The darkness in this comedy is exactly what makes it work so well.
"Amour" isn't just a great movie, it's a movie that may actually do you some good.

Frenetically directed by John Moore from a sketchy script by Skip Woods, A Good Day to Die Hard has the dubious distinction of making John McClane unlikeable. He's had some bad days in the past, but this one finally got him down.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: In the end, "Beautiful Creatures" has one overarching problem: It's boring.
It isn't arty or intellectual, though it is artful and ingenious, and it's the rare crowd-pleaser that never feels obvious or pandering.
A powerful back story does not necessarily improve a movie, but The King's Speech has a pretty irresistible one. It might even end with a dramatic night at the Oscars in February.
A challenge that offers zero rewards.
"Jack the Giant Slayer" is the kind of old-fashioned, entertaining fantasy-adventure you once saw regularly in theaters.
All, or at least some, might be forgiven if there were just one likable character or memorable joke.
"Safe Haven" is passably engaging and almost works as a proper thriller. Then -- wham! Sparks throws that schmaltz pie right in your kisser.
A reasonably smart, imaginative spin on the 1939 MGM classic.
Always cute and breezy, "Quartet" often forgets that its protagonists are in a sobering stage of life, and that there's comedy to be found there as well.
"The Last Stand," Arnold Schwarzenegger's first star vehicle in more than a decade, is not a sci-fi film, though it does travel back in time.
Loyal fans may love the nonstop riot of imagery and music, though others may not even comprehend what's happening on screen.
There's a fine line between macho wish fulfillment and delusional fantasy, and "Jack Reacher" crosses it.
"This Is 40" turns out to be an opportunity squandered.

This is a big story, with big themes, based on Victor Hugo's really big novel about love, law and revolution in 19th-century France. Yet somehow, "Les Misérables" isn't the major movie event it should be.
Unfortunately, it wears out its welcome about two-thirds through, which means -- no kidding -- 45 more minutes to go.
If you're looking for an all-ages crowd-pleaser, this may be your best bet.
More effective than you might expect.
A movie that feels at once deeply personal and more than a little confused.
The tsunami comes to life more vividly than the characters, though Watts and young Holland, as her son, deliver strong performances.
It's tough to come up with new superlatives for Meryl Streep, but the 63-year-old actress delivers her most frankly sexual performance yet in Hope Springs.
Mixed martial-arts star Carano puts major muscle, if minor acting ability, into this enjoyable action flick.
A good-looking cast and strong action sequences are just enough to forgive the cornball script.
You couldn't ask for a more random relationship, but "Rust and Bone" slowly, almost magically, gives it meaning, symbolism, even a kind of symmetry.
movie_title: De rouille et d'os (Rust and Bone) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: "Broken City" wants to get heavy about politics and corruption, but all it's really saying is: 'Twas ever thus.
A well-intentioned look at a fraught issue, but the Damon-Krasinski screenplay ultimately opts for Hollywood oversimplification.
"The Hobbit" is an impressive first chapter.
This potentially interesting dilemma becomes thoroughly dull in the hands of director Peter Webber, who stages endless conversations about political fine points without giving us much to look at.
[It] fumbles so badly that you can almost make out the flop-sweat on its brow.
The usual winks and snarks from Tony Stark, but this edition feels fresher and funnier, thanks to writer- director Shane Black.
Fairly insightful as a drama, but barely adequate as a thriller. Ahmed is pitch-perfect as the conflicted hero, but he's in two movies that cancel each other out.
The fourth adaptation of the Fitzgerald novel scores some hits and wild misses, but DiCaprio nails the bull's-eye.
"Peeples" is a just-this-side-of-legal knockoff of "Meet the Parents," altered only by minor script details and an African-American cast.

In the end, "At Any Price" strikes a dark, even ghastly tone, and rather suddenly it becomes a cynical commentary on small-town hypocrisy and American business. It's hard to tell whether that was the intention.
"Into Darkness" is fast and fun, zipping along on all thrusters while everyone on the bridge settles comfortably into an agreeably lighthearted vibe (and into ever-slimmer outfits).
You may feel the grisly laughs sticking in your throat.
Upbeat and less exciting than you might wish, though it could be a good adventure film for older kids.
A comedown from the high of "Fast Five," but the physics-be-damned stuntwork and girl-on-girl beatdowns keep this series the guiltiest of pleasures.
Late-blooming 20-somethings have never been so perfectly captured -- and Gerwig has never been more appealing -- than in this funny, tender, life-affirming movie.
"After Earth" isn't just chaotic and desperate -- and grindingly slow -- it's also lazy.
It's almost as cynical as the actual Twilight, and not nearly as funny.
It's a well-timed comedy about unemployment, technology and the generation gap, and its comforting main message is that the world will always need the kind of guy known as a people person.
The vague posters for "The Purge" won't prepare you for how sharp and shockingly subversive this home-invasion flick can be.
It seems to have one goal: to be so dark, nasty and joyless that audiences won't want Part IV.
This blend of Scandinavian gloom and Hollywood hokum never jells.
Rob Zombie, film scholar? I'm convinced. Rob Zombie, filmmaker? Mmmyeah, not so much.
The film offers a lot to chew on for boomers -- and for aging punks and indie-rockers -- who may still be wondering whether they made a separate peace with The System or simply gave up the fight.
It promisingly pairs Fey with the dreamy-funny Paul Rudd, though they generate warmth without ever catching fire. The bigger problem is the story they're in.
The junky pleasures of the first installment now just seem like junk in this noisy, nonsensical, lead-footed sequel.
A sci-fi writer like Philip K. Dick ("Blade Runner") might have used this premise to explore notions of memory and identity. Meyer uses it to create a teen soap opera.
If Perry has had one strength as a dramatist, it's been his willingness to empathize with villains as well as victims. In Temptation, he lacks even that.
"Jurassic Park" remains an absolute thrill from a Spielberg in top form: Funny, scary, fast-moving and full of just-right details.
"Evil Dead" turns Raimi's homemade horror treat into a professional-looking, overscripted bore.
Journalists lie, spouses stray and thieves steal, but "Disconnect" keeps trying, unsuccessfully, to pin the blame on technology rather than its users.

It's a sweet little tale, and that co-writer Tony Briggs is the son of one of the real-life singers adds to the heart-tugging. In the end, though, it's not quite enough to sustain a feature-length film.
Its three stories are so loosely connected, its themes so scattered -- morality, justice, fate, fatherhood -- that it never manages to make a point.
"No Place on Earth" depends heavily on re-enactments, but Tobias handles them delicately and keeps a lid on any overemoting.
It isn't Streep's fault that The Iron Lady ends up feeling so uninvolving and oddly dour.
It's fresh, funny, inventive and unique.
Let's hope Branagh was well-compensated, at least. To quote his favorite author: No profit grows where is no pleasure taken.
Playing spot-the-influence is the most fun you'll have during this expensive-looking, slow-moving plod through familiar territory.
This big-budget period piece is more concerned with burnishing a legend than dramatizing a life.
The material sometimes feels oversugared, though it's also guaranteed to raise a lump in your throat.
If you're puzzled by the Coen Brothers' horrific comedies, this is the closest thing you'll get to an explanation.
The Sitter seems to have a good heart, so why all the glib racism?
Check your credulity at the door, and you'll at least enjoy some high-impact action scenes.
An uneven blend of realism and fantasy. The movie is both vivid and baffling -- which is to say, it was made by Spike Lee.
The movie spends a lot of time trying to be cute, vulgar and cutely vulgar. But it forgets about character, plot and believability.
Fanning is exceptional, anchoring the film with the confidence of an actress thrice her age.
Appaloosa satisfies all its requirements but never breaks a sweat.
[Knightley] breathes real life into the role of Georgiana Cavendish, an 18th century aristocrat with striking parallels to another, more modern, British notable.
A slightly poky thriller punctuated by some effectively tense scenes.
This mix of lovingly-written characters and terribly hokey plots makes for an uneven but occasionally engaging drama.
Towelhead spreads itself thin trying to tackle too many issues, but the nuanced characters, and an absolutely stellar cast, make this an uncommonly complex and compelling drama.
An ensemble this good guarantees some lively moments, but the film's outdated message seems more empowering for men.
Doesn't stand up to Fargo or Blood Simple, but it's a chance to watch some top-notch actors jump their rails and head into terra bizarro.
Bangkok Dangerous pretends to have a lot on its mind. It moves slow as molasses and has the same general coloring.

There are heroes, battles and triumphs -- but no villains -- in Save Me, a thoughtful, nuanced drama about guilt-stricken gay men trying to fix their 'sexual brokenness' at a Christian recovery house.
Sex, murder, insanity, perversity -- A Girl Cut in Two has it all, yet it stands as a singularly classy and sophisticated drama.
movie_title: La Fille Coupée en Deux (The Girl Cut in Two) (A Girl Cut in Two) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Romantic comedies don't always have the strongest concepts, but Everybody Wants to Be Italian begins with what barely qualifies as an idea.
For all the visual originality, Sukiyaki seems framed by quotes, a long string of self-conscious references to other films, notably the 1966 Italian Western Django.
To call Traitor deeper than the average Hollywood thriller may not be saying much, but the film deserves credit for trying to both challenge and entertain its audience.
This comedy-drama is wafer-thin, but Marsan gives it some heft as an all-too-human father.
Without Leo, Frozen River wouldn't be nearly as compelling as it is.
An uneven but entertaining action-comedy that answers a question you've probably never asked: What if someone gave Cheech and Chong a shot of testosterone and a couple of Uzis?
It's hard to get too involved in the story lines, which unfold like four half-hour television series quilted together. And the stakes are generally low: Which hunk to choose?
movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants 2 (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The film's soaring climax becomes surprisingly emotional thanks to testimony from those lucky enough to have witnessed it.
The film's faux-documentary style is a distraction, but it fades in and out. Secret is most compelling when the people and places of L.A. tell this tragic but somehow still ebullient story.
A thoughtful study on the way foreign wars can reverberate here at home.
Gory, vulgar and wickedly funny. Easily the summer's best comedy.
The Lucas universe once held a special magic, but The Clone Wars makes that feel like a long time ago in a theater far, far away.
For a mildly quirky comedy-drama, Henry Poole Is Here has some surprising philosophical heft.
The animation is so stiff it makes South Park look like Walt Disney's Fantasia.
The Rocker qualifies as a B-side, but it still makes for a passable summer single.
Hamlet 2 is a tour-de-force from Coogan (the director in Tropic Thunder), who's never been more wonderfully, wildly unhinged.
Death Race may be a loud, lowbrow piece of pulp, but it's also crackling entertainment -- the very definition of a cheap thrill.
Another year, another minor masterpiece from writer-director Woody Allen.
Nonstop weirdness plus an oddly touching performance by Rockwell make for an uneven, fitfully funny film.
Blindness is a face-first dive into the horror of human nature -- call it Lord of the Blind Flies -- with several memorably harrowing scenes and a compelling cast.

It's a nasty, condescending, small-minded film, self-amused and ultimately self-defeating. Its only accomplishment is to make atheists look bad -- and in this political climate they didn't need Maher's help with that.
An entertaining, ingenious yarn, despite a few loose ends.
The action and eye candy may be worth the ticket price, but this Bond needs to get back to business.
With its vapor-thin plot and goofy gimmicks (game of vampire baseball, anyone?), Twilight seems best left to its impressionable teenage fans.
Familiar territory, but the Disney team still knows how to bring a story to life.
Rudd, who co-wrote the script with director David Wain (among others), clearly learned a few things working on Judd Apatow comedies.
The sweetness grows cloying by the end, but perhaps that's fitting for a film that's so clearly a labor of love.
Seagal, it's your turn.
Halfway through, Australia veers sharply into Serious Issue mode.
Van Sant works from a script by Dustin Lance Black to tell Milk's story clearly and forcefully.
Fast, crisp and lively, the film packs a half-dozen stories into two hours with little time for melodrama or sermonizing. The dialogue is quick and sharp; short scenes make powerful points.
Sheen and Langella originated their respective roles in the play, and it's clear why Langella won a Tony for his.

Marvel's latest chunk of comic-book pulp strikes the usual brooding poses, but the film is so utterly ridiculous -- make that bloody ridiculous -- that its self-induced giggle fits become downright hilarious.
The Reader asks profound questions about guilt and redemption, but its answers are misguided and misleading.

Part modern-day Western, part vigilante flick, part after-school special, Clint Eastwood's oddball drama Grand Torino remains entertaining right up to the end credits, during which you can scratch your head and wonder what you've just seen.
Like a gift card in your stocking, the romantic comedy Four Christmases is pretty generic, though you might still be grateful for it.

Smartly written by Jason Richman and Joshua Michael Stern (who also directed), Swing Vote isn't a realistic film -- it veers off course with a subplot involving Molly's absent mother -- but it often has the ring of truth.
If you've seen The Thing or The Evil Dead, you've seen much of Splinter, but it's a lean, fast-moving and fun little flick that doesn't waste any of its scant 82 minutes.
If this film were about teenagers, it might seem less like an outrageous comedy and more like a mundane slice of life.
movie_title: Zack and Miri Make a Porno (2008)

movie_review_blurb: This film rises slightly above convention thanks to Kinnear's strong performance as its not entirely likable hero.
A surprise charmer that mixes family-friendly slapstick with shrewd adult humor.
At its best, this movie feels like a real experience, thanks to terrific performances and Demme's informal direction.
Is there any filmmaker alive, whether Democrat or Republican, conservative or liberal, capable of producing a truly incisive, intelligent satire about our politically polarized times?
A passable Friday night flick.
An entertaining kids' film with more imagination than most.
Wong's reworking hasn't made Ashes more coherent, but it's still a gorgeous enigma.
Writer-director Leigh, maintaining a deceptively freewheeling tone throughout, creates a comedy that's also something much more.

Hollywood loves to satirize itself using its own medium. But with few exceptions -- The Player comes to mind -- the laughs are rarely as wicked as they should be, and the skewers barely break the skin. So it is with What Just Happened.
Sex Drive may slather on the gross-out humor, but underneath it has a heart.
It's devastating.
movie_title: Une Vieille Maîtresse (The Last Mistress) (An Old Mistress) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: You can't create camp on purpose.
Kaufman is full of ideas but doesn't know when to quit.
Thank goodness Lionsgate made another Saw film! Otherwise, how would we as a country get to feel good about ourselves while watching humans suffer through prolonged torture, degradation and death?
RocknRolla marks a pulpy return to form for Ritchie.
The film fizzles in the second half, when flashy effects replace coherent storytelling, and everyone goes all weepy over the innate decency of humanity.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Though it tries to juice up its mojo with currently popular Asian themes and martial-arts sequences, this Mummy seems a teeny bit musty.
movie_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It's entertaining, often funny and ultimately endearing, thanks mainly to its ensemble cast.

David Ayer, who wrote Training Day, directs with enough flash to keep the action crisp and nasty. But he can't swagger his way through Ellroy's swampy storyline, which traps its characters in cynicism and amorality.
Both behind and before the camera, Clooney imbues Leatherheads with an irresistible charm and intelligence, raising it far above the average period piece.
At some point in Shutter you will probably lose count, along with your patience, but the film will keep right on going.
If you never twirled barefoot in the funky old club, Wetlands Preserved may be of limited interest, but it's a loving and thorough document of a small slice of rock history.
movie_title: Wetlands Preserved: The Story of an Activist Rock Club (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Ribas delivers a natural, earthy performance that has helped this film win numerous awards on the festival circuit.
Somewhere between the acrobatic dance sequences and lead-footed script of How She Move there exist fleeting glimpses of a serious film that could have been.
It's a lovely portrait of a fabled time and place, but wasn't there a bit of ugliness, too?
Ostensibly a Christmastime comedy about romance, The Perfect Holiday manages to be none of the above.
Writer-director Guy Ritchie returns to his Brit-pulp roots, only this time he gets all intellectual, too. It's a deadly combination.

[Director Temple's] documentary can be quite clear-eyed, especially when exploring Strummer's lesser-known years before and after The Clash. As Strummer attempts to define and redefine himself, he seems human but still heroic.
movie_title: Joe Strummer: The Future Is Unwritten (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Pete Seeger: The Power of Song could have been called Pete Seeger: The First Punk. As the film traces the singer's long life, it also, inevitably, tracks the evolution of American countercultures through much of the 20th century.
movie_title: Pete Seeger: The Power of Song (2007)

movie_review_blurb: You don't have to be black to enjoy the film, but you do need a strong desire to watch people work out their issues using pop-psychology and self-help techniques.

Instead of trying to find the heartbeat of reggaetón, the movie resorts to teen conventions, banking that its target audience -- Latino teens, who don't often see themselves onscreen -- won't know enough to demand better.
This second-rate action drama features a mostly Latino but mostly wasted cast.
The director, Asger Leth, isn't terribly organized, but he puts us smack in the middle of everything: petty squabbles, horrible riots, casual shootings, even a love triangle.

So many computer-animated movies are brash, loud and popping with pop-culture comedy, but Ratatouille has the warm glow of a favorite book. The characters are more than the sum of their gigabyte-consuming parts -- they feel handcrafted.
Once or twice the film reveals its good intentions and gets a laugh, but mostly it feels like a store-bought mix of jokes and sentiments.
The Coen brothers' latest is one of their best, a bittersweet rumination on creative ambition and youthful dreams.
Been Rich All My Life has a soft, golden glow, but it could have been much richer.
Like Hitchcock or Clouzot, Chabrol excels at building a sense of dread.
The technophobic horror flick Pulse is a cautionary tale that could have been dreamed up by a frustrated parent: If you don't get off of that computer, kids, you'll turn into a zombie.
It's nice to spend time in a mostly sunny world where everyone ends up happy. Except, that is, for the worms.
This is a nice Cinderella story, but here's the problem: It doesn't exactly crackle with drama.
movie_title: LoudQUIETloud: A Film About the Pixies (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Quaid finds what is funny and endearing and worthy in the character, and his performance holds this fine, if somewhat fragile, film together.

Much of the nearly two-hour film consists of impassioned but lengthy speeches about interest rates, deficits, poverty and corruption. This is no way to entertain an audience, so Sissako throws in a few hastily drawn characters and a threadbare plot.
The plot isn't much, but that's OK: The directing team of Will Speck and Josh Gordon throw their jokes at the wall in rapid succession, and most of them stick.
... promises slightly more than it delivers but still comes together nicely.
Head-scratching mash-up of zany dance numbers, gooey romance (but no kissing) and random English phrases such as 'awesome,' "bad habit' and 'noisy birthday parties.'
The Hip Hop Project has a good heart and more than a little trouble organizing its thoughts.

Like any good documentarian (and unlike most publicists), Klores lets us draw our own conclusions. With a tone free of outrage or judgment, he tells the story of Pugach, a successful young lawyer, and Riss, a hottie with a taste for the good life.
A sensitive case-study of a promising artist who fell afoul of the system but still managed, with the help of family, to reassemble his shattered life.
One problem with Terabithia is that the director, Gabor Csupo, puts too much stock in the abilities of computer graphics to make things real.
If you lower your expectations and keep a sense of humor, even that large popcorn will seem worth the money.

It won't spoil anything to reveal that Spurlock doesn't find his man, but his failure to do so -- even though it's played for laughs -- is a cowardly cop-out that unintentionally mocks the very real dangers of life in the Middle East.
movie_title: Where in the World Is Osama Bin Laden? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Stein claims to denounce the tyranny of dogma, then browbeats us with his own.
A finely observed, compelling drama with the creepy tinge of a thriller.
The overall glow remains golden, of course. But with a dash of realism and more than a little intelligence, Kit Kittredge becomes a kiddie film that's worth an adult ticket, too.
Get Smart does all it can to please; thanks mostly to Carell, it just barely succeeds.

The Love Guru scrapes bottom for laughs, resorting to pop-culture jokes (Lindsay, Britney), weak musical numbers (Dolly Parton's '9 to 5' on sitar) and, most abysmally, the sight of two elephants doing it.
Despite terrific efforts from its lead players, Expired runs its meter out long before the end.

Wanted demands a high level of credulity, but in exchange it offers some rewards: improbable car-chases, gritty hand-to-hand combat and the sight of Angelina Jolie poured into her pants and packing a pistol.
Granted, this documentary (surely the weirdest ever funded by the Discovery Channel) could have used more editing. But it's the notebook of a genius, and well worth cracking open.
movie_title: Encounters at the End of the World (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Like Charlie Chaplin's best silents -- a clear influence -- WALL-E is pure visual magic. As a bonus, it packs a wicked satirical punch.

Hellboy II, like its 2004 predecessor, has a middling story line, but it's made memorable by the dark, freaky visions of director Guillermo del Toro. And this time, his imagination runs wilder than ever.
Journey may be an utterly weightless movie, but in the end it floats rather nicely.
movie_title: Journey to the Center of the Earth (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It's a comic-book movie, but it's also a dark and highly complex drama.

The ingredients seem perfect: a stellar cast, an unassailable soundtrack and source material from a proven hit. Somehow, though, this sugary mix turns into a sour hairball that will have you gagging to expel it for 108 minutes.
For die-hard Reed fans, it's an invaluable document.
Nudie magazines, dog poop, words like 'mangina' -- if these are a few of your favorite things, Step Brothers is the comedy for you.
Director Peter Berg knows the difference between cartoon violence and the real stuff, and Hancock mixes both to good effect.
As laudable as the idealism may be, the movie sometimes feels like a self-congratulatory victory lap.
The Happening wants to scare us without providing a cause -- a trick only Hitchcock has managed.
By going easy on everyone, [director Conrad] turns what could have been a searing satire into a lukewarm comedy.
Director Vadim Perelman blends two powerful performances into a seamless whole, giving equal time to the dreamy sensuality of adolescence and the crushing weight of adulthood.
Thanks to the two stars' disparate styles - the laser-like focus of Li and the whirlwind whimsy of Chan - The Forbidden Kingdom makes up for its flaws with plenty of eye-popping moments.
You probably won't find a more illuminating account of what happened within the walls of Abu Ghraib.
Despite the superb acting and wonderfully sly dialogue, Roman de Gare can't tie all its bows neatly enough to be truly satisfying.
Redbelt fails on nearly every level, from its incoherent story line to its threadbare action sequences.
Against all odds it succeeds, making for a spectacular -- and spectacularly strange -- viewing experience.
The first film's main problem dogs this one as well: A dull story. The villain is big and loud, and Banner has a good heart, but neither makes for an interesting character.
A small-scale but thoroughly engrossing drama full of strong performances and sharp dialogue.
The film stops when the jokes do, making for an anti-climactic finale. But if The Foot Fist Way is more about promise than delivery, its creators are off to an impressive start.

Howard Rodman's fine-tuned script and terrific acting across the board (Hugh Dancy is marvelous as a fashionable, well-manicured monster) makes Savage Grace a pleasure -- albeit a ghastly one -- to watch.
Writer and first-time director Bryan Bertino wastes his taut, tense premise -- two lovers, three villains, one house -- by depending on wearingly familiar tricks.
Dario Argento's ketchupy brand of horror hasn't aged well, nor have his sexual politics. Enjoyably campy at first, then offensive and ultimately just bad.
movie_title: Mother of Tears: The Third Mother (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Crude, idiotic, ridiculous -- in other words, flat-out hilarious, and Sandler's funniest film in years.
movie_title: You Don't Mess With the Zohan (2008)

movie_review_blurb: This is well-worn territory, from the cuddly slapstick to the Chinese wisdom, but the movie redeems itself with some surprisingly smart and tender moments.

All the necessary ingredients are here: ancient riddles, rumbling stone technology, a precious artifact with supernatural powers. And Harrison Ford, as Indiana Jones, still looks dashing in a leather bomber jacket or professorial tweed.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Given the incendiary subject and powerful cast, Doubt could have been explosive, but ends up merely solid.
Rourke is harrowing; Tomei is devastating.
Despite some brief vulgarity, this Carrey comedy has charm and -- surprise! -- a worthwhile message.
Burlesque manages what seemed impossible: It is filled with half-naked dancing girls, yet it's still boring.
The movie is the opposite of the cartoons: Everyone's body is in motion, but nobody is using his head.
Practice makes perfectly insane in Black Swan, a tale of one ballerina's psychosexual freakout.
There's just one ingredient missing: anyone with a clue.
What the sci-fi action flick District 9 lacks in famous faces it makes up for with sheer imagination.
The best scenes are still the ones with Downey and Gwyneth Paltrow (as Stark's charm-resistant assistant, Pepper Potts), or just Downey alone.
Even when the film feels murky, Miyazaki's painterly eye keeps things afloat
Better and smarter than you might expect.
All in all, Goats would have been groaningly familiar, even back in the 1960s.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It's sadder and scarier than its predecessors, but it also may be the most important chapter in the tale.
Gibson, of course, snaps and snarls and blows out some brains with a joylessness that is thoroughly enjoyable. It's like he never left.
It's rare to see a film so choppily edited, poorly scripted and spastically directed that you can barely understand what you're watching.

In a rare moment of insight, the teenage but immortal vampires in The Twilight Saga: Eclipse complain about being "frozen" in their lives, unable to "move forward." So is everyone involved in this deathtrap of a franchise.
It's sadder and scarier than its predecessors, but it also may be the most important chapter in the tale.
Hugely raunchy and undeniably funny, with Cusack adding just a hint of sweetness.
Likable as Percy may be, it's not lightning he's stolen.
movie_title: Percy Jackson & the Olympians: The Lightning Thief (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The movie belongs entirely to Bridges, who won the Golden Globe for best actor in a drama. His inimitable Jeff-isms have never been more endearing - the sloppy gait, the whiskey glass balanced on his chest, his general air of discombobulation.
Fans of sophisticated, adult-oriented animation may savor Acker's elaborate visuals. Younger children, however, might wonder why they sat through all the terror.
Love happens in Love Happens, along with hearts, flowers, wine, roses, sweetness, light and every other cliche the filmmakers can squeeze into a two-hour film.
Soderbergh, despite three lighthearted Ocean's films, is not a natural comedic director.
Writer-directors Phil Lord and Christopher Miller, whose television credits include CBS' How I Met Your Mother, pack each scene with jokes big and small, and the voice cast shines...
movie_title: Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Last year, a ... horror flick called Teeth, about a ... girl who had incisors where she shouldn't, covered this territory with more creativity, complexity and humor. Jennifer's Body, for all its promise, could use some of that bite.

The cast is mostly female, the first-time director is Drew Barrymore, and the screenplay comes from Shauna Cross, based on her novel. But the teenage themes are universal: breaking from your parents, discovering yourself and following your bliss.
Like the original, Tron: Legacy obsesses over technology and style but forgets important details like character and plot.
Harrelson mugs wonderfully, Eisenberg stutters charmingly, Stone emerges as more than a token hottie, and Breslin plays a hardhearted tweener who, nevertheless, misses Hannah Montana.

Jonze and Eggers have a firm grasp on the way a child's joy can quickly turn to tears, but they squeeze hard and can't let go. The film is essentially a parade of negative emotions -- sorrow, anger, jealousy, regret.
New York, I Love You weaves 10 short, trivial vignettes into one long, irritating whole.

The script, by Brian Helgeland and director Paul Weitz, frequently strays off course, though the underlying story is always compelling. And, just like Twilight, this movie doesn't end so much as beg to be continued.
movie_title: Cirque du Freak: The Vampire's Assistant (2009)

movie_review_blurb: With its clever visual jokes and sassy dialogue, Anderson's first foray into animation doesn't seem to be made entirely with children in mind. Maybe that's why it seems so perfect for them.
This episode is as repetitive as the first, with endless scenes of kissus interruptus punctuated by moody indie-rock songs.
Dependably charming and enjoyable.
Ultimately, the small-scale, often downbeat jokes in Lying never quite match the grand concept.
It also feels like one man's attempt to try another in the court of cinema, or perhaps correct the course of justice itself.
Part origin story, part spoof, part bromance -- the movie can't decide. It winks at itself constantly, but only to hide its cluelessness.
It seems impossible that this heavy-handed, self-serious movie comes from writer-director Sofia Coppola.
The remarkable Sidibe is one of several daring casting choices by director Lee Daniels.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The Joneses starts with a great pitch but ultimately fails to close the deal.
Dudes, we get it.
The first such film since 2008's The Dark Knight that has something on its mind other than lavish effects and high decibels.
It's an example of what a sequel should, or at least can, be.
A star-spangled superhero from the Norman Rockwell era, Captain America might seem ill-prepared to do battle at the modern box-office... But never underestimate the power of old-fashioned corn.
Director Dominic Sena sets a quick pace; the dull moments are brightened by the unexpectedly likable team of Cage and Perlman.
The Help brings a chick-flick sensibility to a serious subject, which is more daring than it might sound. It's also incredibly refreshing.
It's nice to see the band back together. And when Kermit busts out the banjo for "Rainbow Connection," you might even go for your lighter.
Melancholia will haunt you for days, maybe weeks.
Icky and repellent in ways it probably did not intend.
movie_title: Bucky Larson: Born to Be a Star (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A fascinating, erotically charged mystery.
Nearly a dozen random themes and characters have been Scotch-taped together into a single mess.
New Year's Eve is a perfect example of why the adjective "Hollywood" is so often used as a pejorative.
What remains is the total conviction that the ludicrous scenes are dead serious and fiercely meaningful. The result is not quite a laugh a minute, but close.
Butler is perfect as a piece of barbequed beef, Kyra Sedgwick plays a sexy talk-show host and there are small roles for John Leguizamo and Chris "Ludacris" Bridges.
If the motion-picture industry had existed in 1847, the year Charlotte Brontë's novel appeared, it might have produced an adaptation much like this one.
Just when you thought you'd seen everything, here comes Chinatown, the animated version.
Its most fiendish moment comes when one girl yanks out another's bellybutton ring. Not that -- anything but that!
Blue Valentine has a rare emotional intensity. There is no way to prepare for its final frames, inevitable as they are.
Everything is pat, from the stereotyped characters (Kevin Costner plays the noble blue-collar worker) to the obvious plot turns.
See it at your own risk -- but don't miss it.
Weir has always loved atmospheric locales and group dynamics, and here he makes the most of both
Clinging to false heroism and terrified of anything too dark, The Mechanic is a tough-guy movie for wimps.
It's really just a solid courtroom drama, but these days moviegoers should take what they can get.
Uneven is the course, as the Bard might say, but the ride is plenty of fun.
There's something about Hall Pass that feels grosser than the usual Farrelly brothers comedy.
The movie, much like your own life, is best enjoyed when you don't know exactly what happens next.
Damon and Blunt give such terrific performances you might almost forgive the movie's dopey ending.
The film looks neither fully real nor fully imagined, which could be forgiven if Mars Needs Moms had something more to offer besides its nifty technology.
Beneath it all, however, is a movie with a good heart.
Well, that's one joke. Ninety more minutes to go.
Despite the millions clearly poured into it, the film feels cheap and amateurish. See it on IMAX if you wish, but the flaws will only look bigger.

Cutler never mentions animal fur, sweatshop labor or any issues that can make fashion seem less than fabulous. The September Issue is more about surface than depth, much like its subject. And in case you're wondering: Yes, this movie makes you look fat.
The film isn't merely unfunny and stupefyingly inane but a depressing waste of money, energy and time, yours included.
Lee and producer-screenwriter James Schamus aim for comedy but come up with cliches.
Stark, raw and brutal, this isn't Hollywood's romantic version of the Mafia.
The story, acting and dialogue somehow came out weaker and creakier than before.
Its main goals are to shock, titillate, enrage and otherwise jolt your reflexes, which it does shrewdly and successfully.
movie_title: The Last House on the Left (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Though it waltzes through European capitals and gorgeous hotel suites, it never quite gets the blood pumping. And despite all the husky-voiced pillow-talk about sex and adrenaline, there's little of either.
Monsters vs. Aliens may lack a bit of heart, but it more than compensates with intelligent humor.

This means many loud racing sequences (ably directed by Justin Lin) that look like the very video games inspired by these movies: candy-colored automobiles, digital dashboards and automated female voices.
The film still offers an arrestingly dark vision.
The film feels painfully thin.
Eventually Gigantic decides to become a heartwarmer, and why not? Any ending -- including nuclear devastation or a 1940s musical number -- would have worked, too.
Efron, as a teen with the brain of a father, ably carries this featherweight movie.
You've seen it all before, including the paunch Russell Crowe sported in Body of Lies, but with one exception: One intrepid reporter here is a blogger.
As Ayers, a Juilliard-trained cellist reduced to homelessness, Foxx turns The Soloist from a mildly effective inspirational tale into an aggressive awards-season advertisement.
White-knuckle action and bruisingly bad dialogue make for an uneven but wildly entertaining fight flick.
Like Connor with his women, the film picks up ideas and then drops them. At one point, Connor reflects on Wayne: 'I never figured out why he called me Dutch.' Weirdly, neither do we.
For better or worse, the weirdest, wildest comedy of the year so far.
A satisfyingly crunchy action flick.
Powerful, mesmerizing and full of moments that linger long after the bell rings.
A brave, personal and truly original piece of filmmaking.
The script, by Grant Nieporte, seems to fundamentally misunderstand its moral themes.
Based on a true story, Valkyrie aims to be a thriller, not an issues movie, and it succeeds.
Button makes some powerful points about the precious commodities of love, happiness and time.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A subtle and quietly devastating film directed by Vicente Amorim from John Wrathall's delicately written adaptation of a play by C.P. Taylor.
Defiance comes alive in its quieter scenes and smaller details.
Hathaway and Hudson, both natural charmers, are reduced to female stereotypes in this outdated comedy.
Bikini-clad babes and sniggering humor abound in the teen sex comedy Fired Up!, but so do some other things: namely a charming cast, glimmers of intelligence and a sweetly youthful spirit.

If the use of Nazi atrocities as a MacGuffin for cheap thrills offends you, The Unborn isn't your movie. If, however, you appreciate the sight of a half-naked beauty being terrorized by potato bugs, look no further.
A richly detailed but emotionally blank account of Guevara's life.
In a few moments the British actress, playing a haunted woman named Juliette, will begin speaking French, but in these moments her face reveals more than any dialogue.
Entertaining enough for young teens, but a little more thought could have made it appealing to adults as well.
A work of wondrous animation with engaging characters, charming dialogue and more than a few intense moments.
The movie is short on narrative and long on advice, but still has a touch of sweetness.
movie_title: He's Just Not That Into You (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A rote comedy that tries to pay tribute to this much-maligned subculture, but instead resorts to lazy stereotypes and comedy conventions.
It turns out, though, that a woman can save any marriage with a little home cooking and extra sex.
It's stylish, if not exactly subtle, and daringly brutal for a Hollywood movie. It's also so uneven and overlong that it may leave non-fans wondering what all the fuss has been about.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The script, by Evan Spiliotopoulos, borders on the heavy-handed, but director Aristomenis Tsirbas creates an intensity that may raise even grown-up neck hairs.
There's wicked fun in watching the wealthy sweat the small stuff, but this documentary has empathy for parents of all incomes.
Something about Dillinger's bloody, summary death has always nagged at the public; Mann is clearly urging today's audiences to draw its own conclusions.
Treacly and barely amusing.
movie_title: Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs (Ice Age 3) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It's also a comforting story that allows us to elevate the notion of purity above success.
The Hurt Locker leaves an impression. It practically leaves a bruise.
The movie franchise based on J.K. Rowlings' novels gets its The Empire Strikes Back moment. It's a downbeat cliffhanger that suggests its central characters are exiting their age of innocence.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Berg's name no longer rings so many bells, but Aviva Kempner's documentary Yoo-Hoo, Mrs. Goldberg may change that.
A moving story, but the film's overly romantic tone rings hollow.
The film's central romance flips and flops like a dying fish.
A Perfect Getaway is smarter than it looks and more fun than it has a right to be.
Meryl Streep, as Child, is this film's butter; everything else is garnish.
It's enjoyable enough while it's speeding along. Like the Joes themselves, the movie succeeds by simply crashing headfirst through every obstacle.
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Tarantino is the most fearlessly inventive filmmaker alive -- but we knew that. And while Inglourious Basterds is never anything less than ridiculously entertaining, it's nothing Tarantino hasn't done before.
The film's typically Hollywood message is timeless: If you're a woman, your dreams and plans are meaningless without a man.
Slipped into Robert Rodriguez's smart, funny, fast-as-lightning kids' movie, Shorts, are several sly comments on American culture and the tyranny of technology.
movie_title: Shorts: The Adventures of the Wishing Rock (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Funny People veers wildly in tone and style, with jarring cameos (Ray Romano, Eminem) and a third act that mimics one of John Cassavetes' improvised experiments. Apatow may deserve to be taken seriously, but for now he's still kidding around.
That jolt of energy may resuscitate the franchise; its breathing, however, feels shallow.

The magic isn't in the plot (no disrespect to returning screenwriters Roberto Orci and Alex Kurtzman, joined by Ehren Kruger), but in the obvious delight Bay takes in boyish fantasies of battles, cars, aliens and babes.
Rudolph lends depth and complexity to this otherwise facile story.
Ultimately, the film tries so hard to strike a balance that it ends up standing stock-still.
The closest most of us will ever come to an intimate chat with the champ.
It's a handful of ostensibly quirky ideas glued together by irritatingly conventional devices.
Skynet, Schmynet -- the future is here.
What follows is less a story than a series of semi-clever ideas.
movie_title: Night at the Museum 2: Battle of the Smithsonian (2009)

movie_review_blurb: That rare and wonderful thing: a movie lover's movie.
The examined life may be the only one worth living, but as The Windmill Movie profoundly illustrates, it's no guarantee of happiness.
A whimsical story that taps into the magical relationship between the young and the old.

Not a children's movie, but a movie for people with childlike minds, Land of the Lost" combines the kind of juvenile humor that might amuse a 14-year-old with a shoddy plot that wouldn't satisfy a 5-year-old.
Surprisingly funny and smartly acted.
As a Texas waitress, Carey is convincing -- more so than the film itself.
Director Tony Scott may not suffer from attention-deficit disorder, but he is convinced you do.
Somehow, someone decided this rom-com needed less rom and more com -- a fatal mistake.
Whatever Works is a slapdash composition built around a single note.
A near-brilliant comedy disguised as a quickie horror flick, Sam Raimi's Drag Me to Hell is the year's most frightfully hilarious movie so far.
A somewhat formulaic Rust Belt noir, but Bale delivers a visceral, go-for-broke performance as a man who puts family above the law.
Fiennes and Rickman get the actorly moments they've been building toward for so long, and the film is most fun when it sticks to mechanics: roller coaster rides, battle scenes, close calls.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: What makes "Saving Mr. Banks" work is Thompson in a wonderful, nuanced performance that walks a fine line between villain and heroine.
An uneven adaptation of the Ransom Riggs book, with creepy-funny characters but an extremely muddled story.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Clever jokes and cute moments mostly make up for the contrived story.
An ethnically diverse cast and snappy action scenes make for an entertaining update of the 1960 classic.
A sympathetic but subtle portrayal of a young whistleblower who broke the law and paid a price.
No match for the 2001 original, but the endearing cast makes this third installment better than expected.
A one-note documentary on a one-note band, though fans may enjoy getting screen time with their favorite members.
A confused, charmless take on the Robinson Crusoe story.
The event itself remains a stunner, but Clint Eastwood's somewhat drab drama sheds no new light on the media-shy pilot.
A bummed-out, unfunny Lewis seems to be the main selling point for this dreary drama.
"The Light Between Oceans" hangs on the screen like a large, lovely painting in a beautiful old frame.
"Morgan" works as a reasonably effective sci-fi thriller - perhaps even more so if you've never seen a movie by Ridley Scott.
Kubo and the Two Strings is a visually dazzling film set in an ancient, magical Japan. And now, the bad news. As a narrative, Kubo and the Two Strings is nearly incomprehensible.
A real-life screwball comedy with a solid gold cast. Grant may have just sealed his first Oscar nomination.
A sense of fun is notably missing, but the movie works well - maybe too well - as an emotionally wrenching story about a child who must put childhood behind him.
A gleefully vulgar and very funny spoof of the Pixar formula.
An overly familiar mob drama, though the authentic Brooklyn settings add color.
A beautifully realized adaptation of Philip Roth's novel about minor decisions and major consequences.
Mostly, the inherent silliness of the original material reduces "The Legend of Tarzan" to mild camp.
An affectionate ode to the bond between humans and their animals.
A lopsided gem full of off-kilter humor, hard truths and real emotion. Great for preteens and up.
The female-led cast is a promising idea, but this reboot of the 1984 classic isn't as fresh or funny as it could have been.
It's a no-nonsense crime procedural that suits its hero.
Woody Allen's new period piece is no match for "Midnight in Paris," but the fine cast and bittersweet themes carry the day.
A modest but touching documentary about two underdogs who took each other to the big time.
An enjoyably old-fashioned entry in the new series. Short on back story, long on action, loads of fun.
Another infuriatingly unfunny and probably successful entry in the long-running animated franchise.
A beautiful showcase for Mortensen.
An enjoyable teen flick about the glamour and danger of the internet.
"The Hangover" for working mothers, only funnier, smarter and sweeter.
A ho-hum entry in the previously electrifying franchise.
Ayer tries to bring his trademark realism to the action sequences, but it gets lost in the realm of comic-book fantasy.
A nifty fright flick with glimmers of depth. Short and effective.
Predictable and very Disneyfied, but Mutesi's remarkable story carries the day.
Peter Berg's disaster film about a real tragedy aims only to entertain, and succeeds. Larger lessons, however, are in short supply.
Preposterous and slightly cheesy, like an "erotic thriller" from the 1990s.
A grand wartime romance with nods to Hitchcock and "Casablanca." Thoroughly satisfying.
A lively adventure driven by an independent heroine and the Broadway-ready songs of "Hamilton" creator Lin-Manuel Miranda. Gorgeous animation, too.
Beatty's first directing effort in 20 years is so self-serving and half-baked it could have been made by Hughes himself.
This sequel's main cast is still in fine form, but the rehashed jokes feel past their prime.
A heart-wrenching drama anchored by Affleck, who notches up yet another subtle, stunning performance.
An ambitious but jumbled drama in which the central figure remains elusive. Portman's performance gets lost in the chaos.
Vinny's remarkable comeback story can make for compelling viewing.
Romantic, inventive, visually dazzling - and yet, Damien Chazelle's ambitious movie promises slightly more than it delivers.
This "Star Wars" spinoff doesn't spin very far off from the franchise, but it's a serviceable stopgap between chapters.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: An excellent cast, immersed in a hot tub of self-pity and false sentiment.
Pratt and Lawrence are great company. They could make 90 years go by in the blink of an eye.
A genuine crowd-pleaser, with sparkling characters, feel-good tunes and a big-hearted spirit.

Patriots Day may strike some as unwelcome fuel on a smoldering political fire, but it doesn't seem intended as such. Its only goal is to provide the nail-biting tension and visceral thrills of an action-blockbuster, and it succeeds.
A heart-wrenching true story, with what could be one of the great child-actor performances of all time.
As with so many parties, if you manage your expectations, you might have a pretty good time.
Feeble action and bogus plotting make this one of the dullest John le Carré adaptations you'll ever see.
Ang Lee's unprecedented use of digital technology makes for a hyperreal immersion into the mind of a traumatized soldier.
A standard entry in a formulaic genre, though the actors occasionally sparkle.
An ambitious, intelligent and unsettling film from writer-director-star Parker.
Facts and opinions duke it out in this thought-provoking if slightly low-key drama based on true events.
Unless you're a loyal Hart fan, his latest concert film won't bowl you over.
Poorly conceived and woefully executed, almost on par with Affleck's notorious bomb, "Gigli."
Cruise gives his all to a cardboard cutout action figure, making this sequel an enjoyable popcorn flick.
A low-key, good-natured comedy that never quite explodes the way it should.
J.K. Rowling's "Harry Potter" spinoff is sheer magic, a grand fantasy-adventure that already feels like an old family favorite.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: What begins as an earnest attempt to reach across the aisle turns into an unofficial Clinton campaign ad.
Director Scott Derrickson and his co-writer, C. Robert Cargill, keep Doctor Strange balanced, just barely, between trippy psychedelia and plain incoherence.
A deeply personal and visually mesmerizing drama that just might be the year's best movie.
An unusual pro-peace war film from director Mel Gibson. Solidly entertaining and impressively faithful to the facts.
A gripping, often agonizing character study with a tour de force performance by Rebecca Hall.
McGregor's directorial debut is a well-crafted drama but lacks the depth of Roth's masterful book.
A familiar story about a close encounter, though well crafted and unusually moody.
Silly and implausible, but mostly watchable.
"Hidden Figures" may be a thoroughly upbeat, entertaining movie, but it's too smart to sugarcoat the truth about race relations in America - past or present.
Movie No. 3 in the action-horror franchise again tackles hot-button topics in an entertaining, if artless way.
A snack-size thriller that isn't quite enough to satisfy.
A well-intentioned drama about wartime ethics, but the film's own morality is more dubious than it realizes.

Overlong, underdeveloped and almost entirely humorless, Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice may please die-hard fans by pitting two DC icons against each other. Everyone else may want to wait for the next Marvel movie.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A crude yet cuddly comedy written by a star of "The Big Bang Theory."
A disappointing rehash of Pee-wee's 1985 film debut. Netflix subscribers may find it skim-worthy.
A winning comedy-drama built around one of cinema's most endearing leading ladies.
Miracles From Heaven occasionally wags a told-you-so finger at nonbelievers. But in a genre that tends to hector and bludgeon, that's some kind of improvement.

"10 Cloverfield Lane" is as economical as a stage play but packs in plenty of visceral violence and visual surprises. Whether you've seen the first film or not, this one is a thoroughly entertaining treat.
A coolheaded survey of a fraught topic. The highly intelligent commentators make for fascinating listening.
A scattered comedy-drama with few laughs and even fewer insights.
Entertaining and thought-provoking.
A new trip down an ancient river, with shades of "Apocalypse Now" and "Aguirre: Wrath of God." Mesmerizing and occasionally mind-altering.
movie_title: Embrace Of The Serpent (El Abrazo De La Serpiente) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Fluffy as new-fallen snow, but Egerton is terrific as the unlikely Olympian and Jackman makes a fictitious character seem almost real.
A miserable, misguided police drama that almost seems to hate the police.
If it didn't make you constantly wonder whether some actors are standing closer to the camera than others, "Gods of Egypt" might pass muster as an occasionally lively and frequently campy B movie.
An unsettling journey back to a time when Satan seemed much closer to our world.
Stiller and company uphold the Zoolander brand with honor.
The latest Nicholas Sparks adaptation may turn off even his most ardent fans.
Fact and fiction mix with uneven but entertaining results in the latest from the "Silver Linings Playbook" crew.
Ron Howard's grand maritime adventure has spectacular effects, literary polish and just the right touch of modern-day relevance.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Is The Force Awakens equal to the original trilogy? Fans will have to face facts: Such unique magic can never be recreated... The new Star Wars films must create a universe of their own -- and they're off to a promising start.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A low-wattage sequel to a comedy that wasn't exactly glowing in the first place.

Bay's action sequences are as riveting and technically beautiful as ever, but his reductive worldview is also on display. "13 Hours" doesn't just lionize its American soldiers, it oozes disdain for everyone else.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Crude in nearly every sense of the word, "Dirty Grandpa" is a nasty-humored, poorly made and desperately unfunny film.
Old jokes and little plot, but the charming original cast almost compensates.
The death and destruction in "The 5th Wave" can be highly entertaining, but once that's over, the movie must follow its predetermined formula.
Another successful entry in this dependably smart and well-crafted franchise for kids.
Charlie Kaufman's animated feature is one of his best films yet, a haunting fable about the illusion of love.
A harrowing immersion into the lives of a lesser-known caste of prisoners in the camps. The film's ultimate message, however, is a puzzle.
A remarkable tale, confusingly told. Impressive storm sequences and a very good Pine almost save the day.
"Hail, Caesar!" obeys the first commandment of filmmaking, attributed to the old master Billy Wilder: Thou shalt not bore.
An unexpected and off-kilter treat, thanks to a BBC-quality cast and (un)deadpan humor.

A Western with potential for feminist table-turning and old-fashioned violence, "Jane Got a Gun" is a major letdown. Despite being co-produced by Portman, the movie sells her character short at nearly every turn.
More intriguing than satisfying. There's solid acting and tingly tension, but the story doesn't quite add up.
Fine work from Hawke as a self-destructive jazz icon in this uneven but compelling drama.
A hit-and-miss comedy, but McCarthy leads a game cast through several memorable moments.
Absolutely fascinating, with nearly unlimited and almost unbearably close access. This is the political documentary you never thought you'd actually see.
"Alice Through the Looking Glass" feels as cluttered as an old curiosity shop, one filled with Burton's discarded odds and ends.
Don't believe the negative hype. Though sluggish and overlong, the ninth film in the franchise has some entertaining moments.
Highly original and mordantly funny. Perfect for fans of Franz Kafka, Charlie Kaufman and other bleak surrealists.
As a romantic weepie, not bad. As a drama about a disabled man, possibly offensive.
It's about as briefly entertaining and disposable as the music it spoofs.

Crowe and Gosling are fine, but they never form a genuine rapport. These actors are known for intensity and screen-hogging, not warmth or comedic timing, and here they seem to be moving in parallel but not fully in sync.
A loud, unattractive and most likely successful sequel to the 2014 hit.
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Another year, another mix of "The Amityville Horror" and "The Exorcist." Solid acting and an emotional back story set this one slightly apart.
Twice as preposterous and half as fun as the original.
"Finding Dory" upholds the Pixar tradition with plenty of inventive humor, cleverly drawn characters and emotionally resonant moments.
Hart and Johnson make a terrific team, though it's the latter who really shines in this action-comedy.
Stylish and creepy, but also simplistic and hollow. As an indictment of the beauty industry, it's only skin-deep.
Strong work from McConaughey as a charismatic leader, but the film's meandering historical scope will test your patience.
Something between Shakespeare, Woody Allen and Noah Baumbach, a cautionary tale filled with Manhattanite wit and small moments that have the ring of truth.
The bitter humor of director Todd Solondz has never been for all tastes, and this may be his bitterest yet. Painfully, lethally funny.
"Neighbors 2" arrives with a feminist mandate and an eagerness to give women equal opportunity in the raunch department. None of the film's five writers is a woman, however, and it shows.
A compelling drama that might have worked even better without the action-thriller shadings. The unknown actors are pitch-perfect.
Gyllenhaal broods convincingly, but little else rings true in this contrived drama.
A gonzo Russian action-flick shot entirely in first-person perspective. About as coherent as it sounds, but highly inventive and bloody great fun.
Stunning animation and big-screen thrills, but be warned that this is a much scarier movie than the animated 1967 version.
The franchise hasn't improved quality-wise, but the racially charged humor still crackles.
So-so pulp, elevated by Costner as a feral felon.
Another love letter to the magic hour of adolescence from director Richard Linklater.
The movie's story, by John Cohen, is pretty thin gruel, but Jon Vitti's smart-aleck script can be quite funny, and the brightly colored animation is appealing.
An earnest but aimless-feeling adaptation of Dave Eggers' novel.
Bloody violence and a shouty soundtrack make this a grisly DIY treat.
The third "Captain America" film entertains relentlessly, which is to say loudly and busily, but with enough humor and intelligence to make it seem less pandering than it actually is.
A small-scale but brave and frequently funny documentary from North Woodmere-raised filmmaker Gayle Kirschenbaum.
"The Man Who Knew Infinity" shines a welcome light on a lesser-known figure in mathematics, but it isn't as illuminating as it could have been.
Sarandon sparkles in this lightweight comedy-drama.
A potentially topical thriller marred by pandering dialogue and clumsy plotting. Spend your money elsewhere.
Overall, "The Huntsman: Winter's War" feels like a movie that didn't need making, but at least it justifies it existence.
The movie looks quite nice, thanks to Affleck, and that's about the most you can say for its hero, too.
"Silence" can be a riveting and forceful film. Still, it feels more about abstractions than emotions.
"Why Him?" rarely delivers more than a half-chuckle. Right now, everyone involved might be thinking, "Why me?"

Justice League thinks of itself as a massive event, a culture-rocking fusion of star-power and intellectual property. Instead, it's another bloated blockbuster with generic effects, stock action scenes and strained dialogue.
If the mix of tones never quite jells ... the movie is mostly entertaining, with a couple of sparkling moments from the ensemble cast.
"A Bad Moms Christmas" is pretty typical of Hollywood seasonal fare: a fine cast and a few passable moments, but the material is more miss than hit.
A quiet, intimate drama that's less concerned with violent outbursts and emotional catharsis than with private thoughts and humbling moments.
A misguided mix of nasty comedy and civil rights drama.
Turns down the Shakespearean pretensions, cranks up the humor and delivers what is essentially an action-comedy with swords and capes.
Dreary as a Nordic winter, and almost as long.
A sugary version of what should have been a bittersweet story.
The movie overall can feel more than a little formulaic, but as a tribute to real-life heroes, Only the Brave serves its purpose.
A stranger-than-fiction story told with respect, sympathy and a touch of humor.
A rare dramatic role from Chan, but that's not enough to recommend this dull action-thriller.
None of it would work ... without Winslet and Elba, whose smarts and sex-appeal shine through - even with a teensy bit of fake dirt pressed onto their cheeks.
A visually dazzling follow-up to one of science fiction's most iconic films.
... the low-aiming remake feels like just another generic horror flick.
"Victoria and Abdul" is hampered by the restrictions of a Hollywood period piece: It's glossy and sentimental, with a feel-good message about racial prejudice.
A disappointingly subdued reunion for Fonda and Redford.
Cruise doesn't seem fully suited to the role of lovable reprobate, but he knows how to capture an adrenaline rush and his charisma is, as ever, undimmed.
Throw in a couple of ugly new characters and one semi-nauseating barf joke, and "The Nut Job 2" marks the emergence of a consistently tone-deaf animated franchise.
movie_title: The Nut Job 2: Nutty by Nature (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A remarkable and moving story, anchored by an Oscar-worthy Harrelson.
"Logan Lucky" is his down-home version of the "Ocean's" franchise, with NASCAR instead of the Bellagio, but it's every bit as cheeky, fun and funny.

It understandably wants to deliver the message that you can achieve anything if you just put your heart into it. That might hold true for boxing, karate and even Olympic bobsledding - but ballet? What's French for "get real"?
A rough-edged charmer that puts its own stamp on the underdog story.
All told, this movie about love during a bubble is a bust.
One of the best movies about adolescence to come along in years.

What makes this "It" work so well is the way it pulls us back into our own childhoods with a cast of young characters and the shared experiences - some horrifying, some hilarious - that bind them together.
The director of "Black Swan" and "Noah" combines both to come up with this tough-to-categorize movie.
A view of systemic racism through a highly personal and artistic lens.
A sincere attempt to paint a portrait of a country gone mad.
Fans of the 2014 hit might be disappointed by this sluggish and slightly distasteful sequel.
A winning combination of sports movie and civil rights story, with ace performances from Stone and Carell.
"Ninjago" is such a carbon copy that it barely counts as its own movie.
A glib and shallow take on female midlife crisis.
All told, The Star should be a safe bet for families during the upcoming holiday season.
Despite Washington's best efforts, Roman J. Israel, Esq. feels like it was named after the wrong character.
Coco makes sure to cross every item off its Mexican checklist -- tamales, sombreros, a shot of what looks like tequila -- but that's not the same as immersing us in a culture.
In the end, "The Commuter" feels both overstuffed and empty.
All in all, "Paddington 2" has a warmth and wit that's missing from many a children's movie. Don't let your January go by without it.
Just about anyone with a level head would see "Forever My Girl" as the story of a narcissist manipulating a naive doormat.
A fairly straightforward and enjoyable movie about an extremely complicated and demoralizing war. Its goal is to focus on a small group of heroes, and it shows little interest in the bigger picture.
"Den of Thieves" may not be as moody as "To Live and Die in L.A." or as clever as "The Usual Suspects," but it works well on its own terms. As for Butler, it's like discovering him all over again.
In the end, "The Death Cure" makes for thrilling, if not deep-reaching, entertainment.

The Last Five Years will be a must for even casual Bowie fans, who are most likely still reeling from their idol's absence. It captures the ever-changing artist in his most surprising incarnation yet: a mortal man.
movie_title: David Bowie: The Last Five Years (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Worth seeing for Bening's brave and touching performance as an actress past her prime.
movie_title: Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Another gentle charmer from the "Wallace and Grommit" folks.
"Red Sparrow" isn't trashy fun like "Atomic Blonde" and it certainly doesn't have the brains of a "Tinker, Tailor, Solider, Spy."
"Every Day" is, after all, trying to say something serious about love. And in its modest, teen-modulated way, it says it.
The real letdown is that this ostensibly hip-and-with-it movie feels so square, especially when it comes to its trio of wise-women.
A slight improvement over the 2008 original, which is not saying much.
Romance may not be what fans of this fantasy franchise want, but it's a blessing for the rest of us. In a movie driven mostly by kabillion-dollar special effects, it's nice to feel a human emotion.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The Winchester Mystery House deserves a little better than "Winchester."
A stock story, but the high scare-count should make this a hit with horror fans.
The execution can be a bit clumsy, especially the attempts at comic relief by Elise's assistants, the swaggering Tucker (Angus Sampson) and nerdy Specks (Whannell himself).
Chastain, who's in nearly every frame of the film, delivers an impressively intense, hammered-down performance.
Unearthed fan footage and gorgeously restored concert clips make this a must-see for Beatles fans.
movie_title: The Beatles: Eight Days a Week - The Touring Years (2016)

movie_review_blurb: "Wonder Wheel" isn't one of Allen's worst, but it's definitely a third-tier effort.
In the end, "The Disaster Artist" decides that the only bad movies are the ones that fail to bring us joy. "The Room" certainly can't be accused of that.
A role-reversal monster movie with gorgeous visuals from Guillermo del Toro and a knockout performance from Hawkins.
The main attraction here is Gary Oldman as Churchill. As an act of physical transformation and emotional expression, it's something close to supernatural.
A renegade biopic with punk-rock energy and an in-your-face performance from Robbie.
With the pulsing rhythm of an action thriller and the dank core of a classic film noir, All the Money in the World is terrific entertainment that packs a philosophical punch.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A fresh visual style makes this middle "Star Wars" a welcome addition to the saga.
You may ask: Though good for an initial laugh, how long can this wrong-body comedy shtick pay off? The answer: pretty much the entire movie.
Jackman is a perfect fit to play the man who invented our notion of spectacle, but this is one unspectacular musical.
Alexander Payne's sci-fi comedy-drama is half-brilliant and half-meandering, but never boring.
Despite the on-screen intelligence of Kendrick, plus a screenplay co-written by Mike White, this is a near-plotless, slapdash comedy marked by low-energy improvisation and strained slapstick.
Steven Spielberg's drama about journalism under fire is so timely it's practically a headline itself. Fine work from Streep and Hanks throughout.
Day-Lewis' declared final performance is perfect, the film less so. Sumptuously made, though, with a score to die for.
A complicated movie, erotic yet never graphic, heartfelt yet highly stylized. Chalamet delivers one of the year's best performances.

Despite two fine actors in key roles, and the efforts of a four-man screenwriting team to strip King's story down to its basics, "The Dark Tower" still makes virtually no sense, even by the rules of its own world(s).
That feeling of familiarity tends to overshadow the more interesting and persuasive portions of this film.
movie_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power (2017)

movie_review_blurb: An absolute blast, with a never-sexier Theron in some of the best action scenes to hit a screen.
A haunting re-creation of a first-of-its-kind tragedy. Fifty years later, it seems, we're no closer to answers or solutions.
This action-fantasy creature-feature speaks a cinematic Esperanto - inelegant, unidentifiable, with bits and pieces borrowed from here and there.
All told, this is a sharp, funny, brave movie that strikes the perfect balance between humor and horror. It's the year's first must-see.
A sweet-natured but awfully clumsy animated tale. Best for very young viewers.
Logan provides a fitting finale to the Wolverine franchise. It isn't often a Marvel superhero gets to saddle up, tip his hat and ride off into the proverbial sunset.
Director Ry Russo-Young seems genuinely interested in tapping into these characters and reminding us what fresh hell adolescence brings each day, but the material resists her.
Breathtakingly, pulse-poundingly bad.
An unusual combination of thunderous monster movie and gritty war film, "Kong: Skull Island" is a fresh take on a nearly 85-year-old classic.
In the end, Beauty and the Beast still enchants, largely due to the irresistible story and Woolverton's still-intact touches. The hand-drawn original film, though, remains the real deal.
Any movie that includes death by tape dispenser is worth seeing.
Another intriguing experiment from one of the oddest and most interesting partnerships in the movies today.
The follow-up is as wistful as the first film was wild, which is another way of saying "T2" feels like a ghost of its former self.
[A] calculated, derivative attempt to turn a decades-old piece of junk culture into a new pile of box-office cash.
Yep, it's another "Alien" clone. A few good gruesome moments, but that's about all.
Aims for the grandeur of "Lawrence of Arabia" but falls just shy of made-for-television special.
An engrossing if somewhat glossy drama based on a real-life heroine.
Funny, tender, outrageous - this unpredictable movie belongs in a category all its own.
Though this spinoff has less heart than "The Lego Movie," the nonstop pace and dazzling animation (once again by Animal Logic) should make it a crowd-pleaser.
In the game-to-film genre - which includes such memorable disasters as "Silent Hill" and "Hitman 47" - this is yet another disorganized, incoherent, nearly unwatchable entry.

Though well-made on every level, with gorgeous visuals and raw, heightened performances, "A Monster Calls" is more emotionally intense than the average children's movie - by a factor of maybe two or three hundred.
Possibly the nail in the coffin of this dreary vampire series.
Wants to be "Transformers" but feels more like made-for-video kiddie fare. Tough going if you're older than 9.
For most of its nearly two-hour running time, "Split" is quite enjoyable, a clever one-up of "Psycho" with some interesting twists and several funny-creepy moments.
Pedro Almodóvar's latest isn't his strongest, but his vibrant, vivid world of women is always a great place to be.
The first film had its moments, but this action-packed follow-up is a major improvement. Wild, funny and thrilling.
Keaton is the special sauce in this smart, sharp movie about capitalism and its casualties.
It's basically "Look Who's Talking" with a puppy instead of a baby.
Jim Jarmusch's latest has moments of beauty that help compensate for a slightly static narrative.
"Gold" mostly works. It's just a few ounces shy of solid entertainment.
The movie often delivers on its promises. It is also, however, one clumsily plotted flick, with a screenplay by Allan Loeb that gambles everything on a twist ending you could spot from a galaxy away.
Fitfully funny but also meandering and muddled.
Like many of Farhadi's films, "The Salesman" says something profound about politics without directly addressing the issue at all.
It's a quietly effective documentary that works on two levels.

With energetic pacing and zippy dialogue, "The Big Short" (written by McKay and Charles Randolph) is often entertaining - a screwball comedy with an angry streak. If only the film could sustain that tone.
The voice of Baldwin as an infantile CEO is the selling point here, but a few good lines aren't enough to recommend this chopped-and-strained comedy.
It never digs very deep into its characters or its themes. Still, it's always encouraging to see a children's movie that actually tries to say something to its viewers.
Faithful to the whoopee-cushion spirit of Dav Pilkey's books, with some sly humor for grown-ups.
movie_title: Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie (Captain Underpants) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A somewhat low-key war drama, but it's hard to resist its sweet spirit and fuzzy warmth.
An effectively creepy and at times gut-wrenching take on the pandemic genre.
A blaring, bloated zombie of a movie.
An elegant, sumptuous and subtle adaptation of the Daphne du Maurier novel.
A badly botched biopic that won't earn Shakur any new fans and will disappoint the ones he has.

[Wonder Woman] isn't just a triumph for women, it's a triumph, period. This is grand entertainment with rousing action, sparkling humor, a romantic streak and a titanium-strength debut from Gal Gadot in the title role.
