The movie redlines its engines throughout, but none of it works -- and at 149 minutes, it feels nearly a full hour too long.

The band Spacemen 3 once titled an album "Taking Drugs to Make Music to Take Drugs To"... Edgar Wright, a major record-head, might appreciate this comparison: He makes movies out of ideas that are too crazy to make movies out of.
Not the freshest formula, you say? Perhaps, but it's hard to argue with success.
Director Jon Watts nicely handles the scenes of adolescent banter and awkwardness; if anything, they're more engaging than the action sequences.
It's all meant to be wild and crazy, but somehow it seems simultaneously nasty and dull.
In its pulpy way, War for the Planet of the Apes -- vigorously directed by Matt Reeves from Mark Bomback's screenplay -- captures the zeitgeist.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: In this somewhat disappointing summer at the movies, Wish Upon offers a welcome glimmer of magic.
Moody and compelling, with fine performances all around.
Johansson's star power all but vanishes in this jumble of science-fiction cliches.
A cartoonish Depp and a muddled plot send this fifth "Pirates" film to the bottom.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Two fine performances anchor this half-funny, half-brutal story of a midlife marriage in crisis.
A lifeless, brainless costume drama from, of all people, Werner Herzog.
Another spectacular entry in a dependably entertaining franchise.
It's a brilliant concept, executed by writer-director Vigalondo with a perfect balance of pop-culture irony and sincere storytelling.
Charming period detail but underwhelming characters make this a backdrop without a story.
Heavy on the cute-and-cuddly, but beautifully filmed throughout.
Jocular gun violence and "colorful" characters make for an amusing but glib action-comedy.
A raunchy but good-natured adaptation of the preposterous 1990s television show.
Any action film that sets its opening sequence to ELO's "Mister Blue Sky" can't be all bad, but the "Guardians" franchise will need more than an excellent vinyl collection from here on out.
It's fairly funny, but something about it feels disappointing.
A poignant look at an actor whose best work seemed yet to come.
An unsuccessful mix of saucy wit and portentous sorcery.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A well-intentioned but superficial story about a deep-rooted Hispanic subculture.
Gory, Gothic and more than a little goofy.
The all-new cast is fine, but this "Wimpy" entry feels skimpy on jokes and charm.
movie_title: Diary Of A Wimpy Kid: The Long Haul (2017)

movie_review_blurb: An unlikely superhero origin story, executed with the style, themes and budget of independent cinema.
Spike Lee's incendiary farce is too uneven to recommend, but its uncanny timing and sense of outrage are worth noting.
It's hard to overstate how good Spielberg's movie is (this is the 135-minute Director's Cut) and how contemporary it feels even today.
movie_title: Close Encounters Of The Third Kind: 40th Anniversary Release (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Slow, clunky and not terribly informative.
If you're not in tears by this movie's end, it probably wasn't intended for you anyway.
Director Michael Dowse ("Take Me Home Tonight") can't quite decide on a tone -- sly, whimsical or wacky? -- but the problem is the material.
A low-key, odd-couple comedy built mostly around Nelson's coarse ad-libs and Eenhoorn's sighing reactions.
A slightly breezier and dependably brainless installment of Stallone's action franchise.
"All In" is a lesser effort in this franchise, but not without its charms.
"Sharknado" without the jokes.
Overall, it's tough to grumble about such a sturdy and crowd-pleasing soufflé.
Rougher and slightly funnier than the 1990 original, but still harmless junk at best.
"Get on Up" turns Brown's life into an even bigger mess.
Though based on a comics series launched in 1969, "Guardians" comes on with a hip, absurdist humor that feels thoroughly modern.
"Hercules" heaves and grunts along, interrupted by battle scenes that are visually impressive (when's the last time you saw someone pick up a horse and throw it?) but emotionally uninvolving.
Richard Linklater's latest feels more like living a life than watching a movie. It's a one-of-a-kind experience.
The cat-and-mouse games, while entertaining, feel familiar. What elevates the movie is Hoffman's performance as a man pouring his soul into the only work he knows.
At first, it's dazzling. Besson forgets, however, that he's promised us pulp entertainment and instead delivers a serious treatise on next-step metaphysics.
It's better-made than the first -- DeMonaco's writing and directing are much stronger -- and it also has the courage of its convictions.
The movie never feels like a nostalgia trip. It moves, breathes and sings with life.
Given its subject matter and R rating, "Sex Tape" isn't as wild or woolly as it could be.
Gruesome? A little. Scary? You bet. But that's exactly what makes the "Dragon" films so different, and so much better, than the average children's fare.
The movie is crammed with jokes about how bad sequels are. And guess what? Exactly.
Many "who knew?" moments to keep pop-culture fans fascinated.
movie_title: Supermensch: The Legend of Shep Gordon (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Clint Eastwood's version of the buoyant Broadway musical doesn't hit the same high notes, but it's a must-see for fans of Valli and the early pop era.
It's everything the first movie wasn't: noisy, clumsy and derivative.
Like a nuclear arsenal launched by an insane despot, Michael Bay's "Transformers: Age of Extinction" aims for a million different targets and incinerates them beyond recognition.
Overall, "When the Game Stands Tall" feels like a post-loss locker-room speech: meaningful, but less than inspirational.
"Begin Again" is an ode to the indie-rock spirit, but its music -- written by Carney and others -- is as safe, smooth and Starbucks-friendly as Norah Jones.
Without a strong story or well-defined character to guide her, McCarthy resorts to old tricks and repeated routines.
A surprisingly strong cast and solid direction make all the malarkey in this horror flick tolerable.
You could bother debating D'Souza on history and semantics and rudimentary logic, but chances are you'd end up feeling like Meathead arguing with Archie Bunker.
movie_title: America: Imagine the World Without Her (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The tone is dire, the visuals dark and doomy, the pace epically slow. Like so many sequels, it's everything the first film aspired not to be.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: This movie is never maudlin or sentimental. It shows us a man who, whatever his flaws, seemed to live his life in exactly the right way.
"Third Person" is such a solipsistic, navel-gazing creation that it seems to have barely made it out of Haggis' mind and onto the screen.
The movie tracks "E.T." so closely ... that you can almost hear the legal ice cracking beneath the children's bicycle tires.

The movie's trademark mix of live action and drawing techniques (white silhouettes, reddened lips, an abundance of venetian blinds) looks fantastic. If it's depth you want, you've knocked on the wrong door.
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: "Frank" has a wry sense of humor, the ring of authenticity and glimmers of genuine wisdom.
"Dolphin Tale 2" is both uneventful and predictable, but it deserves credit for treating its nonhuman characters with respect.
Full of strange references, self-reflexive jokes and a cast of actors playing actors, it's a maze of mirrors that shifts under your feet like a theme park ride.
As the narratives build toward their predictable conclusions, "Men, Women & Children" seems wholly unaware that these various evils existed long before Facebook and Instagram.
Imagine a combination of "Unforgiven" and "Men in Black," and you're getting close.
Another inspirational film that rarely strays from the playbook, but first-time director Baker gives it some life.
"Listen Up Philip" works as satire, but it's also as big and messy as one of its novelists' novels.
Well-orchestrated and superbly acted. Though we know the outcome, the fate of Paris seems anything but guaranteed.
For all the extra blood and brutality, this is still a macho and romanticized war movie. Pitt serves honorably in the John Wayne role.
One of the freshest, funniest, boldest debut films to come along in years.
A first-hand, up-close account of Snowden that allows us to meet and judge the man for ourselves.
A nifty premise, but other films have done this with more verve and imagination. The fine cast almost makes up for the ponderous tone.
"Interstellar" deserves credit for aiming for the stars, but the hard realities of filmmaking and storytelling pull it right back to Earth.
Primarily two actors and a jazz score, but the result is a crackling good drama that feels almost like a thriller. Smart, stylish and intense.
A familiar story, albeit from a fresh female perspective and enlivened by a fine cast.
Disney plus Marvel plus Pixar's John Lasseter equals an enjoyable jumble of kid-approved action.
"Nightcrawler" is the kind of movie that rarely hits multiplexes anymore, an edgy, pulpy thriller with a social conscience and a vicious satirical streak.
The actors are decidedly mismatched -- not to each other, but to the material.
[A] gripping documentary set against the internecine battle between Israel and Palestine.
Stretches the book thinner than pizza dough and feels about as nutritious. Still, its intentions are good and so is its cast ...
movie_title: Alexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day (2014)

movie_review_blurb: An offbeat drama with a pervasive sense of unease. Compelling, if slightly inconclusive.
Fine performances, including Gandolfini's last, help compensate for a patchwork plot by first-time screenwriter Dennis Lehane.
The final plot twist is about as fiendishly clever as an episode of General Hospital. Is that a spoiler? You're welcome.
"This Is Where I Leave You" is the year's first real crowd pleaser, a comedy-drama that presses all the right buttons but does so with intelligence and skill.
movie_title: This Is Where I Leave You (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Though it sometimes feels calculated and mechanical, it's also solid, well crafted and entertaining.
"A Walk Among the Tombstones" feels like one of its villains: spiteful, sadistic and amoral.
While it's good to know that character-driven dramas still have a place at the movies, "The Judge" might have worked better as a television miniseries.
Kevin Smith, of "Clerks," delivers a weird in-joke inspired by one of his podcasts. You probably had to be there.
Imaginative but very weird, more Monty Python than Walt Disney. Not for all tastes.
Fuqua's movie is just as dopey and creaky as the series.
Curran's dreamy, semisurreal visuals, along with Mandy Walker's shimmering cinematography and Garth Stevenson's fluid score, help us see the world through Davidson's eyes.
Gillian Flynn's playful novel is now David Fincher's chilling movie. Still packed with twists and turns, but the overall effect is unsettling.
A hip-looking mess of a movie, made tolerable by Benjamin's spacey-cool Hendrix. Great costumes, few insights.
movie_title: Jimi: All Is by My Side (2014)

movie_review_blurb: "Kill the Messenger" achieves the jittery tension of "The Insider," if not quite the righteous fervor of "All the President's Men."
A delicate and ephemeral romance.
movie_title: The Disappearance of Eleanor Rigby: Them (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Die-hard fans may be pleased.
Wears its cynicism the way many young people do: awkwardly and not very convincingly.
It's another example of MacFarlane's ability to mix poop jokes with romance, foul language with sweet sentiment, offensive humor with boyish charm.
movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The tender friendship between the wide-eyed Zero and the worldly Gustave gives this movie an emotional core that isn't always an Anderson priority.
Keaton, riffing faster than a souped-up Agera ("Christmas came early, wing nuts!"), is clearly having a great time. That makes one of us.
The movie has trouble stitching together disjointed episodes into a coherent narrative. Thanks to a strong voice cast, however, the characters retain their charm throughout.
A plotless montage of anonymous bodies.
Gorgeous, wondrous and troubling.
"Non-Stop" may be a tad derivative -- you could call it "Sky Hard" -- and its ending crash-lands in more ways than one. When all its engines are firing, however, it's a heck of a ride.
The movie feels duty-bound to stay absolutely faithful to its sacred source material. It's the classic dilemma of the proselytizer: How far into the secular world can you go to deliver your message?
What's missing are the jolts of realism and flashes of insight that made the original so stealthily effective.
There are remakes, readaptations and reboots, and then there is "Endless Love," a movie that bears almost no resemblance to its source material whatsoever.
It's all rather surprisingly well acted (Kinnaman and Oldman are better than they even need to be), but "RoboCop" is missing a crucial ingredient: fun.
It's "Twilight" as directed by Mark Waters, of "Mean Girls." It's an idea that might have been intriguing 15 years ago, before those movies existed.
At times, this fact-based film feels like a breezy heist flick, while at others it's a somber tribute to the sacrifices of war. The two tones don't harmonize, and they never ring true.
It's the smartest, funniest and most dazzlingly inventive children's movie to come along in years.
A movie that checks absolutely every box and still utterly fails the test.
The romance develops so suddenly (note the three-day weekend of the title) that we never quite believe it, and several murky flashbacks suggest a twist that never satisfactorily arrives.
What the film doesn't have is a sense of humor.

Why did this bright, vivacious, intellectually engaged girl willingly lock herself up in a wealthy man's seraglio? Put bluntly, what did she get out of it? In the end, "The Invisible Woman" remains a mystery.
This sequel may not produce any quotable lines, but to borrow one from the original: Don't act like not you're not impressed.
"Her" goes light-years beyond science-fiction cliches. As the story progresses further into unexpected territory, "Her" sometimes feels like an out-of-body experience.
Grudge Match has wasted its two talented stars so badly that it almost counts as elder abuse.
"47 Ronin" would have been more fun if it kept swinging its sword instead of falling on it.
Director-star Stiller plays Mitty as a zoned-out sad sack surrounded by whimsy. The result is a confused dramedy that isn't funny or compelling enough to make us care.
movie_title: The Secret Life Of Walter Mitty (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Martin Scorsese's epic tale of debauchery feels overlong and sometimes misses its mark, but it's the director's raunchiest, funniest film yet.
"Veronica Mars" isn't really a movie but another episode -- and not even a grand finale -- with all the familiar characters and in-jokes that viewers expect.
"Lone Survivor" offers glorification with little characterization.
The Latino cast gives the movie a fresh, modern feel, but the underlying formula is becoming unacceptably stale.
This painfully feeble version of the strongman story fails on every level, from Lutz's wooden acting to the styrofoam special effects.
The overall mood resembles a furry, nut-based version of Stanley Kubrick's "The Killing."
Pine brings a welcome boyishness and idealism to Ryan, but he's clobbered with clichés by his director and screenwriters. The evildoers, it turns out, were right in his own backyard.
Hart's springy energy and Ice Cube's deadpan snarl can be amusing, but they can't compensate for weak material.
A disjointed and unconvincing movie that is also embarrassingly derivative of "Paranormal Activity."
A two-hour onslaught of extreme profanity, vicious insults and verbal violence ...
Somewhat silly and teen to the extreme, but Woodley and James are surprisingly strong. It's up to them to keep this hopeful franchise alive.
Highly explicit, but more intellectual than erotic. Music, math and sex make an intriguing jumble of ideas, though coherence may not appear until "Volume II."
Delicate animation and a charming score may be why this Belgian film earned an Oscar nomination. Its story, however, makes no sense whatsoever.
Shot in just eight nights using a car mounted with three cameras, "Locke" is a terrific example of resourceful, inventive filmmaking.
Moneyball is a winner, one of the freshest and smartest sports movies in years.
"Legends of Oz" feels like the opposite of the original film. Underneath its aggressive distractions and dim ideas, it has no heart.
It's rare that a movie fails on absolutely every level, but "Moms' Night Out" is a remarkably vivid example.
Though not as comedically energetic or culturally incisive as it could be, the movie squeaks by thanks to the camaraderie of an unlikely duo: Seth Rogen and Zac Efron.
Like your beloved but slightly bigoted grandfather, "Million Dollar Arm" is so touchingly unaware of its problems that scolding it seems pointless.
Noisy action and a jumbled plot make this Spidey flick a tangled web, but Stone and DeHaan are appealing.
The iconic movie monster feels diminished in this multimillion-dollar disappointment.
Though the neighborhood of God's Pocket is fictional, and never precisely located, Slattery's rendering of it is vivid and authentic.
It's a high-spirited lark that works thanks to Russell's dazzling direction, delicious period details and a parade of stellar performances.
Its portrait of early 20th-century New York, a melting pot on a relentless simmer, feels wrenchingly real.
The familiar Sandler-Barrymore chemistry lends a bit of sparkle to this otherwise predictable family rom-com.
"Palo Alto" feels earnest and promising, but half-formed.
For all its sociopolitical smarts and coded subtexts, the "X-Men" franchise, based on the Marvel comics, is primarily about entertainment, and this seventh installment is no different.
The movie's problems aren't small: It moves slowly, meanders everywhere and never quite arrives at a destination.
It's fun for a while, but "Edge of Tomorrow" is what the GIs used to call a blivet -- 10 pounds of movie in a five-pound bag.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: High on stuntwork and low on logic ...
"Volume II" is no more fulfilling than "Volume I."
In his directorial debut, Bateman casts himself as a foul-mouthed, racist jerk. It's a stretch for the nice-guy actor, but the role doesn't suit him.

It's a maddening mix of realistic characters, fine performances, ponderous pacing and oppressive mood lighting, none of which serve to cover up one central, glaring problem: a romance that never feels real.
Wades only ankle-deep into some complicated territory.
Despite some flaws and frustrations, this is one movie whose ending you will not see coming.
That heady blend won't please everybody, but Noah is a daringly inventive, thoroughly entertaining and ultimately very serious movie.
"The First Avenger" was a work of art, while "The Winter Soldier" is serviceable entertainment.
In this battle-of-the-sexes comedy, neither sex feels very real, which may be why there's so little to laugh about.
[It] lacks a solid plot or even much structure -- yet it works beautifully.
Ultimately, the film rides on Frost, who carries it with charm, grace and plenty of heart.
"Draft Day" might be a trick play, but it manages to score.
"Under the Skin" clearly does not intend to telegraph its meaning, but meaning may not be the movie's strong suit.
A supposedly true story that uses faulty logic to reduce the complexity of faith to a fairy-tale. By rights, it should displease atheists and believers alike.
Drags science fiction back to the Cold War era, if not the Stone Age.
Turturro has many dots that he never connects here.
The movie has one goal: to amuse the most children with the least amount of effort.
A slipshod comedy with Williams in default mode as a lovable grouch. A waste of a once-brilliant star.
Where is all this going, you ask? Good question.

In this chapter, Katniss Everdeen, the working-class rebel played by Jennifer Lawrence, mostly holsters her weapons and plays dress-up, just as the movie itself gives up any higher aspirations of offering social commentary or insight.
"A Little Chaos" wants us to be fascinated by a feminist who never was, then undermines her by casting an approving eye on the steamy affair she begins with her boss.
A loud, frenetic kid pleaser, though parents' brains may short-circuit.
A loving but honest portrayal of a doomed talent.
Rudd's charm and an overall sense of silliness make for breezy summer fun. It's also Marvel's most kid-friendly movie yet.
Its obvious weakness, an overall sense of familiarity, is easy to overlook thanks to one of the better casts Allen has assembled in recent years.
Despite Schumer's subversive instincts, the romantic comedy remains unchanged.
This rambling, plotless sequel might have passed muster with more dancing. The stilted dialogue is no substitute.
A heist film of thrilling, almost delirious complexity.
Often fun and fanciful, though kids may not get the endless 1980s references.
A riveting re-enaction of the still-notorious study. The young cast is electrifying.
Lukewarm as a romance, but the charming young cast helps compensate.
Lacks the wickedly funny spirit of the original "Vacation."
It's a light, breezy movie -- fluffy, you might say -- that is clearly suitable even for pre-verbal viewers.
Streep and Springfield make a surprisingly sweet pair of retirement-age rockers, but the scattered story line keeps losing the beat.
In the end "Southpaw" knocks itself to the mat.
Not an update of the old TV show but a revival, with dazzling sets, period outfits and wonderfully implausible action. It's an Atomic Age blast.
"Max" can be corny, but writer-director Boaz Yakin makes it mostly work.
A freewheeling comedy about sex, drugs and identity politics.
A toothless and nearly laughless buddy comedy.
"The D Train" may be a scant and rather unconvincing comedy, but it deserves credit for taking a risk.
The first "Mad Max" movie in 30 years doesn't disappoint -- it's a sonic-speed juggernaut of violence and destruction.
Inspired musical numbers, an uninvested Kendrick and too many ethnic jokes make this comedy a mixed bag.
"Welcome to Me" has its charming, funny and sensitive moments, but it also suffers from its own form of instability.
The discomfiting premise and a fine performance by Hawke make this somewhat thinly written drama worth seeing.
A weepy romance that tries hard to be quirky and cool. More sincerity might have helped.
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: "Tomorrowland" delivers a loud and clear message of hope for humanity, which is a welcome thing to hear at any point in time.
Top-notch effects and a bottom-scraping script make this disaster flick a spectacular bore.
A breezy, enjoyable comedy, and an ideal vehicle for the endearing McCarthy.
It's a daring conceit built around two fine talents, but the results are decidedly mixed.
There isn't anything original here, but it's all executed with energy and skill. As always, the underlying message is that nature, like Hollywood formulas, should not be tampered with.
The novel, of course, is one of the towering achievements in literature, and this trivial movie has no idea what to do with it.
Only Pixar could turn a metaphor into a heart-tugging story about preteen growing pains. Absolutely brilliant.
"Aloha" is one of those films whose characters behave and speak so irrationally that they no longer make any human sense at all. Crowe may have had us at hello, but he's losing us with "Aloha."
The result is not the most explosive -- nor organic -- romance. Still, it swirls and settles in interesting ways.
A riveting film about the birth of not just one rap group but an entire genre.
About as violent and soulless as its title suggests.
The dependable Diesel and a fine cast keep this hokey action flick mostly entertaining.
Ultimately, "Our Brand Is Crisis" isn't as hard-hitting, trenchant or angry as it should be.
A macho foodie fantasy with Cooper as a swaggering sex god in an apron. If this were a comedy, it would be brilliant.
A Bond film that feels caught between its roots as a mindlessly enjoyable action-franchise and its new mandate to deliver the operatic emotions and sudsy plot lines of today's superhero properties.
An intriguing premise dampened by thin characters and a formulaic story.
A compelling but too-tidy dramatization of a remarkable rescue event.
An ongoing war is no setting for a musical comedy, especially one this glib and inane.

The characters speak not in dialogue but in self-help prose ("You love at arm's length") and their motivations feel like writerly contrivances. The film's uneven tone doesn't help: It wavers between whimsical, snarky and dopey.
Todd Haynes' sumptuous romantic drama strikes a welcome note of optimism that's still rare in gay cinema.
A lazy and not very funny stoner comedy.
A dream-team cast is wasted in this contrived and morose crime thriller.
On a technical level, at least, The Good Dinosaur is the most dazzling Pixar movie yet. As a story, however, it's the studio's weakest by far.
The seventh "Rocky" film is uneven but gets by on Jordan's charisma and some stunning fight sequences.
This dramatic thriller is small-scale but profound, with great performances from Larson and a young Tremblay.

Mockingjay - Part 2 deserves credit for incorporating real-world themes like media manipulation, terrorism and power vacuums, but its somber-faced, hand-wringing treatment can be tough to take seriously.
"Beyond the Lights" is a faint shadow of 1992's "The Bodyguard," without the star power of Whitney Houston or Kevin Costner.
An extravagantly entertaining ghost story. Hiddleston could be our next Vincent Price.
A new entry among the pantheon of great journalism movies. Blanchett is electrifying.
An amusing idea, but the ugly violence and weepy dramatics effectively kill any comedic buzz.
Creepy kids and sick jokes make for meager scares, but Ransone is likable as the film's beleaguered hero.
Depp's brutal antihero is the highlight of this compelling if somewhat familiar gangster movie.
Smith deserves credit for keeping a cool head -- and for not succumbing to her addiction under stress -- but the strategy makes for a somewhat low-energy film.
The teen dystopian franchise continues to play rough, and now even rougher, with satisfying results.
A white-knuckle survival film with an outstanding cast.
Steven Spielberg's period drama works as glossy entertainment but also draws subtle parallels to the present.
What Stonewall lacks in narrative power it makes up for with energy, sincerity and heart.
A nasty treat for those with strong stomachs.
A razzle-dazzle thriller with eye-popping visuals, white-knuckle tension and just the right note of melancholy.
You'll root for Damon as a resourceful science whiz, but the movie's total absence of plot results in a narrative vacuum.
A gripping dramatic thriller about the winners and losers in America's game of mortgage roulette.
A botched interpretation of the classic story that trades spectacle for coherence.
A whirlwind tour through the computer age with a flawed human at its center.
De Niro and Hathaway's charms plus a sparkling script make for feel-good fluff.
Thin on story, crowded with characters and padded with extraneous action. In other words, a sure hit!
More intellectually than emotionally compelling, but Segel's sincere performance as Wallace gives the movie a beating heart.
"The Water Diviner" just wants to tell an old-fashioned war story, but it might have picked the wrong war.
A smart, funny, feel-good film -- from Tim Burton? It's his best since "Ed Wood."
A capable cast and some very fine songs, but parents should take note of the dark themes. This Disney movie ain't kid stuff.
Cumberbatch's finely calibrated performance helps bring to life one of history's lesser-known stories and most shameful injustices.
Paul Thomas Anderson's hippie noir seems completely stoned: inarticulate, confused and prone to giggling at unknown jokes. Pynchon fans might tolerate it.
Neeson's late-life rebirth as an action star may be drawing to a close with this limping, wheezing entry in the "Taken" franchise.
Another silly cyber-thriller, almost saved by an intense Hemsworth and some bruising action.
Low on action and tension, long on grand speeches. Wahlberg gets an A for effort in an unlikely role.
A respectable screen version of Michael Bond's classic children's books.
What saves the film are its two leads, who aren't afraid to show their sensitive sides -- along with other parts of themselves.
It isn't nearly as daring or discomfiting as it could be. It is, however, trashy good fun and impressively steamy.
A noxious cauldron of ingredients that shouldn't have been mixed: fairies, Shakespeare and classic rock.
Depp's strenuously unfunny performance turns a frivolous caper comedy into a grim death march to the closing credits.
The found-footage technique is aimed at teens, but surely they're smart enough to see through the thin characters and skimpy story. An almost-enjoyable throwaway.
A modest drama, but Moore's heart-wrenching and Oscar-nominated performance makes this a must-see.
"A Most Violent Year" sets the stage for a showdown between principles and base instincts that never satisfyingly arrives.
Whodunit? Even the filmmakers don't seem quite sure. A waste of a perfectly good premise.
An insightful look into the making of a historic moment; Oyelowo raises the roof as MLK.
Cooper nails the role of an American killing machine in Clint Eastwood's clear-eyed look at the Iraq War.
One of the most insightful films about religion since the 1977 comedy "Oh, God!," which also wrangled with personal beliefs and unprovable truths.
This is rich material for the film's lead actors, and both are superb.
Cruder, dumber and far less funny than the original, which is saying something.
The year's best cast, including a phenomenal Carell, makes up for slow pacing in the latest drama from the director of "Capote."
Passable entertainment if you're 7. Otherwise, frenzied and aimless.
These are timeless themes -- domineering parent, sheltered child, dangerous boyfriend -- all woven together nicely by a crew of filmmakers from the Disney-Pixar trenches.
Well-crafted and compelling, but director Angelina Jolie's best contribution was casting the unknown Miyavi in a pivotal role.
A rare on-the-road movie from a female point of view.
"Exodus" turns out to be part of a time-honored tradition: the old-fashioned, super-spectacular Hollywood bomb.
Jennifer Kent's startling debut is an artful horror-chiller that gets under your skin and into your psyche.
A passably satisfying ending to a franchise that has always seemed a little like a bonus DVD.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Like their affable, ignorant characters, Rogen and Franco seem in way over their heads with "The Interview."
Wallis is adorable, but there's little magic in the new music or the barely-there choreography. A missed opportunity.
Williams glows briefly in one of his final roles, but the overall magic feels dim.
movie_title: Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It can be delightful, intelligent, crude, clumsy and culturally tone-deaf, depending on which scene is rolling by. One minute it's a major letdown, the next minute a joy to watch.
The Wachowskis trade their "Matrix" magic for the silliest space opera since "Flash Gordon."
A solid cast, but the racial issue is so poorly presented that the film feels unintentionally offensive.
A lightweight thriller posing as a heavy political drama, or vice-versa. Not thoughtful and no fun.
A preposterous premise treated with great solemnity. Lively shines, though, as does Ford.
Paul Blart: Mall Cop 2 may be forgettable, but it's difficult to truly dislike.
The usual serial-killer thriller in Soviet drag.
The young Eastwood is better than you might expect, though it's Chaplin who shines in this Nicholas Sparks romance.
A compelling exposé of professional propagandists, though the movie itself is not agenda-free.
Intriguing, but the movie's larger statement isn't clear.
Rich details but thin characters make for a disappointingly flat drama.
A slim excuse, and a perfectly good one, for trotting around the globe, blowing up drones in Los Angeles and sending Lebanese sports cars crashing through Abu Dhabi skyscrapers.
Hart and Ferrell may not be Pryor and Wilder, but they score several laughs in this slim comedy.
The film moves quickly and keeps the jokes coming, which only means that "Home" would rather keep young viewers occupied than give them something to think about.
Promises more than it delivers, but engrossing throughout.
Rarely have on-screen teens felt this authentic. They bluster, bicker and trade horrible insults (whence the film's R rating), then suddenly expose their most guarded feelings.
A self-aggrandizing sermon that preaches only to the faithful.
No masterpiece, but a welcome February surprise with a lively cast and rugged action.
The cast still shines, but this mid-franchise movie is mostly spinning its wheels.
"Run All Night" is a mostly satisfying action-drama from director Jaume Collet-Serra, who made Neeson's "Non-Stop" such a guilty pleasure.
A smart, funny, straight-talking teen movie in the John Hughes tradition. Oodles of charm from the young cast.
Mike Leigh's biopic is so richly detailed that it feels like a documentary. Spall goes for broke in the outsize title role.
Not the most gripping narrative, but the frenetic pace and nonstop gags will please young fans.
movie_title: The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Despite the endless sex, a highly unsatisfying encounter. Cold as a fish and almost as dumb.
The less you try to make sense of "Kingsman: The Secret Service," the more you'll enjoy this freewheeling, preposterously violent action comedy from the creators of "Kick-Ass."
Returning director Steve Pink often simply shows his actors a prop -- a piece of furniture, say -- and asks them to make jokes about it.
Better than you might think, thanks to strong work from Costner and a cast of fresh faces.

While it's often as pedantic and square as an Army training film, this movie about black teens trying to grow up in a gang-plagued South Central Los Angeles area generates strong emotions.
Morbid and overwrought.

This lame effort, Disney's latest live-action motion picture for children, owes a big, fat nod for its plot to Mark Twain's A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court. In no way, however, does it improve upon the original

movie_review_blurb: This is a sequel for sequel's sake - all title, no content.

movie_review_blurb: This series' record of maintaining an admirable level of quality stays intact, even if this film might best be used as a cinematic appetizer to see before renting a tape of one of the Connery or Moore classics.
Adults, despite being wowed by the dazzling, geez-how'd-they-do-that animation, will find their attention wandering to Christmases past.
This film about a real incident that occurred near the end of World War II is involving, always focused and affectingly acted.
It won't make anyone forget Miracle on 34th Street, but this is pleasant fare as far as holiday films go nowadays, which isn't very far.
Thanks to a peculiar chemistry and a terrific script, Mel Gibson and Danny Glover lift this movie above mere TV-cop fodder.
This is the most playfully amusing, inventive new cinematic Christmas fable in several decades.
While director Ted Demme seems to be trying to impose a Home Alone tone, he only succeeds in lending an air of desperation, with lame subplots blundering into the picture.
[Tandy and Freeman] are so affecting they turn what could have been merely well-meant hokum into a touching tribute to compassion and human dignity.
When the movie penetrates to the heart of their buried past, Patient becomes even stronger, stranger, grander -- a threnody beneath a cloudless desert sky.
To say this movie is sporadically artful is to say that it is more interesting than most films around these days. But it is still a failure, if a glorious one.

Above all, Kingsley's astonishing performance, capturing both Gandhi's divine light and his irresistible simplicity, inspires this ambitious film.
Robert De Niro is, once again, explosive in this stunning Vietnam movie.

While Scorsese generates vivid images, he covered this ground in the superb Mean Streets in 1973. Here there's nothing to learn, nobody to sympathize with.

All right, maybe the world isn't flat. But this listless historical epic sure is.
The reenacted Saturday Night Live routines that made Belushi a star seem grim.
Is this a bad satire? No, it's a bad serious romance.
A curiously gripping amalgam of Patton, Citizen Kane and Melvin and Howard.

Alden's script goes from charming to preposterous to preachy.

No sane person should want to get any closer to war than this film.

G.I. Joe is like watching fireworks with a blindfold on: it's deafening and you feel under attack.

movie_review_blurb: Brothers shows us that even when our troops do come home, their war may be far from over.
Mr. Fox doesn't just rescue Dahl's legacy on film. In a year stuffed with kid-lit movie adaptations, it's the only one to successfully reach out to children and adults.
In Date Night, Carell is the cake batter that holds up Fey's icing.
A thrilling, tense, and weirdly funny heist film anchored by a tight, no-nonsense script.
Watching Lights Out is like standing next to an idiot with an air horn, never quite knowing when it's about to blow in your ear. It's a far cry from the freaky grace of David F. Sandberg's short.
This film's biggest strength: its pervasive, unrelenting aura of unease.
Writer/director James DeMonaco has brilliantly tailored the film's political milieu and anti-establishment bent to this year's election, exploiting our country's current anxieties for maximum horror.
entral Intelligence is genuinely funny, intriguingly plotted, and quite frankly one of the biggest surprises of the year.

At its core, it's a simple and triumphant tale of sisterhood, but with so much ladled on top of it it begins to feel as though it's grasping for a grandeur it doesn't need. Sometimes, even the most intense emotions can benefit from a light touch.

London Has Fallen is terrorism porn, an alarmist, jingoistic piece of CGI-soaked garbage that implores its audience to fear nothing after sensationalizing the slaughter of innocents and the destruction of a major city.

Kindergarten Cop 2 ultimately resonates as nothing more than a sub-par rendition of its predecessor. The script is bad, the direction is uninspired, the villain is boring, and Lundgren can't navigate that space between comedy and action like Arnie can.

Howell and Robinson are certainly savvy when it comes to tackling big, emotional ideas with a light touch, but that doesn't always translate to gripping entertainment. Claire in Slow Motion might be a more fitting title.

Miss Stevens is a mature film and blessed with a point of view that helps it transcend other stories of its ilk.
Don't Think Twice is a brisk, engaging watch. It's sweet, it's melancholy, and, perhaps most importantly, it's hilarious.
A sumptuous and affecting visual memoir that doubles as an exploration of memory.
When you factor in politics or the media, manipulating whatever it is that makes you vulnerable is the only way to survive. Deception, as Weiner shows us, is just part of the game.

Youth is so often sacrificed in the pursuit of some kind of warped purity. Mustang is an impassioned reaction to such dogma, a gorgeous, heartfelt assertion that it's your right to live however the hell you want.
It's far too generous to call it a Christmas classic, but Love the Coopers would pair great with a warm cup of cocoa, a roaring fireplace, and whoever it is you call family.
SPOILER ALERT: Toby looks like every other horror movie demon. And The Ghost Dimension just looks like every other horror movie.
Manson Family Vacation isn't a buddy comedy or a road movie, though it has aspects of both. It's very funny, but unafraid of intense emotional catharsis.

The Visit's third act revelation is a doozy, a singular moment that suddenly brings the rest of the film into focus as it makes you facepalm yourself for not figuring it out sooner. Those final 15 minutes are gloriously stupid and joyously breathless.
Kids aren't scary. Get rid of them, though, and Sinister 2 might be.
Watching Dark Places is like watching a bunch of Malibu prep schoolers perform Buried Child. They're hitting all the notes, sure, but they haven't the first idea what it all means.
Creep is an effective thriller, and a fine showcase for the developing talents of Mark Duplass, who hasn't let his foray into the mainstream affect his growth as an artist.
In our mainstream horror landscape's glut of sequels, remakes, and cash-ins, you could do a lot worse than Insidious: Chapter 3.

War Dogs is a "rags"-to-riches story about two white dude-bro arms dealers who lie, cheat, and steal their way into U.S. Military contracts. It's vacuous, ugly, unfunny, and, somehow, not a satire. It might be the worst movie of the year.
While We're Young subverts and exploits the audience's desire to find heroes and villains in its narrative. Millennials merge with Generation X and emerge conflicted, but enlightened.
I never thought I'd write this, but Kirk Cameron's Left Behind, flawed as it is, looks and sounds better in almost every single way.
Exists suffers from a lack of restraint.
[REC] 4: Apocalypse is probably the sequel you wanted after [REC 2].

There's something nostalgic about Morgan, not in its technology or direction, both of which are aggressively modern, but in its structure.

It's a crackerjack premise, if only because it fundamentally alters the fabric of the traditional horror template.

It's Lost in 105 minutes-an unfolding array of neat, amusing, and uncanny ideas that drift into the ether once the writers realize they don't know how to end this thing and should probably look to their forebears.

An imbalance is created by the film's hard turn into social justice when its first two acts are more so centered around discourse and character.

American Assassin will satisfy those who want to see invulnerable American badasses gun down Middle Eastern terrorists. It's like if True Lies weren't a comedy.
Hereditary's horror functions on multiple levels. What we see is undoubtedly terrifying, but it's how we see it that truly distinguishes the film.

Valerian's power doesn't come from its cast or its story, and Besson probably didn't intend for it to. The film's power is in the construction of its world, which is as vivid as any I've seen on film.

Admirably performed.

Green Zone is far from perfect. But man oh man, as a pulse-pounding thriller, it is a knockout.

You leave the theater with a pleasant grin on your face, but by no means is it as wide as the Cheshire Cat's, and that's a shame.
Repeatedly hits us in the gut with the realities of war and might even make us re-evaluate our perceptions about the men who fight it.
Disney's excessively hyped A Christmas Carol brings Dickensian details to such sumptuous life that you mostly forgive it for possessing a stop-motion soul.
Welcome back, Man of Steel, you've been gone far too long.

The loaded-to-the-gills carnival ride, the second in what's shaping up to be a wildly successful trilogy, is almost as good as the first voyage.

movie_review_blurb: This is a deeply personal work on the ravages of drug abuse, and the moral casualties suffered when governments fight it.
30 Days the movie conjures the ominous atmosphere that haunted the graphic novel, but squanders much of the rest.

In the sweet and sexy romance Shelter, the chemistry between two surfer guys magnetically played by Brad Rowe and newcomer Trevor Wright is so electric, so palatable that even the most ardent nitpickers won't break a sweat over the small stuff.
The audience is left with just a whole lot of pretty and not enough soul. Not entirely a bad thing, but you can get that fix by thumbing through an Abercrombie & Fitch catalogue.
From first frame to last, Watchmen holds you in its thrall.
Preposterous? You bet. But 2012 delivers the disaster-movie goods better than any other popcorn movie we've seen since the '80s.

A brawny, rollicking mash-up that is a passionate exploration of the power of filmmaking from one of our finest directors and writers.

Its worst offense is assuming the audience is so dumb that it'll be shocked by one of the most telegraphed endings in movie history. On second thought, maybe the filmmakers got their wish: Whiteout is shocking, shockingly bad.
Its worst offense is assuming the audience is so dumb that it'll be shocked by one of the most telegraphed endings in movie history.

Cornish and Whishaw give powerful, unforgettable performances, with Cornish assured of an Oscar nomination. Other cast members, such as Schneider and Kerry Fox as Fanny's mother, make the film even stronger.

movie_review_blurb: No question, Perry's Girls is compelling and powerful. But it's also a missed opportunity, one that fails to fully capitalize on mostly terrific performances and the story's timeless message.
If Oscar overlooks Franco, it would be a travesty. It would also be a shame to avoid seeing 127 Hours simply because the subject matter makes you wince.
Faults and all, The Next Three Days is a pleasant surprise this fall -- a thriller that moves us while steering clear of the action cliches.
Ultimately it's the chemistry -- that old-fashioned key ingredient in any successful love story -- that fires up Love & Other Drugs and reduces minor quibbles to ash.

Carrey relies little on his physical theatrics to bring Russell alive, for which we are grateful. That toned-down approach results in one of the comedian's most complex performances yet, even if the shadows from previous roles creep in.
Firth makes us feel his alienation, his self-loathing and his sense of privilege. He gives the film its full-bodied voice, one that's perfect in tone, perfect in pitch.
These highfalutin boys sure know how to wrastle up one spitfire of a Western.
Year's success rests heavily on its cast's and director's shoulders. And the performers, most stage veterans and Leigh alums, don't disappoint.
The movie tells an unbelievable story, one that will outrage and -- yes -- inspire you.

Elephants might not perform any new genre tricks, but that's OK. After all, a good story is a good story -- be it on the page or up on the screen.
All in all, Thor is good, quick-witted superhero fun -- written, directed and acted by pros.
No matter how much Cruz and Depp squabble during the quest to find the Fountain of Youth, no real sparks fly.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: We've been on this bender before, and no matter how raunchy and un-PC The Hangover Part II is, there's no disguising that this is just warmed-up leftovers that will leave a nasty taste in your mouth.

Why Click fails to click is because of a crass, uncertain script, which wavers between an unfunny Saturday Night Live skit and a Lifetime Channel movie. Only once, near the end, did I care about his plight. But then, maybe it was heartburn.
In the end, Larry Crowne is watchable and undemanding, but it doesn't leave a lasting impression.
Even though [Damon and Blunt] look awfully cute scurrying around the streets of New York City, there's no escaping from the fact that this Bureau winds up merely spinning its wheels.
Despite flaws and inconsistencies, a geeky teen-superhero flick can be worth seeing.
The ensemble is terrific. These are pros at work here, and they not only show up the new action-star punks but prove they're far from expendable.
Stone and the script shortchange the characters, forcing them to do things that seem phony and having them recite lines that sound stilted and overly didactic.
The movie unpretentiously and effectively shows how our cultural, personal and environmental history not only shape us but affect our decisions.
It's a solid blockbuster with a few faults that you just don't mind overlooking.
It's leagues better than the 1991 Kevin Costner fiasco and thankfully devoid of a Bryan Adams song. But that's not good enough, given the talent in front of and behind the camera.
In one unfortunate regard, Ridley Scott's grimy Robin Hood lives up to the actions of its legendary character: It, too, robs -- but just from richer movies.
I'll gladly kiss the ground for a popcorn movie like this -- one that doesn't bludgeon us for two hours and leave us with a huge headache from wearing those stupid 3-D glasses.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A bold and hilarious comedy that says something astute about us, our idols and how all that sex, drugs and rock 'n' roll really isn't everything it's cracked up to be.
Tom Cruise should go bonkers more often. At least on screen, that is.

After so many bad romance movies, it's a treat to see genuine sparks fly between two major stars. That the budding relationship evolves over the course of bullets, die-hard assassins and chiseled torsos increases the pleasure.
This is a rousingly entertaining and robustly acted movie with electrifying horse-racing sequences filmed from the jockey's perspective. Now, how cool is that?
Eclipse is a convincing piece of entertainment that demonstrates this franchise is starting to realize its full potential.
While Jolie saves Salt from itself several times, the film still demonstrates how her star power comes with a price when a screenplay can't match her smarts.
Funny this movie is, revolutionary it isn't.
Supply acted and engrossing.
This is one exciting and efficient tale -- a hearty-ho of a guilty pleasure.
Minus Patricia Clarkson's pitch-perfect performance, the lovely to look at but monotonously paced Cairo Times would wind up less satisfying.
Bar-Lev summons us to remain defiant when our government demands complacency, and never to falter in our purpose even if the outcome eventually leaves so much still unresolved.
Wielding an improbable vocabulary that would elicit a head scratch from Merriam-Webster and possessing a beautiful and expressive face, the 21-year-old redhead [Stone] makes you fall for her hard.
An intriguing and suspenseful documentary.
Inception is the blockbuster we've all been thirsting for, a sleek brain-twister that makes the other 2010 mainstream releases look puny, drab and empty-headed in comparison.

The Lake House is the type of movie you hear friends groan about Hollywood not making anymore. It's an old-fashioned romance that scoffs at today's frantic pacing, leisurely seducing us with its heartfelt story about the timeless value of love.
Everything about Emma Thompson's Nanny McPhee is pleasant. It's pleasantly amusing, pleasantly enchanting and just pleasant enough to take the kids to a matinee.
Jack Black body slams his way into the heavyweight division of physical comedy with Nacho Libre.

Let's get the most pressing questions out of the way from the get-go. Yes, the latest version of Pride & Prejudice is quite good. No, it's not great, in that 1995 A&E miniseries sort of way, but it's very good nonetheless.
Derailed should have received a one-way ticket to the direct-to-video bin, stacked next to Cruel Intentions 3.

The heart and soul of Walk the Line lies in its powder-keg performance by Joaquin Phoenix.

An uninspired, unoriginal and unnecessary movie with less intelligence and laughs than the very worst Full House episode.

Get Rich seems stagy and phony. What a missed opportunity, because the rapper's compelling story offers ample opportunity for drama.
The Chronicles of Narnia so vividly captures the magic of the book that Harry Potter might just want to watch his back.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Life would be a whole lot sweeter if every grouchy person were sent to watch the high-spirited The Producers.

Welcome back, Woody.
Really what Holiday is about is Latifah.

Joyously goofy and always witty.

[The film] reminds us of why we first fell in love with Kong and Hollywood movies in general.

I haven't had this much fun at the movies in a long time.

This Corpse rises to the occasion.

Hopefully, this loving adaptation will allow a new generation to discover this masterpiece.
It's refreshing to be rescued by a bright little G-rated movie with a 24-carat heart.

... a mesmerizing and unnerving thriller, one with a sharp political bite.

The least satisfying "Hunger Games" entry yet.

What this 3-D extravaganza gets spectacularly right is in putting the epic back into the biblical epic.

While it's true that none of the "Hobbit" films were as good as any in the "Rings" trilogy, "The Five Armies" at least comes closest to capturing Tolkein's essence. And in this instance that is good enough.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Given its subject, it should have been great, but it turns out to be simply good.

If the first film felt like snuggling up with a warm blanket, this one is like sipping a comforting cup of warm tea.

With no bombast whatsoever, The Tale of the Princess Kaguya manages to stir the soul.
movie_title: The Tale of the Princess Kaguya (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A spellbindingly unique experience that will leave you dazed and exhilarated.
Without a doubt, it is one of 2014's best animated films; a holiday delight that exuberantly bursts at the seams with irresistible cultural pride.

Wise and sometimes funny, delicately reminding us to live and love honestly and fully, while we all still have that gift.

Few films have conveyed with such understanding about how a creative soul taps into all that interior turmoil and then somehow shape these thoughts into artful prose that can scald and heal.
Haggis has written and directed better films than "Third Person," and I bet he'll make even better ones in the future.
"Life Itself," filmmaker Steve James' moving tribute to America's most popular film critic, serves as a poignant reminder of what a distinguished journalist and courageous man he was.
"Tammy" is all over the map. But mostly in a good way.
"Far From the Madding Crowd" is one the most satisfying, finest romantic period dramas to grace screens, big or small, in awhile.
"Boyhood" is a cinematic gift, a compassionate and sometimes amusing drama about growing up that extracts truths out of what appear to be life's most random moments.
A summer comic-book movie that effortlessly makes you feel like a wide-eyed, happy kid again.
This feel-good tale about an Indian family setting up a restaurant across the road from one with a Michelin star celebrates things all cultures can get behind: family, food and transformation.

Anyone offended by graphic violence, kinky sex and eyefuls of nudity should stay away. But for those who like their fiction hard-boiled like a rock and naughty to the bone, expect to be pleased, if not thoroughly satisfied.
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: An enjoyable way to spend a couple of hours at the theater.
movie_title: This Is Where I Leave You (2014)

movie_review_blurb: What's admirable about "Pride" is that it avoids melodrama and leaves you walking out of the theater with a lump in your throat and a smile on your face.
Pike is a revelation. The actress ... demonstrates versatility with compelling eyes that can instantly switch from innocent to detached. Oscar consideration is certainly a possibility for her.
While Ayer's "Fury" does mine a well-worn genre, it is texturally different in how vigorously and viscerally it laces us into tired, brave soldiers' muck-stained boots.
Even with its flaws, "Whiplash" is very much worth seeing. With its shotgun acting, fierce direction and galvanizing music, it nails the most important notes.
In the overall Allen pantheon, "Magic in the Moonlight" falls somewhere in the middle. There is enough to recommend it.
Like Caesar, this entertaining picture rises to the occasion and resoundingly exceeds expectations.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Noble intentions don't always net smashing results, and such is the case with the disappointing "Tomorrowland" ...
As for the story line, there are faults and cracks aplenty. But "San Andreas" does know where its epicenter must be: overdone, loud, anything-but-realistic and enthusiastic destruction sequences.
While Joy isn't a smooth ride, it is an interesting one, taking us to some unexpected places while giving us an entertaining portrait of a female entrepreneur.
It is a unique journey that tells a timeless parable about greed, redemption and the dawning realization that man might be even more dangerous than nature.
A sobering, evocative drama.
The difficult-to-watch yet accessible film painstakingly recounts two high-profile cyberbullying cases.
While "Deadpool" heralds the arrival of a talented new director, its success belongs to Reynolds, who also served as a producer.

For anyone seeking an intelligent, atmospheric American horror story reminiscent of Edgar Allan Poe, Hawthorne and the Brothers Grimm, "The Witch" is the kind of pure movie magic that sends chills up the spine.

Colombian filmmaker Ciro Guerra assumes the role of an ever-aware river guide, navigating us through the sweeping beauty of the Amazon while pointing to the toll on humanity and culture wrought by colonialism.
movie_title: Embrace Of The Serpent (El Abrazo De La Serpiente) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: An intriguing meander through one man's existential crisis.

While "The Big Short" could have benefitted from an even harder, names-taking edge, its satirical approach succeeds in a key way: Shaking us awake to the possibility that history might be repeating itself.

All of this is uncomfortable to watch. Then again, given the subject matter, it should be.
Dough is fun, a sweet-natured confection with a hopeful message about unity that is well-suited for our socially complex, divided times.
An eye opener in every sense

It is really no plot at all, merely a vehicle to allow Shepard and Pena to riff about kinky bedroom habits, homophobia and so on. Those flippant exchanges fluctuate from funny to flat.
Sound too bleak? For some, perhaps. But in McDonagh's careful hands, it's a Cirque du Soleil-like tightrope walk, gracefully balancing the harrowing with the humorous.
It offers shreds of hope, something we can cling to even now.
At a time when many films can be viewed and summarily forgotten, "River" unsettles and lingers long afterwards -- just like the ghosts that haunt this family.

A fun, cheerful time passer that's filled with many random zingers that will leave you snickering afterward.
