movie_review_blurb: Your interest is held by newcomer Pierre Chatagny, who captures all the infuriating, frustrating, incontestably sweet qualities of a young gay man in search of himself.
[The] thematic material is so far beyond [director Joe] Roth's reach, you feel that even offering him a stepladder wouldn't help.
The vocal work is so finely honed by the cast of regulars, that the acting conveys a timing and skill rarely encountered in even the best live-action comedies.
When's the last time the tightly clenched buttcheeks of a former pro football star tickled your funnybone?
[Hugo] Weaving finds the right balance of flamboyant flourish and quietly subtle, effective mannerisms. In this actor's hands, even the smallest **** of the head says so much.
In leaving America, Woody Allen has, at long last, put himself back on the map.
Brosnan gives his most liberated and likeable performance since his Remington Steele days.
Unfunny business.
movie_title: Looking for Comedy in the Muslim World (2006)

movie_review_blurb: What good is a scary movie without a lesson?...Hostel imparts perhaps the greatest lesson of all: When traveling abroad, always choose Marriott.
When it comes to humor, this Pink is extremely pale.
Funny, flip, frequently shocking, sometimes appalling, and always engaging.
[Richard Donner's] polished, gusto-filled movie has...a juicy full-steam-ahead quality that never flags. It earns the right to be called vastly entertaining.
World Trade Center is likely the one summer release you least want to see.... But the fact is, [it's] the one film you don't want to miss.
A Scanner Darkly finds Linklater in experimental mode, which is a far, far better place for him to be than in a little league dugout.
[Gordon-Levitt's] performance is flawless in a film that is mildly flawed, a film whose twists and turns really don't amount to more than slight bends in the road.
The movie's driving force is Dench, whose extraordinary performance only underscores her post as one of the world's finest living actresses.
Del Toro has an unmistakable aesthetic -- his movies bear the stamp of an auteur.
Dramatically, it's pale and wan, an almost defiant bore. It sits there, like a month-old stew hiding in the back of the fridge: thick, gummy, indigestible.
Dreamgirls belongs to Hudson. When she sings, the movie transcends its celluloid confines, becoming an experience that is spiritual, impassioned, profound.
The action sequences, filmed with a jerky hand-held camera to impart a sense of realism, are impressive, incorporating a palpable danger that sends shudders.
If it weren't for a singular, gripping performance by Cate Blanchett, The Good German might as well have been titled The Incredibly Boring German.
Casino Royale revives, rejuvenates and refreshes the series.... Watching it, you realize what it must have been like for 1962 audiences to experience Dr. No.
Gone is the nuance, the mystery, the fright factor, in its place a near-campy Dr. Phibes-like obsession with revenge.
If there were any justice in the world of movies, the film's distributor would gather up all copies of For Your Consideration before it hits theaters and burn them.
The PrestigeH is infused with faux intellectualism -- it pretends to be more cerebral than it really is, when all it really wants to do is be the new Sixth Sense.
Borat [blends] the mockumentary form with...an extreme, fearless level of performance art, creating a glorious and profound new kind of comedy experience.
movie_title: Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The movie isn't just mediocre -- it's profoundly mediocre.
There's no twist in Lady in the Water, but that's not to say it doesn't possess an abundance of cleverness.
It fails to evoke one laugh over the course of 90 minutes, revealing Woody Allen's sense of humor to be not merely ailing, but dead -- completely, utterly, forever dead.
Tenacious D in the Pick of Destiny proves one thing: Rock and roll never dies. It just gains weight.
movie_title: Tenacious D in The Pick of Destiny (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Writer-director Neil Marshall has...a gift for psychological subtext that infuses the narrative with a nasty, poisonous moral venom.
Mel Gibson emotes as the doleful Dane.
Shakespeare's great tragedy -- all of it.
Contrived plot purposely pulls at heartstrings.
A tale of heroic sportsmanship.
The Marx Brothers at their wacky best.
Thrilling third Indy actioner focuses on hunt for grail.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade (1989)

movie_review_blurb: Forceful telling of Angelou's coming-of-age book.
movie_title: I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings (1979)

movie_review_blurb: Indy's first adventure is a rip-roaring action masterpiece.
More gore, gross-outs than the other Indy blockbusters.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom (1984)

movie_review_blurb: Kids will get a kick out of this mule tale.
This classic delivers warmth all year long.
British class conflict; ok for older teens.
A witty, sarcastic take on redemption.
Melodramatic, a bit racy -- some teens will love.
Romance, suspense, gags, and one-liners.
A dated rebellion tale.
Steve Martin's sweet-natured wedding weepy.
A treat for baseball fans but might bore others.
A classic American tragedy.
Inspiring, intense story of a teacher and his students.
A violent, offensive comedy.
A complex tale of morals and animal cruelty.
A harrowing and Beauty-ful version of the book.
Coming-of-age classic still a must-see for teens.
Classic based on the Pulitzer prize-winning play.
A fanciful sci-fi tale for the whole family.
movie_title: Journey to the Center of the Earth (1959)

movie_review_blurb: A comic horror movie classic.
Terrifyingly realistic dinos run amok in sci-fi landmark.
A decent movie for teens, if they can endure it.
A realistic look at a teen's coming-of-age.
The little guy wins in this rote comedy.
Sydney Poitier at his best; teens and up.
A star is born in Nashville.
Field of Dreams for tweens.
Educational, exciting action, great acting.
Nastier beasts and mean people in intense sequel.
Reunited and it feels so bad.
Inspiring, sentimental tale of survival.
Worthwhile tale of adolescence and difference.
movie_title: The Boy in the Plastic Bubble (1976)

movie_review_blurb: Offensive, shop-worn comedy.
A lovable pet tale about friendship despite differences.
movie_title: The Adventures of Milo and Otis (1986)

movie_review_blurb: A mature, well-made film for teens and adults.
Glossy, funny, and packs a real emotional wallop.
Suspenseful Cold War tale with teen gamer in control.
Valuable lessons in loving one's family members.
Racy, drunken, hilarious '80s high school comedy.
Stirring movie may be too heavy for some tweens.
A gem of a coming-of-age story.
Cruel treatment of horses may upset some kids.
Far-fetched fantasy is good-natured fun for all.
Action, romance, sharp dialog; best for teens.
Excellent, but may be too long and moody for kids.
Jeff Bridges as appealing alien; best for teens.
Not deep, but definitely funny--teens will enjoy.
Coming of age story still relevant and engaging.
Sensational, implausible, irresistible to teens.
Lots of fun, but too scary for some kids.
Quote not available.
movie_title: Tom Dowd and the Language of Music (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Julian Fellowes is two for two.
To this day, 'Dueling Banjoes' still gives me the willies.
It was the first of Hawks' three immortal screwball goldmines,
This chronicle of the human condition set to music will only rise in value and statue over time.
More style than substance, and perhaps simply an excuse to get Denueve and Susan Sarandon, Miriam's post-Bowie love, in bed together.
It's exactly the type of craziness that good newspapers thrive on. Stop the presses.
Martin Scorsese's Shine a Light will prompt myriad reactions -- shock, awe, glee -- but dismissal will be in the minority.
Viking central's biggest cultural touchstone since the moose, black metal music comes off almost as monstrous.
DeHaan's possession of the spotlight might well best the band itself, since Metallica never completely catches fire live.
At the end of the day, Johnston's childlike stream of unrequited love landed him on MTV, Atlantic Records, and now a feature-length theatrical recounting of his life. Take that, Satan.
Director Gavin Hood works the tension and the moral uncertainty to good effect but at times the film feels schematic and too much like revision.
This brings much-needed new life to a popular cinematic landscape overcrowded with ageing franchises and endless reboots.
Zvyagintsev has a way of making even inert nature live on screen that recalls Tarkovsky, but if the imagery early on evokes fairy tales, this one is only grim.
This is a film-maker revisiting childhood with great glee and mixed results.
It's just as silly as it sounds, but it's also a joyous celebration of heresy from a country that deserves a good laugh.
movie_title: The Brand New Testament (Le tout nouveau testament) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: [A] warmly enveloping exploration of grief, guilt and gradually letting go.
Through it all - action set-pieces, eco-subplots, a few frights - Favreau drives the plot like a man with a machete, clearing the way for us to be swept along, dazzled, delighted.
With fine and affecting performances all round, this is an enjoyably old-fashioned ensemble piece and a solid start to a career behind the camera.
When Miller called "action" on this reboot he really meant it.
Radu Mihaileanu's update of Lysistrata with overtones of the Arab Spring never settles on a consistent tone; as a result, serious moments lack force and lighter moments feel hollow.
Aschan gives her film a glacial surface while suggesting a maelstrom of suppressed rage and sexual urges just beneath.
This is Delpy's picture and she handles the writing-directing-starring juggler's act well, showing an insightful eye for cross-cultural quirks and modern mores.
Despite the most worthy intentions, Childers cannot single-handedly save Sudan and Butler cannot save this movie.

July, who gave us the lovably odd Me and You and Everyone We Know, has layered on so much self-conscious whimsy - monologues from the cat, dialogues with the moon and other dashes of magical realism - that the central drama struggles to be heard.
It all ends with a series of speeches that are rambling but humorous and heartfelt - much like the movie itself.

At times it feels like money for old tropes but Dujardin is a likeable lead who shows he can do more than just ooze charm as he starts to crack the case at the expense of even bigger fissures in his family life.
If you think it sounds like a subject for hardcore cinephiles only, think again. Michel Hazanavicius has a huge amount of fun with his subject ...
Wonder Wheel and its recent predecessors suggest that Allen is not just out of favour but out of ideas. You get the feeling that, one way or other, time's up.
To say that the film lacks a clear focus would be true enough but this, surely, is Haneke's very point.
Never has a 4,000-year-old aphorism seemed more devastatingly of the moment. But the results are inspiring: it seems The Work works.
Coppola has inverted the old order of sexploitation and Farrell has been reduced to a sex object. He just looks like a very happy one.
This is one ghost that can be swiftly laid to rest.
At times the film feels overly episodic and pleased with itself but this is a sharp and skilful dissection of bourgeois hypocrisies that resonates all too uncomfortably.

Human Flow does not pretend to reinvent the form and other documentaries are more artfully constructed, yet in its urgent mission not just to shock us into action but to humanise those affected, it is entirely successful.
Another piercing performance from [Frances] McDormand.
The tone Clooney favours is far wilder than Wilder - a broad, zany slapstick noir. And it's an absolute hoot.
The Shape of Water may not be suitable for children but it has enough disarming charm to briefly make you feel like one.
Adapted from a novel by Willy Vlautin, the film is luminously shot and acted, and, for the most, part beautifully controlled ...
The message almost swallows the movie but Payne knows when to pull back and undercuts the growing tide of schmaltz with little absurdist touches.
Seems to lose interest and skip forward every time it is in danger of building momentum.
It courses with such adrenaline that the tension seldom sags.
Lanthimos's film will no doubt appal many and upset all but this is a gripping and off-kilter horror of operatic grandeur, twisted humour and unabashed seriousness.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Campillo, who wrote The Class, has a flare for capturing group dynamics even if sometimes the characters' speeches begin to sound like infomercials.
movie_title: BPM (Beats Per Minute) (120 battements par minute) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Best by a mile are newcomer Jules Porier as the young Marvin, a pale boy with gamin grace, and Grégory Gadebois as his father, a phlegmy walrus of a man forever exposing expanses of flesh in sleeveless denim and distended briefs.
A powerful, focused drama about the disgusting, damaging practice of sexual slavery.
The specific story, while formulaic, is carried soulfully by its three main actors, who make Under the Same Moon a success despite its flaws.
Lushly photographed and carried along by a spirited score featuring both Ethiopian and Western music, but the film's most striking element proves to be the women at its center.

[Director] Ruzowitzky's straightforward approach to this unusual story and cinematographer Benedict Neunfels's documentary-style immediacy transcend the now well-worn Holocaust genre, bringing another side of the tragedy into unflinching focus.
We can appreciate the film's good intentions, but we can't shake the feeling that we've been talked down to, rather than informed.
The pacing and tone of Girls Rock! match its subject perfectly.
[Actor Gad] Elmaleh is the soul of Priceless, and watching his comedic chops is the highlight of this snappy, joyous ride.
Sputnik Mania is not riveting; but it is, first and last, informative.

With all this fascinating real-life material to work with, it's frustrating that the directors choose to devote half of the movie to well-worn archival footage of members of congress debating the decision to invade Iraq in 2002.
With all these lyrical elements in play, [director Yung] Chang's extraneous voiceover narration is baffling, and all but unbearable.
April and Frank are mired in angst, for no discernable reason, other than having the misfortune of being stuck in a downer of a movie.
[Director] Akin captures his characters' movements, both physical and emotional, with poetic fluidity.
movie_title: Auf der Anderen Seite (The Edge of Heaven) (On the Other Side) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A film whose gorgeous cinematography and endearing subject matter almost mask its mediocrity.
Its comedy falls flat, and the film has a violent core where its heart should be.
After 15 years, is Bridget Jones just past the sell-by date?
Curiously lacking a sense of the 'uncommon nonsense' and freakish fun of the source novel, Alice Through The Looking Glass falls short of its potential.
A hard-nosed biopic of the Panamanian prizefighter Roberto Duran, Hands of Stone is primarily a showcase for Edgar Ramirez.
A gripping film, Desierto could not be more relevant.
Neither exciting nor entertaining, [Billy Lynn's Long Halftime Walk] is recommended for Ang Lee completists only.
This is at best a guilty pleasure; B-movie fun while it lasts.
Livelier and with a more pronounced streak of poignancy than the standard animation fare, Storks puts a clever spin on the myth of long-legged birds bringing babies into the world.
A purported psychological thriller with embarrassing Hitchcockian undertones, The Girl On The Train is dramatically inert and lacks even a semblance of the master's style or storytelling skills.
Rudyard Kipling's beloved and much-filmed story gets a new millennium makeover in the latest iteration of The Jungle Book.
Matt Brown's workmanlike direction ties things up neatly but fails to elicit enough empathy for the central characters of the young number-cruncher and his tutor-cum-collaborator.
Pretty tired stuff.

Triple 9 is best during the first third, introducing its rogues' gallery of characters and detailing their daily grind. Unfortunately, the last third is weighed down by predictable thriller trappings.
Ultimately, Inferno is a long-winded mystery-adventure of the forgettable kind.
Technically sophisticated and emotionally engaging.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: This cheerless piece of yuletide tomfoolery wastes the talents of its gifted comedic cast, top-lined by Jennifer Aniston and Jason Bateman.
Ultimately, The Light Between Oceans is a hokey period romance masquerading as a morality tale.
Potterheads can rejoice as JK Rowling takes another journey into the wondrous world of wizards and witches.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: At a time when most computer-generated blockbusters are aimed at audiences with attention-span deficiencies, it's heartening to come across the work of an auteur like Tim Burton who continues to give free rein to his imagination.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: An undeniable master at telling deeply affecting matinee-style tales, [Spielberg's] 29th feature retains enough magical elements from the source novel to delight kids and captivate adults.
The occasional use of dream sequences and flashbacks, particularly to Joy's courtship and marriage, are jarring. But Russell draws out expert performances from the ensemble.
This retelling of Daniel Defoe's literary classic is squarely aimed at very young children.
This is one of the finest comics-to-screen adaptations ever.
Despite some impressive visual flourishes - the slain President's limousine racing to the hospital - the much-hyped Jackie is ultimately a big let-down.
At times sentimental but never maudlin, Lion is an inspiring slice-of-life odyssey.
One desperately wants to enjoy the cinematic escapade but the fun eventually wears thin as the familiar narrative fails to illuminate the magic of the movies during its infancy.
12 Years A Slave is essential viewing.
Part intense drama, part dark comedy, the fifth feature by the Mexican filmmaker Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu delivers the cinematic equivalent of a knockout punch.
A pulp fiction flick of almost operatic grandeur, Chapter 2 yields one helluva good time at the matinee. Have a blast.
Despite the stellar cast, though, the film is weighted down by an overload of subplots.
Moonlight represents American independent cinema at its finest.
The aim of Rings may have been to revive a long-dormant horror franchise, but the outcome is likely to be forgotten even before all the end credits have rolled.
It doesn't help that Butterfield and Robertson have little charisma and even less chemistry. Two hours is too high a price to pay for this saga that goes nowhere.
The outcome is guaranteed to try anyone's patience.

Lavish colour-coded costumes, impeccable production design and nifty special effects make it eminently watchable, thanks in part to cinematographers Zhao Xiaoding and Stuart-Dryburg and the New Zealand-based Weta Workshop.
[The Founder] benefits from a stirring storyline and a first-rate ensemble.

The film's first hour is a misguided mess of montages and reams of exposition. The latter half, in which Cage and his band of mercenaries demonstrate their unwavering commitment to carnage, is marginally more tolerable.
Affleck balances the labyrinthine plot with pulse-quickening suspense and vivid production design.
As ponderous and cliché-ridden as its predecessors, [Blood Wars] is weighted down by an abundance of dull dialogue, tacky effects and murky cinematography.

Despite shoehorning into the narrative a shoplifting teenager (Danika Yarosh) who may or may not be our anti-hero's daughter, there is little attempt at development of characters or emotional relationships.
Of appeal to viewers of all ages, Sing is an apt way for fun-loving families to usher in the New Year.
The magnificence of the titular septet is barely discernible in this unwarranted update of the 1960 Western that was itself a remake of the 1954 Japanese classic Seven Samurai.
Simplistic to an extent, the good guys-versus-villainous 'others' narrative is further undermined by the occasional undercurrent of jingoism.
It's certainly smarter than the last few Bonds that have zipped in and out of the viewer's mind. The impact of this espionage adventure lasts after it has ended.

Drew Goddard, with assistance from his cohort scenarist Joss Whedon, achieves an exemplary fusion of horror, humour and science-fiction while undermining genre conventions and audience expectations alike.
Richly detailed, the dialogue-free adventure serves as a tribute to the visual ingenuity of silent cinema.
Should you choose to accept this Mission... be prepared for one helluva roller-coaster ride.
The Bat-brigade as well as Christopher Nolan zealots will doubtless go batty over The Dark Knight Rises.
It's a brain-bender, all right. One of the more audacious narrative experiments since his own Memento, writer-director Nolan's seventh feature is every bit as intelligent as it is gripping.
A fight with an assassin atop a speeding Japanese bullet train is guaranteed to leave the viewer giddy with excitement.

The smash-happy action is complemented by wondrous visuals and techno-chic production values. The climactic London-set battle royale, with Thor's magic mallet ever primed for slinging, holds the viewer in a vice-like grip.
Neither exhilarating nor entirely dismissible.
Infusing plenty of laconic wit into his role, Robert Downey Jr is impressive as ever.
At best, Edge of Tomorrow adds up to a videogame-compatible diversion.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The creature design and prosthetics are astonishing. Throughout, cutting-edge technology is employed with a great amount of gusto.
The special effects, especially the transformation of a pumpkin into the golden carriage, are uniformly impressive.
A film of visionary grandeur.
The performances by the fresh-faced newcomers are spot on.

The sequel lacks the consistent creative vision of the 2009 outing. Nevertheless, Star Trek Into Darkness should satisfy the hardcore Trekkers while reaching out to audiences unfamiliar with the [ series'] mythology.
Debutant writer-director Andrew Stanton, crams the feel-good fable with wondrous visuals while ensuring that the life lessons are schmaltz-free.

This crackerjack crime saga provides a peek into the workings of a mob-controlled Irish-American 'family' in South Boston during the 1970s and '80s. It also marks a welcome return to form for Johnny Depp after several disappointing performances.

The first collaboration between the veteran Oscar-winning filmmaker Barry Levinson and legendary comedian Bill Murray yields a leaden political satire that doesn't measure up to one's great expectations.
An intimate portrait of the fearless young advocate for women's education, He Named Me Malala is one of the significant films of the year.
Recommended whole-heartedly for those seeking visceral, pulp-'n'-gulp entertainment.

Take two heavyweight Hollywood stars, cast them in a shaggy-dog story set in Los Angeles circa 1977 and assign a writer-director with a proven flair for madcap action comedy. Voila! It's time to get acquainted with The Nice Guys.
Clearly aimed at a tween audience, this purported feline comedy is far from purr-fect.
Even the recurring passages of pin-drop silence generate edge-of-the-seat dread.
This empty-headed 'thriller' is tedious from the word go.
Ultimately, Deepwater Horizon serves both as a testament to their heroic sacrifice and a critique of the corporate greed that led to the unconscionable real-life tragedy.
Eastwood elicits Oscar-worthy performances from Hanks and Eckhart.
[An] underwhelming panel-to-screen Marvel adaptation.
This fishy tale may not be as lively as its popular predecessor. Still, Finding Dory strikes gold anew for a new generation of family filmgoers.

In the lead roles, both Fassbender and Cotillard fail to bring any sense of fun to the cheesy proceedings. Regrettably, redoubtable actors like Jeremy Irons, Brendan Gleeson and Charlotte Rampling are also given short shrift.
Much like the row of multi-coloured dominoes in the adman's office, Collateral Beauty topples under the weight of its pseudo-profundity.
The preposterous climax is merely a ploy to ensure a sequel -- a proposition that is scarier than anything else in Incarnate.
This film cements Villeneuve's reputation as one of the finest filmmakers of his time.
Escapist fare of the fast and furious kind, Jason Bourne will likely impress diehard fans of the long-running series. Others may prefer to have the invincible spook finally put out to pasture.
Brimming with gorgeous visuals, enchanting tunes and a captivating narrative, Moana chronicles the life-changing story of the eponymous South Pacific Islander.
This delightful extravaganza revives the big-screen musical -- and how.
The Babadook is a worthy addition to the psycho-horror genre.
Even the stubbly charisma and martial arts credentials of Statham can't deflect from the formulaic screenplay and cookie-cutter characterisations.
A curiously empty exercise in blockbuster filmmaking, Man Of Steel is full of sound and fury signifying... you know what.
At best, The Accountant may be worth checking out for its very personable ensemble. Led by the deceptively mild-mannered Ben Affleck, they elevate the film above the standard B-movie entertainment.

Unfortunately director Jordan Vogt-Roberts, making the leap to a big-budget blockbuster after his indie debut The Kings of Summer (2013), can't match the white-knuckle excitement of the iconic black-and-white original.
The screenplay abounds in droll dialogue and provides insider insight into Hollywood even lampooning people who work in show business.
Let's just get it out there: Hollywood has milked the stuck-in-a-time-loop premise for all it's worth.

Ferdinand may not measure up to the standards set by such recent animated blockbusters as Inside Out or Coco. Still, the beloved bedtime story provides sufficient entertainment for the young at heart.
None of the characters makes an impression; there's no on-screen chemistry even between the lovers. You can safely give this one a miss.
Daddy's Home 2 is as creatively bankrupt as the 2015 original.
Borg Vs McEnroe is an even-handed sports movie that merits a look-see.
Like its celebrated predecessor, All the President's Men, Mark Felt... is essential viewing.
movie_title: Mark Felt: The Man Who Brought Down the White House (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Instead of tension and thrills, there's just a bunch of clichés and an overwhelming sense of déjà vu.
As inspirational as it is heartfelt, Wonder will strike a chord with audiences of all ages.
What was supposed to be a superhero extravaganza from the DC universe feels instead like a sloppy remake of The Avengers.

It's sumptuously designed, has some catchy tunes and an A-list cast voicing anthropomorphic household appliances. Still, Disney's live-action remake of its 1991 animated feature is, by and large, underwhelming.
Clearly aiming to cash in on the (undeserved) success of last year's Bad Moms, this slapdash sequel is even more dispiriting.
A labour of love that has taken nearly seven years to finish, Loving Vincent raises the bar, and then some, for animation filmmakers.
Thor is a rousing example of how to refresh a comic-book franchise.
Blade Runner 2049 honours and even amplifies the vision of its predecessor.
Quite an airy romp, American Made is worth checking out.
Based on the comic book by Mark Millar and Dave Gibbons, there is an appropriately cartoony vibe to this follow-up flick.
All these years later, it still has the power to thrill.
The only thing that makes the film watchable at all is the supercharged performance by Michael Keaton in the role of trainer / mentor.
The Last Jedi is awe-inspiring and poignant. Expect to be riveted, despite its runtime of two-and-a-half hours.
An intermittently amusing fantasy...welcome to the Jungle will appeal primarily to adolescent viewers.
For a biopic that purports to celebrate humanity in all its diversity, The Greatest Showman is surprisingly flat.
The negotiations with the abductors are not always convincing, but the ticking-clock thriller elements are executed with flair.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The script is stodgy, the effects absurd. Saddled with shootouts, explosions, and stormy devastation, the film does little more than place cartoonish stereotypes in perilous situations.
The ensuing race-against-the-clock narrative is crammed with chases, stunts and cheesy effects, and totally devoid of intensity.
Lady Bird is one of the most affecting coming-of-age movies in recent memory.
The rest of the long-winded, twisty-turny narrative doesn't make a lick of sense. In place of tension or suspense, you have an amoral cat-and-mouse game played across several swish locations.
Rather than acting as social commentary, the remake merely exploits the overarching theme of crime and punishment to unleash more violence and death.
Satisfying from the first frame to the last, The Hurt Locker ranks among the most accomplished contemporary war films.
Car chases, shootouts and film references abound. In other words, there's scarcely anything original about the outlandish caper.
Martin McDonagh is undisputedly one of the finest scriptwriters in contemporary cinema.
Baadshaho has too many ordinarily written characters jostling for whistle-worthy one-liners for 136-minutes.
This wordless animated gem has finally made it to our shores, four years after its release internationally, and boy has it been worth the wait.
movie_title: Boy and the World (O Menino e o Mundo) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The final chapter in the trilogy is poorly written, predictable, devoid of suspense.
Day-Lewis burrows into his role with characteristic intensity. Manville is spot-on as the stern but sympathetic sibling. The accomplished Krieps gives an Oscar-worthy performance.

The ever-reliable Kristin Scott Thomas is the standout among the supporting cast, as Churchill's stoic wife. If only for Gary Oldman's Oscar-calibre performance, and hers, Darkest Hour merits a trip to the multiplex.
To be fair, some of the action scenes are photographed with genuine flair, but none of the actors make an impression.

The Hitchcockian stranger-on-a-train premise is squandered on lapses in logic and generic close-combat skirmishes. Slow-motion shots and endless tracking through the compartments further impede the flow of a deadly-dull narrative.
An evenhanded snapshot of the fractious relationship between a deceitful government and committed journalists, The Post is essential viewing.

Working from an audacious idea conceived by his long-time collaborator Jim Taylor, co-scenarist and director Alexander Payne (Nebraska) has pulled off one of the great cinematic accomplishments of the new millennium.
A rare sequel that lives up to (and even improves on) the original, Paddington 2 finds the beloved bear of children's literature off on another wondrous adventure.
A shoddy riff on Michael Mann's Heat, this misbegotten mess doesn't even bother to acknowledge the 1995 crime classic.
The climactic confrontation is long-drawn-out and merely serves to set the tone for the proposed Chapter Two. Here's hoping it takes another 27 years for It and the gang to creep back into cinemas.
The movie is clearly aimed at kindergartners (who may be frightened by some of the violent images); accompanying adults, expect to be left squirming in your seats.
[Dark Tower] has a hackneyed plot that never really hits its stride.
From its deceptively gentle prelude to the majestic, Wagnerian finale, [Alien: Covenant] infuses the long-running series with a new lease on life.
More outlandish and much less successful than several previous incarnations of the Arthurian legend, Guy Ritchie's reimagining is full of sound and fury, signifying, well, nothing.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Overall, though, Vol 2 suffers from blockbuster bloat. Hopefully the next installment, hinted at plentifully in the end credits, will recapture the fun-fuelled zing of the original.

movie_review_blurb: What the film doesn't misrepresent, it trivialises.
Talitha Bateman is effective as the possessed, polio-afflicted orphan, but the rest of the performances are uniformly forgettable. As, indeed, is Annabelle: Creation.

movie_review_blurb: Nolan deserves to be commended for his superior craftsmanship. Ultimately, however, Dunkirk falls way short of such contemporary genre classics as The Big Red One, The Thin Red Line or Steven Spielberg's Saving Private Ryan.

movie_review_blurb: The utterly incomprehensible plot of The Last Knight revives the old fracas between nice CGI metal machines and their nasty counterparts. As in the previous iterations, the fate of Earth is at stake, not to mention the viewer's eyes, ears and sanity.
Heartwarming, compassionate and wholly human, The Big Sick is highly recommended.

An utter waste of production resources as well as viewers' time and money.
Smart, funny and tremendously exciting.
One of the most stylish extravaganzas in years.

movie_review_blurb: The Lost City of Z is a stimulating reconstruction of one man's quest, over decades, for a vanished South American civilisation.

The language is magnificent. As delivered by Samuel L. Jackson, it's one of that great voice's greatest performances.

Maren Ade's third feature... is bittersweet and berserk, realist yet surrealist, which, once you've absorbed the particulars of the premise, has as many indelible laughs as any movie released in recent months.
Matthew McConaughey Matthew-McConaugheys the ---- out in Stephen Gaghan's strange but still insufficiently weird satire of the American fantasy of having a great fortune land in your lap.

A sly delight, a superbly crafted satire of mercantile, opportunist entrepreneurship, and with it, how the flow of commerce in the United States was compromised in service to scale since the 1950s. Michael Keaton is fully invested in his dynamic star turn
Wildness and comfort alternate to touching effect.
The 1980s passages are the brightest and boldest (shot by Isabel Coixet's cinematographer Jean-Claude Larrieu) filled with gentle hope and boundless potential. But secrets, as always, sear.

Can we speak of an "art-house programmer" in 2017 and not be entirely dismissive about it? Something that looks good, moves well across a large screen, rather than coming to your awareness as a "Recommended For You" icon?
Celia Rowlson-Hall makes her minimalist widescreen feature debut with the limber, challenging delirium of Ma.

Bugsy Malone... but without the bubble guns... Affleck tippy-toes to reach the top shelf where classic movie epics are kept but comes up with only "Once Upon A Time in Hahvad Yahd." (Or just maybe, "The Hatman.")
The few visual flourishes startle: most of the style is stripped, simplified, distilled in the contents of frames, in the duration of shots.
The dreamy, joyous The Fits is elegance and simplicity supreme.
Larraín's play with time and performance is largely hypnotic, down to an exemplary ending within mythic landscape.

With fleet features and darting eyes, Auteuil always excels at indicating fear, at capturing the quicksilver of thought. He applies those skills to wide-ranging use as events, and years, flicker past.
movie_title: In Her Name (Au nom de ma fille) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The triangle that ensues is voraciously sexual, unabashedly fetishistic. And the crosses, and the double-crosses, and the twists-within-twists are almost as carnal in their voluptuousness.

A superhero in his ability to be in every single location that matters... A teenage boy's savior fantasy: if only I am always in the right place at the right time, I will be the greatest hero my friends and family and my town has ever known!

The interviews with street artists about the ethics of making art and taking art become the true subject... and a small, spirited conversation with graffiti artists and other passionate voices. The museum curators on view, not so much.

Dialogue-free, "The Red Turtle" begins at simplicity, then accumulates the most delicate of emotions in one compelling scene after another... superlative visual storytelling. The existential allegories? They'll take care of themselves.

The violence escalates: alongside the filmmakers' insistent world building, every splay of limb and brandish of weapon is acrobatic and emblematic, "gun-fu," as the makers jokingly dubbed their masterful centripetal urgency.

The range of physical acting that Léaud accomplishes beneath teeming, toppling royal perukes-powdered wigs-is both minimal and maximal, body laid out, papery eyelids aflutter... the dead weight of our memories of Léaud's long onscreen life-on-the-run...
movie_title: The Death of Louis XIV (La mort de Louis XIV) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: We witness these girls, offhanded, in the moment of becoming women, in an alienated yet hyper-connected culture, stubborn against a succession of sensations in a sea of Instagrams, of societal expectations. [A] brief but compelling dispatch.
[B]odies are bent, not broken. The results are resilient, ravishing, resounding.
movie_title: Mr. Gaga: A True Story of Love and Dance (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Starting in Argentina, ranging to Mozambique and the Philippines, The Human Surge picks figures from the blur of the modern world and depicts them in shadowed motion, language an indistinct gesture, too.
movie_title: The Human Surge (El auge del humano) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Bland runner: Crime and passion play out in dank, close backstreets redolent of rust, verdant with verdigris, with chains clanking and hoists at the ready around most corners, still black water underfoot, kindly stray dogs on the loose.

The images come quickly if not furiously, the camera mesmerized by imagery high and low, a succession of jagged-around-the-edges Terrence Malick-type tableaux. The men's stories sear with the force of troubled lives lived rough.
Raw's errant psychology is apt, acts and reactions escalate with finely-stitched logic, and, as in the best work of David Cronenberg, we simultaneously witness ruin and flowering transformation.

Kaiju a-go-go: Hyper-scaled B movie set in 1973, in the waning days of U. S. days in the Vietnam War, that appropriates the DNA of dozens of other movies for a crisp burst of grandiosely-scaled goofiness.

Zhao's images are freighted with beauty as well as the weight of ravaging, of man and landscape: the cumulative effect is harshly political, rising to the spoiled grandeur of the earth surfaces of Canadian photographer Edward Burtynsky.

More than a plot's complications, his characters are complex, almost as if the result of inspired anthropological study. Telling details... add to Barras' assured telling in his brief, lovely film. Families, sometimes, form themselves.
movie_title: My Life as a Zucchini (Ma vie de courgette) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Turkish B-movie The Ottoman Lieutenant, veteran director Joseph Ruben's third directorial credit this century, is impure bunkum, a jumbled gloss of romance-novel grade set at the onset of the Turkish Armenian genocide.
Logan's superb depiction of sorrow, of deadening dejection, of the awareness of mortality on multiple planes, rises far above Mangold's ready embrace of influence.
Onur Tukel's proudly ragged, black-and-black comedies lean gleefully toward interpersonal savageries, and the compelling fisticuffs of the presciently Trumpian Catfight ... is no exception

A refined suspense thriller, consummate film critique, savage satire, inspired horror and fierce, profane comedy. It's archetypal, prodigious American moviemaking, smart and sly... a succession of shocking, often thrilling satisfactions.
The abstracted events transpire, occur, invoke, weighted neither by plot nor a psychological accounting: an atmospheric dream of everyday things, a dark dream of all our todays, lustrous dread.
Imagine your favorite online cat video, multiply by hundreds... a ravishing beauty.
The romcom will never die as long as comic innovators find new veins to drain, and as long as the profane imagination of someone like Headland is so capably and entertainingly unleashed.
In punchy journalistic fashion and through elegant, combustible aerial imagery, Kennebeck captures a range of collateral damage in other countries and back home.
A grand adventure told on an intimate scale, with an exemplary heroine, illustrated in slabs and slashes of color with dynamic simplicity, Chayé's feature debut is a memorable journey.
movie_title: Long Way North (Tout en haut du monde) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Nutty gags-a couple Terry Gilliam-worthy-and crisp comic timing allow the boisterous tone to rise above the machinations of a busy plot.
movie_title: The Brand New Testament (Le tout nouveau testament) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Dazed yet undaunted, grief-stricken but determined, genteel yet steely, Jackie is the role Natalie Portman was born to embody, swaddled in a brilliant skin of a score by Mica Levi.

Elemental yet expressionistic, Tower is an admirable attainment, a broadside from the solar plexus, and the powerhouse ending, partially narrated by Walter Cronkite commenting in the day, is magnificent. So much tenderness! So much humanity.

Alarmingly sensuous thriller. Her attention to sound is gripping, nailing the narrative to Vincent's point-of-view, the audience sharing his hyper-attentive subjectivity. The surfaces are chaotic and subterfuges compound.
At times, Beauty and the Beast seems more like a demented Asian movie than a French one, to its merit. A quantifiably bad movie, but also certifiably grandiose.
movie_title: Beauty And The Beast (La belle et la bête) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Consider the thin and thick wallops of blue... Blue, blue, electric blue. Lazy blue. Electrified blue. Wash of water. Ice-blue buzz of fluorescence. Azul, azure, lapis lazuli, teal, turquoise, sea, seafoam, sky, cerulean, cobalt...

Yes, there is quiet, but there is calm within moments of stress and strain and trying just to keep it together through the day in a rural world where you still have to deal with other people... It all flows like cool, clear water.
We watch the visions of her imagination, from dragons in the sky, on down, transformed into art.

singularly lived-in and reflected-upon essay film draws upon her 25-year career as one of the major forces in American documentary. From shot to shot... one of the most engrossing and inventive movies of the year, if not one of the year's greatest.
As in the best genre films, larger truths and topical awareness are introduced as primal fears are stoked in Cuarón's admirably harsh, bloody, unsentimental exploitation thriller.

The lovely, loving craft extends to gentle, haunting sound design: these worlds are both concrete and dreamy in Tseden's eye, geometrically exquisite yet filled with implications of wandering and wonder.

The Last Film Festival runs ninety minutes. I wish I had run in the opposite direction with unseemly haste. (It bears no relationship to Hopper's fascinating excursion into the jungle, The Last Movie.)
Morbid, apocalyptic yet enthralling.

Often less than compelling, lumbering even... In the small details, the huge determination, the teeming world of the canvases, the machinations of "CSI: Den Bosch" melt away, all the tidy journalism is immaterial, the up-close examination... transfixes.
movie_title: Hieronymus Bosch, Touched by the Devil (Jheronimus Bosch, Touched By The Devil) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Sturdy, pleasingly unpleasant horror thriller.
Shocking but straightforward chiller.

illo Pontecorvo's fictional documentary classic of the mechanics of terrorism and counterterrorism is a tense, crack thriller and one of the greatest films to draw a portrait of both sides of urban conflict.
movie_title: The Battle of Algiers (La Battaglia di Algeri) (1967)

movie_review_blurb: Heidi Brandenburg and Mathew Orzel's crisp, brisk When Two Worlds Collide captures the 2009 confrontation between Peru's president Alan Garcia, hailing from the elites, and indigenous activists who intend to preserve their Amazonian rainforest hom
Despite errors made, the film's embrace of sexual agency is well, bracing. The memorable ending justifies nearly everything that came before. Contains graphic sex, degradation and sexual violence.
Cinematographer Simon Niblett captures vital beauty with exceptional vigor, not limited to a rash of scenes captured through drone technology.

Gravity, logic, physics, the deaths of major characters, their ready resurrection, nothing can stop the middling geniality of the "family" of characters led by Dom Toretto in "Mission: Implausible"-style adventures around the planet.
[The] most inspired moments earn respect as well as genuine dread, working in ordinary settings with extraordinary creepiness. And the climatic cruelty is sweetly punishing payoff.
Powerful accomplishment, capturing in under two hours a comprehensive sense of the work the poet, author and activist made, and the life she lived fully in her eighty-six years.
movie_title: Maya Angelou: And Still I Rise (2016)

movie_review_blurb: This romance of language is hyper-heightened intellectual discourse... but also supple and seductive. Often static, the images nonetheless glow from within, lustrous, in love with the speaker, more in love with the listener, face turned this way or that.
movie_title: The Academy of Muses (La academia de las musas) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Rosi moves in and out of stories. The pastoral life of the island is apart from the humanity crashing to the shore. The images he finds are bold, from the gentle to the dire. [H]ope is in limited supply,contrasting with the seawater that seems limitless.
Nothing in Don't Call Me Son is everyday, and yet everything is presented as such: that's the beauty of Muylaert's contemplation, her embrace of the power of suggestion.
movie_title: Don't Call Me Son (Mãe Só Há Uma) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Thought in action, ideas in motion and also the portrayal of a slippery, frightening slide down a rabbit hole of hurt... The story is what is true and what is false, and it's all true and it's all false... Ghosts. Ghosts everywhere.

The casually bravura action scenes, generous with vehicle-on-vehicle action, are punchy and kinetic, far more engrossing than the thriller plotting. Lam's knack for filling the widescreen frame with eye candy is as sturdy as ever.
The unraveling of sparring personalities comes quickly, but there are other games left for Takal to exact, with cool precision and blessed confidence as things go formally berserk.

There's a screwball complication that draws out the class differences between the boys, but their hate-love bonding comes from beating each other up, a two-boy fight club... The brute mix of emotion and sensation suits the confusion of their age.
Ahn and cinematographer Ki Jin Kim work with levels of color and quiet stylization that gently nudge the film into sweet moments of cinematic subjectivity.

An approach that once seemed like contrived creature wrangling and anthropomorphizing voyeurism looks sleek, sometimes majestic, smack in the center of the age of "cute overload" Twitter and "Bodega Cats Of Instagram."

Brightly colored, boldly played, serves up inspired gags at the most unexpected moments alongside course after course of exquisite culinary joy. And even more toothsomely, food and ----ing are intricately aligned.

Anna Biller's blissfully strange widescreen appropriation of the trappings of sexploitation, horror and high art, is a rubicund marvel, and a deadpan madhouse comedy... Biller's movie isn't beholden to influence, it's its own wild creature.

movie_title: The Tenth Man (El rey del Once) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A jittery delight, an anxious, hyper-verbal, edge-of-panic coming-of-age comedy about small social fissures that abruptly erupt into emotional struggle... Steinfeld's poised intelligence is matched by a gift for comic alarm.

[A]ssured, savage comedy and it is shocking and thrilling and oh so funny... The reversals, the revelations of character, the implications of behavior, and yes, the level of behavioral authenticity, surprise again and again.

Rebecca Hall plays the twenty-nine-year-old career woman, and her performance is akin to what Campos does as a filmmaker, filled with fierce concentration, ambitious and scatty, present yet plainly preoccupied.
A piercing, panoramic look at the federal government's purposeful yet potentially cataclysmic militarization of local police departments.

"I don't wanna belong to the glam people. I don't wanna belong to the hip-hop people, I don't wanna belong to any of it, I don't wanna belong to the TV people, alternative people, none of it, I don't wanna be a punk, I just wanna be."

Fine, impressionistic portrait of a lion in winter, one of the greatest living photographer-filmmakers still at work, still undaunted at 91 by his choice-or lack of choice?-to face life head-on and portray... unstintingly stark, rough-hewn beauty.
It all so sounds dead serious and yet Colossal is bristling, deliriously serious, explosively funny, and rich with wicked suggestiveness at every burn.

As parables about fundamentalism go, The Student is bold and compelling... Tall, with the brooding, intent looks of a teen Michael Shannon, Petr Skvortsov is a superb incarnation of both zealot and charlatan,

Lady Bird hits the mark of the American teen movie while quietly reaching toward literary effect [including] a set of sequences of driving in Sacramento [that] fall into place with the weight of a two-story house.

The most pungent result of Scott's redrafting.... the summoning of a magnificent performance by Christopher Plummer, central in its sour power. From ham to brine: Plummer gives a performance hailed from failing flesh and eternal brimstone.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Another manic mother comes forward in Allison Janney's charismatically assured, unsentimentally sewer-mouthed mom to Margot Robbie's gloriously vivid Tonya Harding in Craig Gillespie's brutal, funny, biting, cutting, kicking, snarling I, Tonya.
Unadorned, urgent, [and] troublingly intimate.
There's not so much story, but there's so much dread.

Hope for generational change, the power of any single, small, nameless dreamer, who may yet know a world not manipulated by gunrunners, moneychangers, the venal and power-mad. Forces against The Force. The sky is filled with more stars than we know.

Karukoski's scenes often have a smoky, sweaty reek that would have amused the late Rainer Werner Fassbinder, a titan of tang himself... The tensile central performance by Pekka Strang is adroit at capturing the complicated man.

Allegory for the politics of the modern moment careen beneath nearly every complication, and yet del Toro keeps to the business of his lovingly designed sea of surfaces and... a single, singular theme throughout: loneliness.

A grandiloquent compatriot to their later masterpiece, Geronimo... More exuberantly stylized than The Warriors, it seemingly stands in stark relief to the carborundum asperity of movies like Hard Times and The Driver...
Jokes. So many jokes. Attitude. So much attitude. Snark? Bring on the Goldblum! Sexual ambiguity? Yes, oh my. Action scenes? ... Action scenes? Jokes! More jokes!

Texan Woody Harrelson of the fleet, trickster countenance is mudbound by his layers of facial appliances, nearly as dense, certainly as confining, as the cheeks of the Lady in the Radiator in Eraserhead .
Working with and against genre conventions, Melville's movies are hushed, deadpan abstractions of space and gesture, restrained, refined, a palette reduced to essential colors and compositions.
Sean Baker's effortlessly headlong dive into a child's imagination is a tender thunderclap... generous, grand, gorgeous... ground-level magic.

A small, lovely treasure, a biographical love letter to the great American actor Harry Dean Stanton... It's also a documentary of Harry Dean's haunted eyes and lived-in face and elder body... funny and philosophical, punchily short.

Brute beauty... quietly savage 1975 x-ray of the exploitation of a simple man... startles with its dense, concrete tapestry of trashy fairgrounds and garishly tasteless apartments and bolthole gay bars and swimming pools and horrifying exploitation.

Nimble Brit director Joe Wright arrives again; it seems like he's always arriving every couple of years, every other film announcing himself as a bold maker of thumping entertainments, who alternates precise, startling work with fancies that fail.

Inquisitive press pitted against an overreaching executive branch with present-day concerns... banter and grown-up turns akin to the best of the late Nora Ephron. The details of a 1970s newsroom and pressroom are elemental tactile poetry.

Since encountering "Code Unknown" blind around the turn of the century, I've always admired the finery of Haneke's work, which in other hands could doodle into curdled misanthropy or haphazard hauteur, but instead pulses with his serene disapproval.

Renoir's happy, goofy, giddy, and, yes, awe-inspiring [comedy] is a timeless marvel. The only good reason this warm, rollicking, political and politically sophisticated comedy is [lesser-known] is that it's been out of circulation for years.
movie_title: The Crime of Monsieur Lange (Le Crime de Monsieur Lange) (1936)

movie_review_blurb: I don't know your mom, but she might like this.

A return to form... where large men scream very loudly and jokes are pounded into the ground with vigor and brio. Goodman's Walter is a bullet-headed, barely contained titan of rage, running on the fumes of cracked beliefs and fierce garble-gabble.

Fire, fury, frenzy, fraternity. Salles' narration remains deeply personal even as the kaleidoscopic imagery bursts forth in grandiloquent poetry. Cataclysm awaits. So much history ahead. Such dense, ordered beauty behind.
movie_title: In the Intense Now (No Intenso Agora) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Werewolf is a wowser.

See me for myself; see me as I see myself. See me as I shall become. (The bold, bright flights of fancy are splendid and necessary.)

Katja meets obstacle after obstacle, which forces the story onto her leather-clad shoulders, her wrought features. Blood and tears and ink and unspoken, perhaps unspeakable fear and anger: this is a fantastically physicalized performance.
Every composition, each image of her epic endeavor, especially in close-ups, comprise sensual, atmospheric marvels.

Furiously inventive, overlong, overwrought, battering, mesmerizing, magical. From an outsider's perspective, the massive project of Kusturica's convulsive carnivalesque celebrates the vivacity of the survivor. (His countrymen may know better.)
Kiarostami's elemental evanescence is a precise but also aleatory stroll through the field of his vision, and all twenty-four of these fragments. The final shot is a glorious, frame-filled eternity.
Politically incendiary, emotionally incandescent.

The coruscating critique of the pathetic male is thick with predecessors... Jake possesses not a shred of discernible talent, poetry, wit or virtue. Simply, it's an apt, savage take on the fugly American.
From A-line to eyeline, Anderson's serenely sensual sub-dom stare-down rom-com set in another, ostensibly more romantic era, is generous, wicked and tailored with surprise after surprise.

Glimpses of the self-described "cobbler" to the world of fashion and hundred-thousandaires everywhere, Manolo Blahnik, working at designs at home or on the factory floor are the liveliest moments of the diverting process-and-praise documentary.
movie_title: Manolo, The Boy Who Made Shoes For Lizards (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Once more, with feeling: "God? It's me, Darren." Each strand of madness is there to be relished, even if it will make some viewers seethe.
What an obscenity. Call it "The Bourne Abortion."

The auteur excavates, and the connections made are blissful in their rangy strangeness... washes over the brain like cool, cool history: an intricate singularity and a cinematic gold rush... Miss this cockamamie bliss, this onrushing marvel, at your risk.
An overstuffed, genre-leaping monstrosity that has great ambition and very little taste, most of it p----poor.

James excels at drawing out the dynamics of extended families under stress and Abacus is no exception.

Most political in its insistence that the smallest "I" matters, but as at his best, like his 1990s work... Loach's film is about empathy, a portrait of ordinary people, blunt, bracing yet loving and far, far from mere polemic.

I've got no subtweet with Wonder Woman, ninety percent of its running time being nothing less than sharp moviemaking. Yet the true and lasting fun will be to witness its eddying cultural influence upon younger generation
Yet another incarnation, yet another murmuring of a movie that once seen, will be dreamt again and again.

Exquisitely measured portrait of the waning days of the prolific poet Emily Dickinson, unrecognized in her time, bearing afflictions, immersing herself in family... a muted yet wry portrait of a very shy person making the most of her 19th-century life.
Beyond the narrative's inexorably destructive unfolding, the brilliant, thrilling ending of The Wall has brute conviction and chilly logic that befits a reported $3 million budget.
Multiple passages stitched from a succession of still photographs with readings of Coltrane's words in Denzel Washington's recognizable voice make for deadly viewing.
movie_title: Chasing Trane: The John Coltrane Documentary (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Chockful with the fall and rise of prototypical high-schooler conflicts and catastrophes, John Hughes on a variety of hallucinogens and pharma, but the tastily strange filmmaking is about handmade apocalyptic velocity and explosive score-settling.
movie_title: My Entire High School Sinking Into the Sea (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Gere's genial sleekness placed against Coogan's consternation and growing agitation... Coogan trembles with... resentment, a barely-stemmed incendiary force. These are terrible people; Moverman hopes to demonstrate why. Coogan and Gere deliver.

Part meditation on modern means of contact, part elusive ghost story... the signification of class and fashion and the fate of effortless style, a girlish clumsiness transformed in each awkward action and tensile interaction as elemental fierce presence.
Dreamy, elusive, even spectral spectacle of lives haunted by what jungle exploration could reveal about man and civilization.

The theatrical version is some kind of compacted masterpiece, hormonal, vital, dazed, blissfully unhinged... I'm too attached to Donnie Darko to worry over its wanton weirdness, its mix of concreteness and intangibility.

Tenaglia keeps pretension largely at bay, with reenactments of Tower's childhood the only annoying element. Interviews with Mario Batali, Wolfgang Puck, Ruth Reichl and Martha Stewart are spunky, and archival footage from kitchens past is intoxicating.

Classically well-shaped and captivating in its small, well-observed gestures of behavior and of color and shape which pour from her patients' subconscious.

Modest tonic, a bright and agreeable musical drawing on the boldly colored palette of countryman Jacques Demy and American filmmakers like Stanley Donen.
Narcotically propulsive... a 1970s New York City motion picture in style and energy... Action is character. Energy is unstable. Chronic energy confined is a dangerous force.

Theron is perennially present, sullen sculpture. No need for backstory, no need for maudlin sentiment. There are a couple of love scenes with a French spy that impress... understated and discomfortingly erotic. Present; tense.

Elegance of nightmare, essence of terror. We are catapulted to war, in three interleaving but sometimes indistinct timeframes: a week, a day, an hour. Time collapses. There is the presence of fright, the adrenalized now.
A wounded, wondrous poem of a picture about many things, not limited to the needfulness of coupledom, loss, lingering, the parsing of love, the passing of language.
Hints at cultural relevance-a madman must build at wall at all costs to keep other humans out-however well-intentioned as commentary blurt like sound cannons.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's a Sofia Coppola film through and through, hushed, decorous, communicating through the placement of furnishings and the rustle of costumes and exchanged glances as much as by the minimal complications of plot.
