A gripping thriller, this one is bold, audacious and shocking.

What do you do if you're a young parent and need about an hour and a half to entertain your little one with a cute animated flick that's neither too long nor too short in duration? Storks comes to the rescue!
Essentially, this is everything - absolutely typical and more - that you'd expect from a Tim Burton-helmed film.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Phil Claydon has already made a name for himself in US TV and now, he has outdone himself here.
Bold, audacious and shocking, a consummate piece of work.
Don't miss this one. And stay for the end credits.
Do not miss this one.

Despite the staid title like 'mechanic' and a plot line that is as simple as can be, Statham pulls punches - literally - like we haven't seen in any action film this year. Okay, to be fair, at least not yet.
A few logical fallacies aside, this one's really enjoyable.
A breath of fresh air in the world of animated films.

A hugely impressive and entertaining story of arguably the most powerful character in the superhero pantheon (and also one of the biggest pop culture icons), it's clear that the Man of Steel is here to stay.
The film will grab you from the opening shot and not let go.
There is darkness, there is depth, but the important thing is that the element of fun is also most definitely present.
Delightfully quaint and definitely entertaining.
An artillery barrage of action.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: This one's both intelligent and endearing.
You might just feel like treating yourself to a delicious meal after watching this.
If you like stories about complicated relationships, this might be the ticket for you.
While HT 2 is all about feelgood emotions, there are some interesting edges to it.
This is definitely a gripping tale that's worth watching.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The film's only plus points are a few jump scares, slickness and the scenic great outdoors, where it was shot. Apart from that, there's little else to recommend.
As far as performances go, Roberts and Kidman are definitely on point.
Saddle up for a thrilling ride with this modern-day Western packed with action.
The special effects are noteworthy and then of course, there are Vin Diesel's heroics.
While the film's basic premise is unusual and in parts interesting, it loses steam in the second half.
What is immediately striking about this movie is the immaculate camerawork, framing and detailing.
The scares only happen at the very end. All in all, Ghost Dimension does not really deliver the excitement that horror film fans seek.
Even though a lengthy two hours, the narrative skips along rather nicely. Fans of the series are sure to like it.
Although a slightly over-dramatic ending holds the film back from greater heights, this is on the whole, quite enjoyable for kids as well as adults.
The rendering of the animation itself is decent, without being over-saturated. Fun fare for kids.
Sicario is heavy on action and gritty realism. This is without a doubt, one of the best movies out this year.

Working in this film's favor is the aforementioned brisk pace and the taut editing. It somehow adds to the sense of desperation and urgency that the lead pair feels. Overall, a passable action potboiler.
Eye In The Sky hits the bulls eye.
In an age where even animated flicks are designed for consumption for the junior and senior of our species, this film somehow manages to take the intelligence of children for granted.
While the underlying concept of the series is the examination of a big social experiment, this gets lost in the film. Extremely lackluster fare, overall.
More than anything, the intricate landscaping, masterful camerawork and environment (actually filmed in Downtown Los Angeles) create a delightfully immersive experience. Heartwarming and enjoyable.
Plenty of metaphors - some unnecessary - but decent fare, on the whole.
What we get here is a thin stew instead of a hearty brew.
In ping-ponging in between the sibling rivalry and the love story, the narrative fails to get too deep into either track.

The period detailing - be it a rustic locale or sophisticated surroundings - is quite superb. Brown also tries to give the story an emotional touch, to good effect. And in fact, it is this which makes this film both enjoyable and gripping.
It's a tad unfortunate to see Aniston hamming it up to the high heavens, doing what she has been doing in rom-coms since, well, forever.

The camerawork perfectly captures their closed surroundings, with tight angles, thereby accentuating dramatic tension. Winstead's performance is also amazing, evoking both empathy and intensity with equal ease. Don't miss this gem of a thriller.

Okay, Collet-Serra has taken a few liberties (read: many gratuitous close-ups of Lively's pert posterior) here but all said and done, this is without a doubt the actress' most daring and challenging role to date. Blake Lively, take a bow. You rock.
As an ensemble comedy, it somewhat works. But the jokes could have been more in number. Pass the spanakopita, please.
It is more than just a hostage-crisis film. It tries hard to make you think about the bigger picture, and mostly succeeds.

Sure, there is a fair bit of violence. And yes, it might seem needlessly gratuitous at times but you can let that slip as you've probably not seen Costner in this challenging a role (for him at least) in quite a while.

Collision Course is a relentless, fun-filled, fast-paced and most recent part in a long-running series that is pretty much sure to keep the kids (the audience for this movie) entertained with its energy.
It is refreshing to see something chillingly different in this genre.

The film does ... drag a bit towards the conclusion and it may seem too loud at times. Ghostbusters also takes a clear potshot at sexism in general, but by and large, it delivers a decent amount of fun.
Bad Moms sometimes falters when attempts at mushy sentimentality are made. That being said, as a buddy flick, it delivers the goods, with a good amount of laugh-out-loud moments too.

Morgan Freeman's character - a shrewd but honest merchant who cannot resist a good bet - is sagely wise enough, and he carries it off with effortless ease. All in all, justice has been done to this tale of epic scale.
There's a generous dose of fiction thrown in but for the most part, ​​War Dogs serves up some pretty kick ass entertainment.
There is humour, there is fun and Nine Lives is honestly, quite enjoyable. It will put a smile on your face.
It's fantastic. Go watch it.
If you like Jackie Chan's brand of cinema, make no mistake; you will enjoy this.
Hanks is fantastic as Sully. In fact, this is a fantastic film. Go watch it.
The good points outweigh the bad, and if you're a football fan, you'll realize why football's 'the beautiful game' description came to be associated with Pele.
An interesting tale of tragedy and survival.
The film simmers but never really sizzles.
You'll watch it for De Niro and Hathaway's easy onscreen chemistry.
Those familiar with the various seasons of the show will find all of what they see to be reassuringly familiar and fun.

Despite the very predictable way the movie moves along, the message here is simple, well-known and comfortingly reassuring -- that if someone loves you, they will do so because of who you really are on the inside.
The effects are superb, the action is supersized and ultimately, if there is just one word that can describe this movie, that word would be 'awesome'.
Apart from the humour, there are some rather poignant and moving scenes as well.
movie_title: What We Did on Our Holiday (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Unusual and engaging.
The sets look like budget Lord of the Rings and the script isn't really much to write home about.
Kingsman: The Secret Service is a breath of fresh air in the spy movie genre.
It is chiefly the chemistry between the lead pair that makes this movie quite enjoyable.

We've seen Neeson play a tough-as-nails retired cop/hitman/special forces person who rescues various members of his family/public, who also finds his own redemption in the process, for a while now. But... he's perfected it.
Lazarus gets sloppy in a hurry.
Chappie is slightly bonkers, but delightfully so.
Thankfully though, there is enough originality in here to please hardcore sci-fi fans.
Spy manages to combine humour and intelligence into one really entertaining package.
Most surprisingly, Maggie sees a rather interesting change of pace for Arnold Schwarzenegger, who pulls off playing a caring, sensitive character pretty well indeed.
Suitably creepy.
If you want your big screen thrill ride this summer, this might just be the ticket.
In undoubtedly his best performance in years, Al Pacino has taken this story and elevated it to a whole different level altogether.
If there are two words that best describe this often surreal serving of a movie, those would be "playfully deranged."
movie_title: The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Hot Pursuit is a film that takes the whole buddy-movie formula and gives it a wild, sometimes boisterous and genuinely funny female spin.
The casting is spot-on.
Crowe's undeniable screen presence adds gravity to the film and he manages to make you empathize with his grief and the doggedness of his search.
The overriding message of Broken Horses is, of course, one of brotherly love and the fact that although circumstances might change, some bonds remain unbroken.
You'll only want to see this is if the sound of gunfire is music to your ears.

The touching tribute to Walker puts the entire series into perspective and will make many eyes teary. The film's flaws suddenly vanish when you realise that if there is another film in this series, it just wouldn't be the same.
Home is meant squarely for kids, but that doesn't mean that accompanying adults will also not find this multi-coloured tale of the importance of friendship and familial bonds, heartwarming.
The Program can be viewed as especially relevant, given that doping in sport is coincidentally, in the news again.

There's plenty for kids to enjoy -- laser guns, jet packs, space ships and plenty of tricks to fire a fertile imagination. At the same time, it also manages to mix in a message about environmentalism and cautious idealism regarding the future.
What we do get is a revealing and no-holds-barred look at life behind the Iron Curtain. It busts the myth that the Russians, during the Cold war era, were emotionless propaganda machines.
Really clever stuff.
The film is high on ominousness, especially those dark atmospherics when Elise slips into the 'Further', a place fraught with danger.
Watch it for Johnny Depp and Joel Edgerton's masterful performances.
A little grittiness interspersed with the neon party lights and techno flash would've made things more interesting.
This U.N.C.L.E is effortlessly cool.
The action is slick and indeed, very stylish.
By the end of the film, you might find yourself wondering if Streep (she plays and sings for real here) really is in a rock n' roll band on the side. Yes, she's that convincing.
While [Skrein's] efforts are sincere, he's not as effective as Statham.
There are barely any action scenes in the film, save the film's climax, which looks rushed.
You get the feeling that you're in for a treat right from the first few frames of The Gift.
This version spares nothing when it comes to bawdiness and potty humour that can either hugely tickle your funny bone, or put you off, if naughty jokes don't float your boat.
All in all, fun viewing for kids.
We get an idea of the kind of limits Tom Cruise will go to, in order to entertain his fans, almost as soon as the movie begins.
Sandler unfortunately brings nothing new to the table.
While there are a few appropriately scary scenes, the overall feeling is that Neveldine could have served up a far more terrifying film if he'd pushed the envelope more.
Rudd's Lang is refreshingly self-effacing and charming. Pena is flat-out hilarious.

There are superhero movies with better gags and then there are superhero films with more effects. Eschewing any of those in excess, what this film also offers is soul, pathos and a pretty good look at the multifaceted character that is The Wolverine.
Big Hero 6 also provides many moments of genuine sweetness.
The effects are amazing but the best moments are when Thor and Loki share screen space.
The action sequences are breathtaking and despite the running time, the film doesn't drag. Garfield and Stone, in the scenes where they are together, have a palpable chemistry.
For a complex plot with so many characters, the movie is surprisingly easy to follow because of the cogent and clever distinctions made between front-line and secondary plots and characters.
There's a chance you might, at night, catch yourself looking over your shoulder more than once after watching this.
Some [found footage horror films] work, some don't. The Gallows lies somewhere in between.
If you're a fan of her music, you wouldn't want to miss this.
A heck of an intergalactic romp.
Quite a fun ride.
More than anything, you'll watch it for Arnold.
By and large, PP2 is a fun film with its best moments being of the musical variety.

Sakurazaka's story has solid sci-fi credentials and Cruise proves that he still has the chops to pull off mega action movies. Edge of Tomorrow is one of his most compelling and nuanced performances in this genre.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Essaying a complex character like Fischer isn't easy, but Maguire does a pretty admirable job of it.

While Sudeikis and James comprise the athletics angle of the film, Irons owns the behind-the-scenes part that deals with the bureaucracy. Ultimately though, what comes clearly through is that this is a really inspirational story.
The film is essentially a far-fetched, sometimes muddled, cautionary tale about mankind being taken over by the machines that they themselves have created, albeit with the best of intentions.

Expect every action film cliche to be thrown in. Also, you might wonder what the heck Gerard Butler is doing with his career. But that said, it is clear that he knows his niche. Clearly, this one's for die hard Butler fans.
Although light on plot and performances, the film delivers exactly what it promises.
The song sequences are both fun and wacky -- two words that sum up this film.
Schwarzenegger fans will enjoy this action fest, as this is undoubtedly his vehicle all the way.

Although Aronofsky has dipped liberally into the well of fantasy in his recreation of Noah's tale, he does it in a manner that serves up a quasi-modern story laced generously with allegory and backed by some solid, no-nonsense performances.
Rogers might not have Batman's toys, Tony Stark's wisecracks or Superman's strength, but he is the most 'human'. This ranks among the finest in the superhero genre.
At the heart of this dystopian tale awash in grays and browns is a lesson about finding one's identity and being at peace with oneself.
Colourful and well-paced except for a cloyingly sweet song or two, the kids will enjoy this one.
All in all, it's a slipshod rendering of a classic.
These cliches are handled in such a deft manner by Gillespie as to make the overall package quite heartwarming.
This is a fantastic homage to monster movies of yore and is bound to go down as a modern classic. Go Godzilla!
Gigolo is pure Woody Allen formula and provides the right amount of gags to keep this sex comedy afloat.
If you enjoy savage, on-screen action that is unabashedly over-the-top and even sometimes borders on pastiche with all the gangster film tropes, don't hesitate to go watch this.
Lighthearted while managing to mix a torture scene with a recipe for spaghetti sauce, the film's myriad elements come together with a deft touch, without losing the plot.
The movie is no doubt funny, but the genuinely good jokes are just by the handful.
If you want to watch some really good movies inspired by and about the life of Christ, there are plenty of other options you can go for instead.
Here, for a movie that attempts to portray such an interesting life, the result is pretty bland.
Pleasing yet somewhat predictable, this film marks a sharp departure from Favreau's various blockbuster (*Iron Man*) films into something far simpler.
Be it fiery photogenic explosions, smashing buildings, mega monster battles and more, there is no doubt that action rules this film.
Decidedly different from super-budget, superhero fare, this one is sometimes sappy but mostly engaging and definitely driven by music.

While the script is full of obvious and easy aircraft metaphors which are funny, it lacks the kind of witticisms and wisecracks that elevate other contemporary animated films so that they can be enjoyed by a much wider audience.
The climax could've been better and while the battles scenes aren't as epic as Gladiator, the film, along with its sprinkling of tongue-in-cheek lines, makes for a fun watch.
Go for a load of laughs and stay for the end credits.
Despite the impressive cast (Taylor Swift has a cameo), performances are uneven.
While an ensemble cast is indeed impressive, you might feel that so much more could have been done with the story in terms of excitement.

The sometimes-cluttered plot aside, this slickly-shot film manages to pass muster. A big reason why you might want to see this film is because Pierce Brosnan is in it. And indeed, it is on his able shoulders that this movie rests.
If you get your jollies watching houses, cars and even a bunch of passenger planes flung into the air like toys, you might like this.
All in all, an imaginative take on the old classic.
Thin plot aside, *TMNT* is peppered with just enough humour and maintains a strident pace throughout.
Although you will have seen many action films set during a point of time in history (this one's set in 480 BC), there is plenty in here to keep your attention from start to finish.
At heart, the film looks at history with a bout of fun.
Apart from an unnecessary profusion of subplots, you'll likely find this heist-thriller to be quite satisfying.
Ultimately, the message is simple and visceral enough to have crossover appeal. Give it a shot if romantic comedies float your boat.
The characters fit to a tee, except for 50 Cent, incongruously miscast as a computer nerd! The action is routine but the way they plan the escape is interesting and inspired.

A movie about Assange and WikiLeaks is bound to be tough to tackle and while it has a few things going for it, Condon could have scored better if he chose to focus deeper on Assange's admittedly complex and mysterious psyche.
It is nice ... to see Colonel Graff at his gruff best.
Overall, the feel of the movie is relaxed and Turteltaub does a good job of breaking the mould of onscreen senior citizen stereotypes. This Old Boy's Club still knows how to party!
Based on 2011's movie, Starbuck, this is Vaughn's vehicle all the way. All said and done, the movie has its heart in the right place.
The film has graphic violence and perversion, but there is no take-away. It leaves you trying to nail down what the point to this remake really was.
The film is supremely accessible and enjoyable, even if you haven't read Tolkien.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: For a film where so much effort has been put into making the CGI effects look good, a similar amount of emphasis and importance haven't been devoted to dialogues.
Although Stiller has acted in far-out films like Zoolander before, this one gives viewers another side to this actor - one who can handle such ambitious films with ease.
movie_title: The Secret Life Of Walter Mitty (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Magical lands and sorcery add to the movie's mythic structure. While Mika is suitably simpering, the witch is delightfully evil and is a pleasure to watch. As for Reeves, his lines are minimal, but his swordplay does all the talking.
There's not one weak link in the portrayals of this train-wreck of a family.
[The] emotional angle in the film allows Stallone to deliver some surprisingly effective emotional monologues.

Although it cannot top Brian de Palma's 1976 movie, this retelling does allow more empathy for Carrie; she is not evil just for the heck of it. It's a case of the underdog suddenly becoming an overlord.

While some of the effects are alright, the Nemean lion that Hercules battles in one scene looks comical. Hercules, looking like a beefcake at a toga party, starts using his superpowers only towards the end of the film. Too little, too late.
Watch this - while making you laugh and cry, it takes you on a wondrous walk.
The film is more of a generic action-fantasy based on a graphic novel, rather than the book by Mary Shelley, so don't expect it to be emotionally moving.
This is not a movie to be enjoyed but endured. But there lies its disturbing genius.
Heartwarming without being soppy, this film makes for a thoroughly enjoyable watch.
The fact that war really is hell is always kept front and centre throughout. Tobia Schliesser's cinematography is brilliant. This one's an adrenaline- packed ride all the way.
There's much to enjoy in this film for all age groups - everything from the pop culture references, the multitudes of characters, light-hearted sarcasm and above all, the fantastic script.
The film makes a profound point in a subtle way - that the Fuhrer's ambitions if left unchecked would have been world-altering, in the most unsettling of ways.

The love story itself is forgettable and cheesy. But that is only incidental compared to what you can watch this movie for - its fight scenes and cataclysmic climax, both produced and recreated in good detail.
If there's a film that is pretty much true to its name, then this one is it. Another variation on the classic theme of a plane hijack, the movie is relentless with not a wasted second.
Moving at its own pace, this is a fantastic study of Mid West America, where time almost stands still.
Generously laced with dark humour and part-melancholic, Inside Llewyn Davis is full of clever Coen-isms and the film's soundtrack too is wonderful. This one makes for some compelling viewing.

The film is like a bunch of music videos strung together with a romance angle. And as mentioned earlier, you don't go for this movie for scintillating dialogue, but to see them move it like experts on the dance floor.
One of the first among many plot holes you will wonder about is how Gatling is a military rank despite clearly being a mercenary. Does he have a backstory?
The film stops short of being something truly memorable but has just the right amount of witty turns, deft plot twists, funny situations and interesting characters.
The seamless blending of animation with live action is the most striking point in the film.
An affecting tale of an extraordinary human being.
The three actors deliver solid performances while getting completely under the sun-blistered skin of the downed pilots' characters. Definitely an inspirational tale.
The taut editing (Tom Cross) is outstanding and Simmons outdoes himself.
While the ending seems a bit hurried and underwhelming, it is Witherspoon who shines throughout.
Apart from the fantastic characterizations and top-notch cinematography, the real beauty of Turner's vision was his ability to find beauty in the seemingly ordinary.
The idea that a reality TV show can unite a war-torn country and make the Afghans forget their concerns, comes across as farcical.
Director Lawrence ... gives the other characters a greater sense of development with the result that the movie doesn't come across as a Jennifer Lawrence Glorification Vehicle.
Simply put, if you like films about boxing, with the emotional quotient thrown in, you will enjoy this one. It's Stallone, after all.
Legend has all the elements of a period gangster film in place, along with dollops of additional dash and verve.
All said and done, this is Salma Hayek channeling her inner GI Jane. It could have been way more ambitions though.
This one will both charm the adults and keep the kids entertained.
The storytelling is top notch. It's a carefully-crafted dance of nuance that balances a bit of everything.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Point Break comes across as a string of admittedly amazing action sequences and sports feats with the rest of the film haphazardly built up around it.

Monster Hunt, although an acquired taste, is an interestingly different tale told keeping various Chinese themes in mind, in addition to various sight gags, martial arts (but of course) and some humour too.
This one makes for some fairly delightful viewing.
movie_title: Asterix and Obelix: Mansion of the Gods (Astérix: Le domaine des dieux) (2014)

movie_review_blurb: This is a beautiful tale of a mother's love for her child, selfless and pure.
Pine ... is in his element as the resolute rescuer. His character is heroic, but in the strong, silent kind of way. Enjoy movies about daring rescues? Go watch this.
There's absolutely nothing to cling on to, as a viewer that can engage you about this movie in terms of emotional content.
Supported by a very clever script, Deadpool is deliciously irreverent, subversive and uproariously funny.
The last scene of the film alone is worth the ticket price.
So what we really have is a film that cannot be taken seriously either as a satire, as a period film and neither as a zombie film.
From the first frame, you know you're in for something special and it's pretty clear that Leonardo has given his everything to this film.
If kitsch mythology and a swords-and-sandals clad Butler along with various bosomy lasses float your boat, it's passable.
The direction and screenplay (intertitles are used) is understated, but younger viewers might find themselves stifling a yawn or two at times.
The film's biggest draw is the action scenes.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: With its simple dialogues and also because it is in essence a gorgeous-looking tableaux, enjoy this slick slice of cinema more for its visuals rather than anything else.
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: What works greatly to the movie's credit is the pacing (never a dull moment here!) and that sense of 'What's going to happen next?'
The film is largely compelling and touches upon many aspects about the dynamics of a couple's love, along with the lengths and limits of tolerance one can have for the other.
The Carell-Ruffalo-Tatum trio put in terrific, edgy performances.
Overall, the movie doesn't rewrite the book of shock (despite the jump scares), but what you get is a fast-paced scare flick with an ending that could have been creepier.
movie_title: The Woman in Black 2 Angel of Death (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Moretz manages to convey some of the delicate and bittersweet shades of love and romance with a maturity that prevents the movie from becoming a sob-fest. Therefore, the story moves at a brisk pace.
The greatest effort seems to have gone into getting the look of the fight scenes correctly in an otherwise bland film.
The movie is classic Liam Neeson and like any good thriller, keeps you guessing till the end.
Featuring a few beautiful scenes that will probably warm the heart of the most hardened cynic, Dolphin Tale 2 makes for some wholesome family fare.
It keeps you engaged and is often amusing.

While it isn't in the league of, say, Insidious or The Ring, Deliver Us From Evil packs in a mixed bag of thrills that is, at times, deeply disturbing by virtue of using the kind of horror tropes that are more psychological than gory.
It will give you your money's worth, while not really serving you anything too memorable (or scary) as some of the other, more sinister horror films we've seen in the last few years.

The basic premise of the film could have made for an engaging and far-out watch. The very concept of the Rapture could have been depicted with power and mystery, but instead the opposite is achieved in a film that just looks slapdash.

Delightful but somewhat un-memorable, the energy of the film lies in the push-pull conflict between the two protagonists handled deftly by Radcliffe and Kazan - the whole question of love that cannot be...and hoping against all odds that it can.
This is a tale encapsulated simply enough within the deceptively simple parenthesis of a small-town family bonding saga. And of course, Downey and Duvall shine.
There's humour in here for sure, but some more of that playful silliness in between the unnecessary bits would have made this a better watch.
Fury is unflinching in its depiction of war from the get-go to the point of being unsettling.
For a movie that is about the perils of summoning sinister specters, the film itself could have been scarier.

This is essentially Evans's vehicle. His version of Dracula is action-oriented rather than horrifying and creepy. And keeping that in mind, he manages, in most parts, to get his teeth into the substance of Count Dracula's legend convincingly enough.
This revenge film looks slick, stylish and despite its camp story line, keeps you engrossed throughout with a strong impact.
O'Connell and Ishihara bring a stunning sense of realism to their roles, which is a great reason why you'll want to watch this movie.
This fairly entertaining kiddie comedy is full of funny little asides and exchanges that keep the pace going.
movie_title: Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb (2014)

The battles are indeed mammoth and this is undoubtedly the most deadly of the Hobbit series.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Kent knows what she's doing - possessed parents, sinister children and haunted homes - this is the stuff sleepless nights are made of.
Sometimes sappy and sometimes over-the-top, it is mostly enjoyable.

While the intricacies of the mystical world can be confusing at times, our introduction to this side of the Marvel Universe makes for a thoroughly enjoyable viewing experience, thanks to dazzling 3-D visual effects.

...combines the adolescent humiliation of American Pie and the middle-aged angst of The 40 Year-Old Virgin.

Ren now dances with his iPod, the black kids krump in the carpark and the grown-ups worry about the recession. And that's about where the updating ends.
The script is witty, the chemistry just right, and the overall effect so sweet it's a little like eating too much chocolate.
A film with as much substance as a very long beer ad.
It's an earnest, sweet film that relies on the extraordinary true story of Winter, the rescued dolphin, and little on manipulative Hollywood tricks.

Managing to keep melodrama at a distance, it's nonetheless impossible not to get swept up in the relationship.
Weekend is a film that feels like real life - sometimes dull, sometimes funny, and bittersweet.
A sexy crowd-pleaser for both genders.
It's a fast-paced adventure tale like they used to make 'em, a slice of old-fashioned Hollywood that traverses tragedy, romance and exotic travel.
Like his irreverent film Thumbsucker, Mills tackles dark territory but never strays too far into melancholy.
It isn't bashful at all, incorporating plenty of sex and humour; you'll feel like you're sleeping with them too.
If it wasn't for the music, this biopic would be a total dud.
It's not hard to imagine Coppola as Cleo, the little girl growing up in her father's lavish world, seemingly unaffected, and the preternaturally mature Fanning is a stand-out in the role.

Will leave you grinning for days.
Semi-satisfying, if you can keep up.

movie_review_blurb: What is an occasionally charming upstairs/downstairs comedy is overshadowed by one unintentionally creepy relationship.

A moving, sweet and at times harrowing tale...
Whether or not you care about fashion, it's an absolute must-see.

movie_review_blurb: As far as sports movies go, like Hamm, it's immensely likeable.
Spinning Plates has three moving personal stories, and that's what makes it memorable.
Worth seeing for the impressive performances alone.
A spectacular film, as messy, strange and funny as a dream, with hedonistic party scenes to rival The Great Gatsby.
[Meryl Streep's] performance teeters between the brilliant and the OTT.
One Chance has, for the most part, more wit than sentimentality. Formulaic but moving.
Austenland is bound to become the guilty pleasure of the spring.
Hugh Laurie as the children's teacher Mr Watts is both hauntingly sad and inspiring, and the captivating Xzannjah as Matilda is a natural.

movie_review_blurb: Silly but unapologetic entertainment.
Has a wit and style you won't find in his kick-ass work for Buffy the Vampire Slayer, Firefly or The Avengers.
A relatively entertaining way to upload your consciousness for 119 minutes.

The result is a film that is intoxicating, emotional and exhausting.
A pretty safe bet for a fun time no matter your age - a bit like a day at a water park, really.
...will sort the lovers from the cynics in a heartbeat.

Bigger, better and bloodier than its predecessors...

Hammers home [the Stones'] amazing, timeless appeal.
You could say it's a film that would play just as comfortably on television. But the clever writing, understated performances and slick editing more than make up for it.
This is one film that's equal parts moving and grating.
Your enjoyment of the film will depend on your appreciation of the troubling and brutal nature of the source material.

movie_title: Diana Vreeland: The Eye Has To Travel (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The joy of watching lies in the purity of the dancer's passion.
Thankfully there's a somewhat compelling story here for you.

Grandma holds its ground by having the right actors say the right things the right way, however wrong those words might sound at times. It is a quiet storm of a film that stealthily moves you when you least expect it.
The Meddler is a delightful film with an emotional honesty that can be traced back to the real-life mother of writer/director Lorene Scafaria.
The screenplay, adapted by both Kidd and Schulman, apparently leaves out much of the book's biting black humour.
It's nice to see a film for the guys that doesn't feature anorexic chicks in leather hoisting huge guns or fighting robots destroying metropolises. Good on you, Ron Howard.

I was moved by this film. I laughed, I teared up. I - dare I say? - related. And that is more powerful than any message movie could ever be. You should see it even if (like me) you're white and conservative. Especially if you're white and conservative.
Is it a sin to covet the life of someone who exists purely for the purpose of being coveted?

Calm down. This movie fits fine with conservatism. It's pretty much a warning about what will happen to Earth if socialism wins. Future Socialist Earth is in bad shape. It's dusty. It's dirty. It's unkept. Basically, it's Detroit.
This movie makes you believe in revolution.
Zombies bad. Brad Pitt good.

Planes would be a fine DVD to have in your arsenal to keep your toddler boy occupied while you take a shower, if they'd grown tired of Thomas the Tank Engine or Cars itself. It's that level. Nothing more.
Like the road trip that fills the bulk of the story, it's a ride that feels awkward and even pointless at first, but one you're sure glad you took by the end.
She's nothing like Bella, that vampire-girlfriend, and this romance is nothing like Twilight.
Memo to schoolchildren planning on watching Peter Jackson's Hobbit trilogy in lieu of reading the novel for your book report: Don't. You could read the book in less time than watching the movies.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: On paper, American Hustle should be the movie of the year and sweep the Oscars, but its supreme promise fades once the lights go down in the theater. It's good, not great.
It's not ok to make three hours of graphic sex, epic drug binges, and general debauchery as boring as it is in The Wolf of Wall Street.
Enough quirky, charming moments, as Walter travels the odd corners of the world, to elevate the film to something enjoyable. It has its own sense of delight.
movie_title: The Secret Life Of Walter Mitty (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A powerful telling of a true story that reminds us there is a qualitative difference between America and the evils we fight at such great cost. This devastating movie will make you proud.

It works on all levels: as a fun, funny movie to enjoy with family, as a commentary on the conformity of society and its lack of creativity, as an ode to human connections, and even, if you squint just right, an exploration of the nature of God.
It's the kind of movie that Christians, indeed everyone, should want Hollywood to make.
If it were released from any other studio, it would be their best film. From Pixar, it's not even in the top bunch. Not everything can be "Up" or "Toy Story 3," I suppose. Oh well.
Perhaps Jason Bateman serves his edgy audience by bringing them a redemption story in their own language. Perhaps he crosses lines that shouldn't be crossed. Perhaps both.

Created by Disney, lauding Walt Disney, about the creation of a Disney classic, it has much the same effect as a trip to Disneyland: It's a heartwarming, sweet, kind, and fantastical ride that works best if you never wonder what's behind the curtain.
Engaging, entertaining, and refreshingly sincere.
What with personal problems and a bad economy, mob hitmen are just like us. Only more violent.

If you see it, I highly recommend that you do what I did and sit in front of your local chapter of The Rock Fan Club. It, um, enhances the experience. One might even say it pumps it up. Puts the fun on steroids. (Too far?)
The creators, more than most, understand that a good setting and fun sight gags are secondary to a story with heart.
If there were any justice in the world, this would be the movie inspiring mass riots. It's that bad.
Daring staging and a great story make this adaptation the movie to beat this Oscar season.
This is how the political sausage is made and it will make you feel better about American Democracy. Not many movies can say that.
Mostly lightweight, but the most interesting part of the movie is Jamie Foxx as Electro. This villain embodies black rage, more Malcolm X than mutant.
A star-studded cast and a good concept add up to less than nothing in Playing for Keeps, an attempt at a warm, family romantic comedy that, like the main character, succumbs to its vices.
Beneath the moving acting, soaring music, and powerful images is a story. And what a story.
Once again, the insightful Judd Apatow has put his finger on Generation X. Sadly, the result is not encouraging.

The controversy comes from insistence by Bigalow that audiences think for themselves. She neither condones nor condemns, but rather asks questions without giving easy answers. Plus, she does it while thoroughly entertaining the audience.
There's nothing particularly wrong with Gangster Squad, except perhaps its timing, but there's nothing particularly right either.
Don't be dismayed, Die Hard fans. The problem is with the movie, not yourselves.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: After years of Shrek-like cynicism and fart jokes dominating children's media, a refreshing tornado of sincerity blows into theaters with the new spectacular Oz the Great and Powerful.
If I had a pickle for every time a person went to meet his Maker in this film, I'd have a bulging full barrel.

What's happening in America? Are there really scores of concerned but overprotective parents locking their daughters in padded rooms and not letting them experience any adventures? Actually, maybe Hollywood has a point.
Perhaps not a great movie, but definitely a good adaptation of a great American story.
A profound and mystical exploration of love that juxtaposes marriage between humans with a priest's marriage to God but gives few answers.
It has the flash and quips to be a good time, if not the heart to be great.
I'm not sure I understood the book until I saw this movie. Yeah. I said that.
Good despite the poster-blurb title. I hear the sequels are "Best Family Movie Yet" and "Amazing Thrill Ride!"
Vince Vaughn and Owen Wilson deliver a pep talk to Millennials with nice, easy chemistry, but the sweetness of the message deserves a better overall vehicle.

This film explores manhood in a way few do: The jaw-clenched man determined to do the right thing, the man set in his course who will not be swayed, the man who has taken his own measure and who cares only for that measure.
If humanistic pop science is a religion, then Christopher Nolan is its high priest and Interstellar its rapture story.
'Her' reduces love to a purely intellectual pursuit. The body is oddly irrelevant, the soul absent, reproduction abandoned. The result is dehumanizing. And yet fascinating.
Soap opera with supercars and explosions. Pitch perfect tribute to Paul Walker. What's not to love?
This monster may not reflect terror and grief over nuclear war, but he sure is fun to watch. And you can bring the kids!
It makes sense a MAD MAX army goes into battle with a metal guitarist. This primal, epic film is the stuff of Homer in the key of Metallica.
Anna Kendrick's charm saves this film from being entirely predictable and only half funny.

"Jurassic World," like its predecessors, fills up the screen with roaring, slathering, earth-shaking dinosaurs, then fills in mere humans around the edges. It's a formula that works as well in 2015 as it did in 1993.

After you realize the central message, which has to do with Sadness herself, the film feels a little like an exercise you'd experience at a good therapist's office. Only Pixar could pull that off and make a good, not great, film out of it.

The film makes the case for getting over yourself and growing the hell up. It's more than romantic comedy. It's profound, even as it makes you laugh again and again. Here's hoping that Apatow and Schumer are just getting started.

Like its predecessor, "Guardians of the Galaxy," "Ant-Man" plays with the Marvel universe without upending it. It manages to make fun of the superhero genre while still fully embracing the emotions that make the genre powerful.

A punk rock rebel of a movie. It follows no rules. It slaps you in the face while making you laugh. Completely entertaining, it also isn't afraid. In our environment of careful and slavish correctness to groupthink, that feels like a refreshing breeze.
Ridley Scott's enjoyable space drama feels like a throwback to the days when American know-how and determination promised a brighter future ahead.
Delivers an effective mix of nostalgia and new storylines. Disney pulled off a modern-day Christmas miracle keeping the plot almost completely unknown to audiences. My advice is keep it that way.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Whatever audiences expected from Michael Bay's examination of the Benghazi debacle, it wasn't this insightful war story about hubris on every level except the men who carry the guns. This film rivals greats like "Black Hawk Down" and "Zero Dark Thirty."
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: This film is a testosterone flick, the opposite of a chick flick. That is not to say that no women will enjoy it, only that many will not. Its purpose is grit, gore, strength, and endurance. It is simple and elegant in its simplicity.
"Deadpool" is not so much a movie as an extended inside joke with a movie wrapped around it, plus an abject apology for Green Lantern.

Too competent to be universally panned, too disjointed to be universally praised, too anticipated to be a new revelation, too beloved in subject to be easily dismissed, the film will be one people either passionately love or passionately hate.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The core of the film, the beauty of it, and the spirit of it are what I wish religious movies would be about. Scratch that. It's what I wish all movies would be about.
The thing that sets this movie apart is the magic that happens between Gosling, Crowe, and Rice.

It's nostalgic in the same way a hipster combing through vinyl records in a record shop coffee house is nostalgic. It picks and chooses what it wants to remember about the past and puts a decidedly modern spin on the treasures it decides to keep.
Although the plot remains, for the most part, the same, the tone is so different as to reverse the pacifism-at-all-costs message of the book, making a good series even better.
I kind of had a tepidly good time in "Jupiter Ascending." It won me over in the same way that bag of tater tots in the freezer wins you over: it has its own freezer-burned charm.
You can't escape the feeling that Whedon and the gang are having a good time making the film, and want to share that glee with the audience. It's a franchise that has hit its rhythm.

Do not believe anyone trying to make "Selma" a factional thing, a liberal or conservative, black, white, or hashtag movie. It transcends all that. It is a great American story, well told, and nothing less.
Everything you want in a time-traveling, mutant-filled, disco-styled, over-the-top, effects-filled extravaganza.
It lacks the irony of "Shrek" and "Wicked." And that's a good thing.
A story about daring to love in the face of death, well, it's really all our stories if we are brave enough.
The storyline of Earth to Echo may seem familiar, but don't let that stop your kids from enjoying this sweet, child-driven adventure.
A story about real peacemaking that manages to both instruct and delight in classic fashion.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: For those who have never been high, the new film "Inherent Vice" will give you a pretty good sense of it. You'll have no idea what's going on. You'll wonder whether you're supposed to know. In the end, though, you won't be sure you care.
The very things that others love, the meandering, unfocused essences of the movie, were the things that I disliked. Variety is the spice of life, right?
This priest cuts through false motives, calls people on their baloney, talks to them straight, loves them despite themselves. Sort of like his Lord. No wonder they want to kill him.
'Get On Up' makes you feel, rather than tells you about, the groove that ran through the life of James Brown. This is not a movie about The Black Man, it is a movie about a black man.
No good roles for women in movies, you say? Hudson's Sarah consciously and joyfully embraces her midlife transition to matriarch of a family. She is up to the task. I wish there were more like her.

Is it really so hard, Hollywood? So hard to make a well-directed, well-acted flick that keeps audiences enthralled? In a year when movies have failed to live up to the hype, Gone Girl makes it look easy.
The material is well-trod, the story oft-told, and the characters familiar, but children don't mind in the same way that they don't mind hearing the same bedtime story every night.
Wrapped in an exciting movie with beautiful special effects, 'The Giver' makes the case for the beauty of grown-up freedom.
Increasingly, in a world of ISIS, we know evil exists and is not going away. Maybe we need symbols to inspire us.
This secular pilgrimage has fine acting but wants to be more meaningful than it is.
The movie wastes its fine actors and, more importantly, its rich subject matter.

"Unbroken" is the film that will bring hope and inspiration not only to American audiences, but those suffering in war zones and under dictators the world over. That makes it a far more dangerous movie to oppressors than "The Interview" could ever be.

Primarily, it is a gritty and moving war story about the heroes who have answered America's call to arms. Secondarily, it is an unapologetic manifesto from Eastwood about what it means to be an American and a warrior today.

An ambitious film that addresses what it means to be human. It unabashedly appeals to our better natures. In a world addicted to irony, it is unapologetically sincere. Adults as well as children should go see this fantastic film.

While it's always commendable when filmmakers attempt to broach new territory, this disappointingly slight rom-com does not live up to director Susanne Bier and writer Anders Thomas Jensen's more serious work.
Jean Dwight (Brenda Blethyn) is perhaps the most overbearing, self-obsessed and irritating matriarchal big screen figure since Norman Bates' mum in 'Psycho'.
An intelligent, thrill-quenching blend of sci-fi and satire introducing a welcome addition to the woefully small canon of admirable action heroines. Bring on round two!
Somehow this mishmash of borrowed ideas all comes together to create an unexpectedly solid genre movie.
A pathos-laden chamber piece poignantly played by an ensemble of actors at the peak of their powers.
The central premise of The Host is fundamentally unfilmable and, hence, probably shouldn't have been filmed.
A sweet, dark, funny true-crime story with a dream cast - and that includes the real-life residents of the town of Carthage, Texas.

Itbecomes increasingly difficult to pin any message at all on Marc Forster's astonishingly expensive and extensively re-written (and re-shot) blockbuster. And you know what? I didn't mind in the least.
Loads funnier - and smarter - than it sounds on paper, and well worth watching for the unflinching Hollywood satire, even if you're sick of Apatow-esque bromantic comedies.
The tween and teen target audience will no doubt lap Sea Of Monsters up, but adults will be disappointed by its feeble protagonist and uninvolving plot.
Excessive improvisation and scrappy plotting let down an able cast.
The uneasy blend of comedy and ultra-violence will turn some viewers off but, if you can stomach it, you may find yourself curiously entertained.

Whether or not you enjoy this film depends entirely on whether you judge it to be po-faced or parody. If you believe it's the former, you'll probably hate it. If you believe it's the latter, you'll have an absolute blast.
A smart, gripping thriller and further proof that Ben Affleck is as adept behind the camera as he is in front of it.
What ultimately makes this film stand out is the way it captures the painful dawning experienced by all human beings that neither youth - nor you - are eternal.
Bleak and bleaker.
Largely incoherent in its hyperactive attempt to cut edge.
Darkly comic and surprisingly touching in equal measure.
An acid drama which leaves a deliciously bitter aftertaste.
A cinematic sight for sore eyes.
Strictly compelling viewing.
So, do elephants pray? Who cares!
An illuminating angle on a forgotten crisis.
So-so.
A discreetly epic observation of solitude and circumstance.

movie_review_blurb: The film never struggles under the strain of its weighty subject matter, delivering an enjoyable and heartfelt tale which combines elements of exhilarating comedy and tense drama that never detract from its bravely articulated subtext.
Forget Hortense, we're still looking for the plot.
Oscar winning Spaniard Fernando Trueba ponders the relationship between artist and muse, and in glistening black and white.
movie_title: El artista y la modelo (The Artist and the Model) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The story of four women and their attempts to uphold abortion rights in the US makes for compelling, if horrifying viewing.
This is divine.
The comedy inherent in a human/zombie love pairing doesn't get this tired and unambitious genre pastiche very far.
Nick Broomfield returns with his best film in a decade with this dark exploration into the actions of a LA serial killer.
The fans will love. The faint-hearted won't.

This is about a woman discovering her voice (literally) via a fish-man who is unavoidably attractive. She's Belle, but hungrier, more resolute. And it's about time we handed a tenacious woman some decision-making power.
La La Land touts itself as a love letter to movie musicals, but it fails to honor the memory of films like Singing In The Rain and West Side Story through its casting choices.

The (writers) repeat the same old stuff you've seen before. They ask, though, that you be patient. Pay attention, and the routine won't be as stuffy as you thought, and may even lead to surprising insights.
Bee Movie has its moments but all in all there is very little sting in its tale.
Unfortunately, despite the best efforts of its cast, the film just isn't that good.
Ultimately, despite all its toughness, the film's flaws make it a little too vulnerable to stand up on its own.

The title and central concept may be ripe with religious allusions, but there's no heavy-handed allegorising here. Nor does the film ever veer off into soapy drama: forget about any shock reveals or intrigues.
Despite Radcliffe's best efforts, Aja's film lacks any real bite.
Its plump chickens maintain that strange, haptic quality that makes you yearn to reach out and squeeze them.
Characters you can't help but care about? Check. A spot of amped-up social commentary? Double check. Lashings of bloody, bite-y mayhem? Triple check.
A little more vinegar... and Bad Moms could have been a genuinely subversive comedy, rather than just a sweetly funny one.
Plot and character quibbles aside, there's doubting Alvrarez's taste for horror. But, while you might hold your breath while watching, Don't Breathe probably won't give you any lasting nightmares.
Its power - its shuddering, relentless intensity - lies in the way it makes you vicariously feel both her dual hungers, and surreptitiously relish every sticky, illicit bite.
Universal's monster franchise has made it out of the tomb, just about - but if this rebirth is going to sustain itself long term, it's going to need a little more meat under its bandages.
It's utterly ridiculous - and impossible to resist.
Watching Mr. Gaga develop as a dancemaker is as entrancing as watching Batsheva perform live.
movie_title: Mr. Gaga: A True Story of Love and Dance (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Many films have portrayed the rigors of ballet training, but none will make viewers wince quite like Mao's Last Dancer.

On the most basic level, Wadjda is a wonderful piece of filmmaking. It's a tale that's delightful and insightful and gently transgressive, and Al-Mansour tells it with economy, lyricism and terrific warmth.
Exuberant and disarming.
It's a deeply affecting yet keen-eyed portrait of the struggles of art, love and life.

As in Laika's previous two efforts -- the fantastical Coraline and playfully supernatural ParaNorman -- The Boxtrolls boasts a scrupulously crafted world. But its overstuffed screenplay lacks humor, and it could use a great deal more fun.

Here's some good news for Oregonians: Wild gets our state right, and it does so without a single artisanal letterpress studio or gluten-free doughnut shop. It's also a rich and affecting piece of filmmaking, independent of any book.

The effect is that of a single, continuous take. It's balletic and bravura work from cinematographer Emmanuel Lubezki... But just as the camera floats along, so too does much else in this self-consciously clever film.
Smart, gutsy and relevant.
Though Pride hits the expected beats-the soundtrack swells and a little old lady asks if all lesbians are vegetarians-it's so ebullient that it just feels shrewish to resist.
It's astonishingly, wonderfully refreshing.

Watching 12 Years a Slave does not feel like an ethical or educational obligation. While its instructive value is undeniable, this is also a rousing portrait, a morally complicated tale and a masterful work of art.
For someone who made her Broadway debut 68 years ago, Elaine Stritch is still quite the firecracker.
Big summer action movies can be thrilling, but if you really want to feel your heart pounding out of your chest, try being a 15-year-old girl for 101 minutes.
movie_title: The Diary Of A Teenage Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: "Aloft" sets up a compelling mystery - how could a loving mother abandon her son? - and then, frustratingly, refuses to solve it.
"Barely Lethal" is clearly confused about its intended audience, starting with the icky title, a pun on the porn label that selects and photographs models to emphasize their youth.
While "Ted 2" is absurd and occasionally disgusting, it is also wickedly funny.
Watching it was like opening the wrong gift -- that's not my size, and I don't like blue, but thank you, Warner Bros., for even bothering to shop for me. Most of the other studios forgot my birthday.
The chemistry of the leads and their authentic, crackling dialogue make it a pleasure to tag along for the day.
A surprisingly touching and raucously funny R-rated comedy written by and starring Amy Schumer.
Neustadter and Weber, who also adapted "A Fault in Our Stars" for director Josh Boone, have a feel for the mundane moments of teen life that carry an emotional punch.
The kind of movie that exists because greenlighting it is easier than thinking.

At the center of the film is the interesting idea that we're all putting on performances for each other; unfortunately, the manner in which "Mistress America" explores that theme also makes it a movie where moments of authenticity are scarce.
"Trumbo" is timely in its portrayal of a moment when political speech is dangerously charged, yet unabashedly old-fashioned in the sincerity of its storytelling.
In revisiting the pop rock quest of a multiracial group of adopted sisters in suburban California, Chu has made a stylish and self-aware musical fantasy for the YouTube generation.
As a writer, Jolie Pitt is better at ideas than dialogue, much of which is leaden here. But the characters' behaviors feel true ...
