Going in expecting one thing and getting another is always going to throw you off.
I, for one, really hope that the future becomes what it is in Robot & Frank.
The Huntsman: Winter's War having so many good bits made me me more frustrated than if it had been a wall-to-wall mediocre movie. Because there is potential, and it was squandered.
The Legend of Tarzan is garbage.
I was not disappointed.

Ruby Sparks is a good little cute 'n' clever (dare I call it... quirky?) movie, and it's possible that the degree to which I'm frustrated with it is solely due to the fact that I hoped for something different, something more.
Hushpuppy, a six-year-old with no superpowers, no great destiny, not even much by way of contact with the outside world, is a more active female protagonist than 99% of [Hollywood heroines].
There's just something refreshing, at least for me, about going to a movie and not knowing what it's going to be, even down to its genre.
The Boxtrolls is a thoroughly enjoyable movie that I already have plans to see a second time.

It contains some interesting visuals, great sound editing, and a decent score by Game of Thrones' Ramin Djawadi. However, as a villain origin story, which it purports itself to be, Dracula Untold is an absolute failure.
Without a single narrative throughline sufficiently weighty to justify the continued involvement of most of the main characters, just about everyone besides Thorin kind of... bops around.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Ultimately, is the takeaway. 13 Hours is a good Michael Bay movie... but it's still a Michael Bay movie.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Visually, the film's amazing, blending the everyday with more fantastical elements in a small-town, blue collar version of the fairy tale Iranian landscape in Chicken with Plums.
Ryan Reynolds was born in a damn lab to play this role, and T.J. Miller is equally good as possibly the most realistic superhero sidekick ever.

Every once in a while I see a movie that leaves me vibrating with energy as I leave the theater, knowing that what I just saw will stick with me probably for the rest of my life... Snowpiercer is one of those.
It's definitely worth checking out.
movie_title: Wonder Women! The Untold Story Of American Superheroines (2012)

movie_review_blurb: When (if) this movie comes to mind a few years down the line, I imagine I'll be thinking less about any specific scene than the fact that it has so much wasted potential.
Director Fede Alvarez has crafted a tight, relentless thriller that over the course of its 88-minute running time ratchets up tension to a squirm-inducing degree.
Gritty, grimdark Bond may have been novel when Casino Royale came out and the franchise was shrugging off the spectre (sorry) of the silly '90s, but now all that self-seriousness is dated and tiring.
I've never walked out of a movie in my life (and I saw City of Angels in theatres!), but if I weren't reviewing this I would have been out.
Last Knights is both better and worse than Outcast, aka That One With Nicolas Cage and Hayden Christensen and Truly Awful Haircuts.

It Follows is miles and away better than a lot of the low-budget horror that abuses the eyeballs of genre fans, but it's not good enough to be worth the time of people who aren't already into horror (like The Babadook is).
It's dull. It's literally, if not metaphorically, bloodless.
The Hateful Eight isn't among Tarantino's greatest. It's not one of the best movies of the year. But it's not awful, unless you find Tarantino intolerable.

It's to McKay's credit that he makes The Big Short so fun; there are a lot of talented comedic actors here, the banter is strong, and there are pop culture montages strewn throughout, meant to mark the passage of time, that help maintain visual interest.
Afghans in this movie are for the most part either barbaric or stupid... sometimes both.
Yeah. It's a little contrived.
How to Be Single gets major points for trying to do something different, but ultimately it's still a Netflixer at best.
Honestly, it's pretty compelling.
It's like a PG-13, dad version of Chi-Raq. The message, if a little preachy and a little schmaltzy, is also worthy and well-meant.

Freeheld is not an Oscar movie. Freeheld is an HBO-on-a-Sunday-afternoon-because-you-don't-have-anything-else-to-do movie, and as an HBO-on-a-Sunday-afternoon-because-you-don't-have-anything-else-to-do movie, it's solid.
It's a good one for baby horror fans, and adults (Goosebumps fans and non-Goosebumps fans alike) will have a good time as well.
Actually pretty watchable and fun.
It's a very entertaining movie! It is not a perfect movie, but considering the state of summer 2016 so far, "doesn't make me want to light my hair on fire" is pretty damn good.

I like that both the book and the movie ditched the action-y bombast and took Katniss' story to a quieter, more emotionally resonant place. It felt earned, given The Hunger Games has always been more about Katniss' character evolution.
Divergent and Insurgent weren't good. Allegiant is less good. Make it stahhhhhp.
Do you want to see a dark comedy that opens with corrupt cops Alexander Skarsgard and Michael Pena running over a mime? Do I even need to ask you that question?
2 Big 2 Fat 2 Greek isn't terrible so much as it's aggressively bland and predictable, ie "terrible without the decency to be entertaining about it."
This is a movie best seen in theatres with a group of rowdy and slightly tipsy (or more than slightly tipsy) friends.
Now You See Me 2 is... fine. It's not good, but it's entertaining
If you go in not expecting much, Apocalypse is actually pretty entertaining.
Ben-Hur isn't good. It could have been. Conceivably.
If Little Accidents never feels quite comfortable in its own skin, it's still evidence of a filmmaker who should have a lot to offer once she gets more secure in her (considerable) abilities.
There's no drama. No suspense. No real stakes, even, because most of the movie takes place after the Rapture already happened.
Don't see this movie. Or do, because it's really good. But don't, because you will hate yourself afterwards.
Vastly smarter--and more terrifying--than most of the low-budget horror films (sequels and prequels and spinoffs!) being pumped into theatres on a regular basis.
Danish director Jonas Alexander Arnby makes his feature debut with an understated, contemplative coming-of-age drama...with werewolves.
The only fantastic thing about Fantastic Four is how much blandness it manages to pack into 100 minutes.
At times, Cop Car's story is too spare [...] but much is redeemed by the nail-biter finale.
Works as a who's-who of animated talent, if not so much as a cohesive, complete film.
Rory Culkin shines (and terrifies) in this modest but deftly handled psychological thriller from first-time director Lou Howe.
Intermittently funny caper tries to be a high-school comedy and a spy adventure but doesn't go hard enough on either genre to be successful.
A witty, emotionally authentic comedy/drama that heralds the arrival of a true filmmaking talent in first-time feature director Alonso Ruiz Palacios.
This thoughtful, contemplative Western is compelling and well-crafted, even if it's occasionally as slow as a wandering tumbleweed.
Ultron maintains Marvel's record for solid, entertaining blockbusters but falls down a bit in the "making sense" department.
The blandness of Adult Beginners' characters and story makes it feel much longer than its 90 minutes.
The Hunger Games' braindead younger sibling aims for dystopian gravitas but only succeeds at being dull and joyless.
Basically, don't put too much thought into this movie, because no one involved in making it did.
Everly ricochets between light and dark so abruptly that it'll make your head spin. If Lynch had fixed the messy tone problem, he'd have had a good movie on his hands.
This documentary about the epidemic of rape on college campuses is a difficult but worthy watch.
The tension this movie keeps going throughout its 99-minute runtime is nothing short of remarkable [...] There is not an ounce of fat [present].
An endearingly dorky undead heart beats in this vampire mockumentary by two of the creators of HBO's "Flight of the Conchords."
movie_title: What We Do In The Shadows (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Saying this underbaked Chronicle knockoff is meant for teenagers is an insult to the intelligence of teenagers everywhere.
It's another New York-based coming-of-age comedy/drama, but don't roll your eyes: Desiree Akhavan is a fresh new voice in filmmaking.
If you're curious, the movie that has North Korea so upset is genuinely amusing, if flawed in the length department.
As such a character-driven piece, Goodbye to All That lives or dies on the talent of its lead actor, and Schneider thankfully delivers.
At once a rollicking good time (its two hours and 21 minutes fly by) and extremely emotionally affecting.
Angel of Death took that solid foundation and wasted it with unoriginal, lazy storytelling and a drab visual sensibility.
movie_title: The Woman in Black 2 Angel of Death (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A bit of a frenetic mess, but an entertaining one, Joe Wright's latest is a fitting entry into the pantheon of Peter Pan movies.
Academy, just give Blanchett the Oscar now.
Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles is a sloppy, unholy mess. It is a blight, not only upon the art of cinema, but upon humanity itself.
Kate Winslet's outfits-but not much else-shine in this tonally jarring revenge thriller/dark comedy/small-town drama/murder mystery/... pseudo-western?
Blair Witch has all the bells and whistles of an effective horror film, without delivering on the originality and general terror of its predecessor.
A heavy dose of style and a top-notch cast can't keep Morgan from being a bottom-of-the-barrel bore.
Laika Entertainment tackles fantasy in this stunning Japan-set fable.
Truth or Dare goes digital in the teen techno thriller Nerve, a light bit of summer fun as long as you can look past the fact that none of it makes any damn sense.
If it doesn't offer anything particularly groundbreaking, Star Trek Beyond is nonetheless an exciting, well-crafted actioner.
Though somewhat meandering, Steven Spielberg's The BFG benefits from one of the best performances of the year so far, courtesy of Mark Rylance's Big Friendly Giant.
This fantasy epic is made with love. If only it were made with quality, too.
To say that [this movie] is better than its 2014 predecessor isn't exactly abundant praise. Alas, it's just about all the praise there is to give.
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Royalty Hightower is a powerful new presence in a film that nevertheless falls short of the mark.
Russell Crowe and Ryan Gosling make for a great comedy duo in this dark, cynical noir with an unexpectedly earnest center.
Joey Kuhn's gay coming-of-age romance is riveting, in spite of (because of?) of occasional detours into melodrama territory.
The Jungle Book manages to take an old story, presented in a traditional, earnest way, and still make it feel fresh and exciting.
Simple, brutal and intense.
It's a light, breezy, shaggy story where the most dramatic thing that happens is a scuffle in a disco.
Tina Fey does a lot to carry this Afghanistan-set war comedy through some rough patches.
The movie absolutely drags along, bouncing back and forth between endless celebrity cameos [...] and joyless retreads of some of the original Zoolander's key moments.
A powerful political call-to-arms (or call-away-from-arms) is dulled, but never entirely diminished, by an inconsistent third act.
Despite half-hearted moves towards providing a new take on a classic story, Victor Frankenstein is less "aliiiiiive!" than trapped in a coma of its own making.
Jem and the Holograms is a top-notch example of a direct-to-DVD Disney movie. As a theatrical release...not so much.
If you're expecting anything like intelligence, subversion or social commentary [...] you'll walk away from Knock Knock disappointed.
A big ol' sack of dull.
Director Attila Till subverts expectations with a dark crime comedy more about its characters' inner lives than blood and body counts.
For all that real estate doesn't seem to be a particularly zippy topic, 99 Homes plays out like a moral thriller, with the stakes constantly ratcheting higher and higher.
As in Snowpiercer and The Host, Bong presents a dangerous world where people at all stages on the moral spectrum just have to do their best to survive. There are no easy victories or pat solutions.
If War of the Planet of the Apes doesn't take the summer blockbuster to new heights, it's still an exceptionally well-crafted film.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's not as funny as recent comedy hits like Spy, Shame, or Scott Pilgrim, but it'll do the job if you're looking for a boozy night out with the ladies.
It Comes at Night is a masterpiece of subjective storytelling.
A very solid offering that retains some of the magic of Disney's best.
Unfriended is a well-executed, refreshingly innovative little horror movie featuring teenagers behaving the way teenagers actually behave.
Wonder Woman might not be the greatest thing ever, but it is a damn fine film, and full admission: I spent a good chunk of it honest-to-God misty eyed.
It's not that good. It's not even interestingly bad.
Alien: Covenant has all the same problems that Prometheus did, but the highs are higher, and the lows aren't as low.
Tension escalates in this spare Australian thriller.
Rote and only intermittently amusing.
Ham-fisted mish-mosh occasionally delivers the goods.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: How to Be a Latin Lover reads like a watered-down version of something frequent Marino collaborator David Wain might have done. Very watered-down. Like five parts Wain to fifteen parts water. Which is better than I expected, if less than I wanted.
movie_title: How to Be a Latin Lover (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A you-are-there approach elevates this LA riots doc above the realm of a dry history lesson.
You have to see this movie on the big screen if at all possible. There's a 2001 Space Gate-esque sequence that had me in full hand-to-my-heart mode.
Scrappy and surreal, this GKids release should appeal to both eccentric teenagers and onetime eccentric teenagers with fond memories of "Daria" and "Clone High."
movie_title: My Entire High School Sinking Into the Sea (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Wilson works better in ten-minute segments than it does as a complete movie.

For fans of the '91 Beauty and the Beast, you'd do better rewatching that movie than watching this. But you can't exactly see the '91 movie on a big screen anymore, so this one is a fine (if inferior) substitution.
There's nothing even remotely inventive at play here.
Better than expected, worse than hoped for.

There's one element, though, that keeps Personal Shopper together as a compelling whole, and that is Stewart's performance as the grieving, shell-shocked, disengaged yet yearning -- for connection, for an end to the emotional numbness -- Maureen.
I love this movie.
It's a great movie -- one of the best horror films in recent memory, in fact.
Visually innovative fairytale adaptation should appeal to fans of experimental animation.
movie_title: The Girl Without Hands (La Jeune fille sans mains) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Charlize Theron is a Stoli-swilling superspy extraordinaire in David Leitch's worthy follow-up to John Wick.
The team behind Prey at Night is great at building tension and atmosphere-one only wishes they knew how to deliver a payoff.
Black Panther succeeds at being emotionally resonant in a way a lot of Marvel movies-a lot of blockbusters, period-don't.
Kiyoshi Kurosawa weaves a handful of stranger-in-a-strange-land tropes together in new and interesting ways in the darkly comic alien-invasion drama Before We Vanish.
One hour and 47 minutes of cheap jump scares and dull grinding of gears.
Nothing less than the smartest, most nuanced, most ambitious Star Wars film ever made.
Painful, but it's positive, too. It's walking that line that takes The Disaster Artist beyond cringe comedy to an unexpectedly touching tribute to a 21st-century icon.
One of the best performances of the year toplines Sebastián Lelio's stirring drama of grief and identity.

It's such a harmless nothing of a movie that being being bounced around in my seat and sprayed in the face with water was actually pretty fun. And it kept me from falling asleep, besides. Geostorm is the perfect 4D movie. Put it on the poster.
Happy Death Day is stupid, but not in the fun way.
Wonder Woman gets a real-life origin story in the bold, compassionate, sexy Professor Marston and the Wonder Women.
Does Battle of the Sexes break new ground in terms of cinematic form? No. But it's an exceedingly well-done film...
With American Assassin, Michael Cuesta (Kill the Messenger) has made a movie where Michael Keaton bites Taylor Kitsch's ear off unspeakably boring.
Though suffering from diminishing returns, the LEGO franchise still has some spark.
Vaughn has crafted a film that's stylish and amusing and makes wonderful use of Elton John, and that's not something every director can manage.
The great comeback of Pennywise the killer clown is scary and surprisingly fun.
I don't want to make Tulip Fever sound more interesting than it is. It's not bad enough to fall into "so bad it's good territory."
Adam Wingard's manga adaptation about a teen terror and his killer book does a half-decent job of embracing its weirdness.
If nothing to write home about, it's still not awful. You could catch this on HBO and be pretty impressed.
Not gonna lie to you: I wasn't expecting to like Annabelle: Creation.
No matter how bad you expected The Emoji Movie to be, believe me when I tell you, from the bottom of my heart, that it is so much worse.
Bonni Cohen and Jon Shenk check in with climate crusader Al Gore in this effective, if too loosely structured, doc.
movie_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It is a good movie. One bordering on great, even. The best movie Christopher Nolan's done in years... and I say that as someone who likes (most, sorry The Dark Knight Rises) Nolan movies.
Before I Fall is a melodramatic, "inspirational" bit of teen schlock where everyone in it is a sociopath.
Ghost in the Shell is bland, soulless garbage.
An upbeat, even charming look at the lives of a group of orphans living in a French group home.
movie_title: My Life as a Zucchini (Ma vie de courgette) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Stunning visuals go a long way towards enlivening this largely unexceptional superhero origin story.
Calling this movie "half-baked" gives it too much credit -- it is none baked, completely raw and run-through with salmonella.
I wish I could tell you Miss Peregrine is good, except it isn't. It's not bad, either. It is, you might say, a movie that exists.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's fine. It's good and fine. It is good and fine and decent and completely, in all ways, an acceptable movie.
The main problem The Girl on the Train has is that it's a Lifetime movie, but it doesn't know it's a Lifetime movie.
Lush, romantic Bollywood drama joins the ranks of the year's most beautiful films.
Trite and annoying.
It is a slow-motion trainwreck of a movie.
I really wish The Edge of Seventeen had been around when I was seventeen.
Can Jenny Slate be in all the movies?
If you're an Austen fan, be prepared to wince your way through original P&P bits.
It's beautiful. This movie is beautiful.

I'm not a hardcore horror fan, so I can't say whether hardcore horror fans will like this movie. But I can say that I think Poltergeist has potential outside the group of people who normally see horror movies.
You know when you see a movie, and you don't hate it, but you don't love it, either?

It's particularly nice to see Schwarzenegger get the chance to take on a more nuanced role than what he normally gets. He does well with it, too. It's just not enough to sustain a whole movie. A really good short film: Yes.
The script could have used another draft or five to tease out character intricacies.
The new movie from M. Night Shyamalan... is... good?
No one expects low-budget horror sequels to be the height of innovation. But it's still a shame, because it left a talented director without much to work with.
We get Radha Mitchell, surrounded by Pottery Barn furnishings and moping, and Kevin Bacon conducting a valiant effort to keep himself from falling asleep.
I did not laugh a single time during this movie.
[A] 131-minute movie [that feels] like it took up six hours of my everloving life.
One of the best, most unexpected movies of the year.
It's funny, it's frenetic, it's filled with over-the-top violence and it's occasionally just plain twisted.
There are some scenes in Ted 2 that you might want to look up on YouTube later, but there's no reason to subject yourself to the whole thing.
I'm all for thoughtful, character-driven genre films, but Maggie just drags.
2017 could use a good comedy, and it finally has one, in the form of The LEGO Batman Movie.
There's enough good to make A Cure for Wellness watchable, but too much bad to elevate it above the merely middling.
There's the odd jump scare -- Samara, barely present in her own movie, seen through a keyhole; an umbrella loudly popping open right into the camera -- but that's about it.
It's a great movie -- one of the greatest of the year, I'd say -- but it's not a particularly feel-good endeavor.
That's what you get from A Dog's Purpose: emotional torture porn of the canine variety. Its sole purpose is cheap emotional manipulation.

This movie tries to gaslight you into thinking its central baddie is actually well-thought-out (and is, presumably, worthy of sequels that God willing won't happen), when really it's the most generic crap, both in terms of substance and character design.
Though generic in the extreme, Monster Trucks still boasts a charming throwback feel.
A slow-burning, utterly immersive, claustrophobic, chilling little number.
The boring parts of the movie water the good parts down, leaving a whole that's a solid have-it-on-in-the-background-on-Netflix option, but not something to spend $10 on in a theatre.
An audacious mix of genres, A Monster Calls brings a dark, fantastical twist to a tale of childhood grief.
20th Century Women, in a very real way, is about the evolution of the American female psyche.
Collateral Beauty is nonsensical, but it's not nonsensical in a Winter's Tale flying rainbow horse way. It's just dull.
There's absolutely nothing to it.
Good god, but Assassin's Creed is dull.
A boring story told by staggeringly bad actors [...] spouting wooden lines of dialogue.
Nary a surprise, nary a scare.
The ending is a let-down, with all attempts at plot twists falling flat.
Though slapdash in terms of story [...], Fantastic Beasts is enjoyable enough to offset many of its problems.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: So bad. Atrocious. But not in an interesting way. Just a completely pointless movie all-around.
Do not let yourself be fooled. This movie is bad.
A more-than-worthy addition to the galaxy far far away.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Childhood best friends reconnect in this sweet, sun-drenched LGBT romance.
Luca Guadagnino's shimmering remake of Jacques Deray's 1969 La Piscine transports the action to the far-flung Italian island of Pantelleria, an outpost for celebrities wanting to discreetly recharge.
The film lays out its subject like an enticing quest, as if many mysteries are about to be uncovered.
movie_title: Revolution - New Art for a New World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Otto Bell's beautiful, cinematically innovative documentary ... strikes at the very heart of our primal instincts to strive and succeed.
Nick Leeson, as the tale goes, was the man who had everything -- intelligence, charm, dream wife and job -- and spectacularly lost it. Unfortunately, Rogue Trader fares little better.
Alvarez' film would almost qualify as a psychological thriller if it weren't a faithful, slightly dramatized reenactment of history, and if we didn't already know how it ended.
Sarsgaard is exceptional in the role. His embodiment of Milgram's measured demeanour is ferociously calm - almost chilling.

Almost Christmas goes light enough on the cliché and gives the stacked cast - which also includes J.B. Smoove, Gabrielle Union, Omar Epps and Romany Malco - enough decent material that the film remains relatively lively.
Cats, despite what any dog people reading may suggest, do make great friends, especially if you give them a whole city's worth of space.
Despite the constant reincarnations, A Dog's Purpose doesn't contain much in the way of spirituality. But any agnostic big-picture messaging it may be reaching for doesn't quite come through, either.
An oddly compelling documentary that sheds light on an important - albeit forgotten - cornerstone of modern, contemporary cuisine.

If most of us are paying attention to our food (one way or another) those actually making the stuff ought to start paying a different kind of attention, as well - if only for the length of a world's fair.
What a rare pleasure to see a classic book adapted for the screen and walk out feeling neither bored, offended nor outraged.
Though the film lacks the elegance of Kieslowski's later and better known work, its irony and playfulness presage things to come. Definitely worth checking out if you're a fan.
The movie may not amount to much, but the genial tone and exceptionally good performances from the three leads make for a winning debut by the Duplass brothers.
No one has bothered to develop a coherent story or remotely likable characters to sustain the CGI effects, ear-splitting music, and hyperactive editing.
Pretty tough to sit through.
Admirably low-key, yet [director Daniel] Burman's relaxed approach becomes a liability -- everything goes down smoothly but leaves one hungry for something more substantial.
The astronaut interviews are fun and occasionally moving...
movie_title: In the Shadow of the Moon (2007)

movie_review_blurb: While few of the paper-thin characters register long enough to make much of an impression, Diesel carries the movie with his unsettling mix of Zen-like tranquillity and barely controlled rage.
A cringe-inducing flop.
The movie is breezily fun and every bit as entertaining as its predecessors.
Unexpectedly witty and affecting.
Seriously undermined by the skeletal script, which barely develops the characters and unintentionally raises more questions about Kearns's quixotic battle than it answers.
There's something genuinely transgressive beneath the movie's rom-com surface, though director Howard Deutch keeps retreating to the safety of frat-boy humor.
This is shocking only for its tepidness; except for some raunchy language, it's ready-made for basic cable.
movie_title: Van Wilder: The Rise of Taj (Van Wilder 2) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: if you can get past the cutesy mugging and preening onstage, you may find the true creative talent refreshing.
Embracing evolutionary theory will turn you into a close-minded, God-denying Nazi -- that's the upshot of this ludicrous propaganda piece.

Without resorting to any background narration, Which Way Home raises questions about cross-border immigration policies and the macro-economic causes that propel people from struggling countries to stream into developed ones.
Too bad some studio executive didn't post a 'wrong way' sign when this road picture was pitched.
It washes up on the beach like a dead whale.

Right off the bat you should know that A Girl Like Her is essentially an anti-bullying Public Service Announcement. If you go into the film knowing this, then it's easier to appreciate the good things that the movie has going for it.
Cooke (a Rose Byrne doppelgänger) can convey incredible sadness with a shoulder shrug, or giddy excitement with a widened eye. She's a real surprise, and fascinating to watch.
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Results is a meandering, overly long film in which a lot of stuff happens, but none of it is all that interesting.
Yael Melamede's illuminating documentary, (Dis)Honesty: The Truth About Lies, delves into the reasons why we lie and how we rationalize it.
Admittedly, it's a predictable storyline, as exciting to watch as it is to read, saved only by Eddie Marsan, who is absolutely superb as the large-hearted loner.
